description: This course will help you to acquire the skills required to deploy and configure System Center 2012 R2 Operations Manager for Cloud and Datacenter monitoring. Architecture of a SCOM Monitoring Group, upgrading and/or migrating to SCOM 2012 R2, Management Pack creation, importing, and customization are all discussed and demonstrated. In addition, how to configure end-to-end service monitoring, fabric and application monitoring, and Application Performance Monitoring (APM) for .NET and Java applications are all covered. If you are new to SCOM 2102 R2, or have been using prior versions and want to update your skills, then this course will show you how.

If you are new to SCOM 2102 R2, or have been using prior versions and want to update your skills, then this course will show you how.

subtitle: Data Center Managing with SCOM

A lot of things have changed, if you're

your boss at work is saying hey,

[NOISE]

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Adam begin the series by giving you a quick overview of Microsoft System Center's main components which includes the App Controller, Config Manager, Endpoint Protection, Data Protection Manager, Ops Manager, Orchestrater, Service Manager, Virtual Machine Manager, and Advisor. They also compare/contrast System Center with Azure.
episodes.title: Overview and Architecture
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.280 --> 00:00:02.895
Welcome to ITProTV,
I'm your host [CROSSTALK]

2
00:00:02.895 --> 00:00:05.406
>> Coming at you live from San Francisco

3
00:00:05.406 --> 00:00:06.138
[CROSSTALK]

4
00:00:06.138 --> 00:00:07.838
[MUSIC]

5
00:00:07.838 --> 00:00:12.123
>> You're watching ITProTV.

6
00:00:12.123 --> 00:00:13.912
>> All right, greetings everyone and

7
00:00:13.912 --> 00:00:16.750
welcome to another great
episode of ITProTV.

8
00:00:16.750 --> 00:00:20.770
I'm your host, Daniel Lowrie and
in today's episode, we are kicking off our

9
00:00:20.770 --> 00:00:25.350
Data Center Monitoring with Microsoft's
System Center Operations Manager series,

10
00:00:25.350 --> 00:00:27.220
and yes that is quite the mouthful.

11
00:00:27.220 --> 00:00:31.840
So we're gonna shorten that to Data Center
Monitoring with SCOM or Microsoft SCOM.

12
00:00:31.840 --> 00:00:34.540
And joining us in the studio, that's
right, the man, the myth, the legend.

13
00:00:34.540 --> 00:00:36.800
You know him as Mr. Adam Gordon.

14
00:00:36.800 --> 00:00:38.552
Adam, welcome sir, how are you doing-
>> How do you.

15
00:00:38.552 --> 00:00:39.358
[CROSSTALK]
>> Glad to have you.

16
00:00:39.358 --> 00:00:42.030
>> I am good, thank you for
inviting me to come back.

17
00:00:42.030 --> 00:00:45.500
Always a pleasure to spend time
talking about different technology.

18
00:00:45.500 --> 00:00:47.960
We're gonna focus on,
as Daniel was saying,

19
00:00:47.960 --> 00:00:53.490
Microsoft System Center Ops Manager
2012 R2 Data Center Cloud Monitoring.

20
00:00:53.490 --> 00:00:57.400
Commonly referred to, as you said,
Microsoft S COM or SCOM.

21
00:00:57.400 --> 00:01:02.010
We're gonna spend some time really
going into the System Center suite,

22
00:01:02.010 --> 00:01:05.160
primarily focusing on
System Center Office Manager.

23
00:01:05.160 --> 00:01:07.821
We'll take a little look here and
there at some of the other technology.

24
00:01:07.821 --> 00:01:10.460
We're actually gonna start
out by talking about

25
00:01:10.460 --> 00:01:14.063
what makes up the System Center
Ops Manager technology platform,

26
00:01:14.063 --> 00:01:18.390
by looking at the associated products
that are part of the System Center suite.

27
00:01:18.390 --> 00:01:19.680
We'll talk about those.

28
00:01:19.680 --> 00:01:23.490
We're gonna broadly focus on
the concepts of data center management,

29
00:01:23.490 --> 00:01:26.940
take a look at what it means to be
able to do continuous monitoring

30
00:01:26.940 --> 00:01:28.990
from the Microsoft platform perspective.

31
00:01:28.990 --> 00:01:30.610
How do we set up SCOM?

32
00:01:30.610 --> 00:01:31.800
How do we get it up and running?

33
00:01:31.800 --> 00:01:33.450
What's the architecture look like?

34
00:01:33.450 --> 00:01:35.180
What are our deployment options?

35
00:01:35.180 --> 00:01:40.000
How do we use it to connect to a variety
of different technology platforms,

36
00:01:40.000 --> 00:01:43.330
monitor both Microsoft and
non-Microsoft technology?

37
00:01:43.330 --> 00:01:48.110
Can we do cross-platform
monitoring outside of Microsoft,

38
00:01:48.110 --> 00:01:50.780
with virtualization and
private and public cloud stacks?

39
00:01:50.780 --> 00:01:52.590
The answer is, absolutely.

40
00:01:52.590 --> 00:01:55.010
So we're gonna be taking a look
at all that, pretty cool stuff.

41
00:01:55.010 --> 00:01:59.470
And along the way, as we always do,
we'll tell you some interesting stories.

42
00:01:59.470 --> 00:02:02.908
Daniel and I, I'm sure, will come up with
some interesting ways to refer to things.

43
00:02:02.908 --> 00:02:06.147
We're also gonna try to do as
many hands on demonstrations for

44
00:02:06.147 --> 00:02:07.214
you as we can fit in.

45
00:02:07.214 --> 00:02:10.602
We'll be going ake a look at how to build,
how to deploy, how to manage and

46
00:02:10.602 --> 00:02:11.381
how to monitor.

47
00:02:11.381 --> 00:02:15.570
We'll be going into detailed
demonstrations around all of that.

48
00:02:15.570 --> 00:02:19.550
So having said that, let's talk about
what makes up the System Center stack.

49
00:02:19.550 --> 00:02:23.510
System Center, as a product line and
a group of products,

50
00:02:23.510 --> 00:02:25.450
has really grown over the years.

51
00:02:25.450 --> 00:02:27.800
Back in the day early on,

52
00:02:27.800 --> 00:02:31.590
when I first started working with these
individual products one at a time.

53
00:02:31.590 --> 00:02:35.330
There was no such thing as
System Center as a suite of products.

54
00:02:35.330 --> 00:02:40.290
There was the System Center Ops Manager
back then would have been called MOM.

55
00:02:40.290 --> 00:02:42.150
Microsoft Ops Manager.

56
00:02:42.150 --> 00:02:47.021
System Center Configuration Manager would
have been a different product name.

57
00:02:47.021 --> 00:02:50.340
And it would have been, really,
just individual products.

58
00:02:50.340 --> 00:02:52.950
There was no data protection
manager back then.

59
00:02:52.950 --> 00:02:57.520
So we didn't really have a formal
enterprise level backup solution.

60
00:02:57.520 --> 00:02:58.856
Or Microsoft didn't, anyway.

61
00:02:58.856 --> 00:03:02.152
FCCM System Center Config Manager
would have been called SMS,

62
00:03:02.152 --> 00:03:04.340
Systems Management Server, back then.

63
00:03:04.340 --> 00:03:07.590
And when I say back then,
I mean really way back [LAUGH] right?

64
00:03:07.590 --> 00:03:12.290
We're talking about many, many years ago,
because these products started out as

65
00:03:12.290 --> 00:03:15.340
individual pieces of
a broader puzzle that,

66
00:03:15.340 --> 00:03:19.840
over time, Microsoft has knitted
together into a suite of products.

67
00:03:19.840 --> 00:03:21.890
But there was no Data Protection Manager,

68
00:03:21.890 --> 00:03:25.590
there was no orchestrater
to do work flow directly.

69
00:03:25.590 --> 00:03:29.570
There was no endpoint Protection Manager,

70
00:03:29.570 --> 00:03:33.390
although there was the acquisition of
a company called Sabari years ago.

71
00:03:33.390 --> 00:03:36.520
You may or may not remember,
I don't know if you remember Sabari.

72
00:03:36.520 --> 00:03:40.240
But they were one of the number one,
or they were in the top two or

73
00:03:40.240 --> 00:03:43.090
three AV vendors, years and years ago.

74
00:03:43.090 --> 00:03:46.066
For Exchange in particular,
they were really well known,

75
00:03:46.066 --> 00:03:47.750
this was what they specialised in.

76
00:03:47.750 --> 00:03:51.272
Microsoft went out and acquired them,
among many other companies, and

77
00:03:51.272 --> 00:03:54.852
turned their technology into what you
may more commonly know these days as

78
00:03:54.852 --> 00:03:55.901
Forefront, right?

79
00:03:55.901 --> 00:04:00.169
So, the Forefront product line, and
all the protections that come with that,

80
00:04:00.169 --> 00:04:02.550
although that's kind of moving away.

81
00:04:02.550 --> 00:04:06.690
Threat Mitigation Gateway, TMG,
which is what the proxy server technology

82
00:04:06.690 --> 00:04:10.980
kinda morphed into,
along with the forefront technology,

83
00:04:10.980 --> 00:04:14.890
has really all been blended back in and
is changing around.

84
00:04:14.890 --> 00:04:17.930
And become what we think of as
Endpoint Protection Manager for

85
00:04:17.930 --> 00:04:20.600
System Center Config Manager,
and Endpoint Management,

86
00:04:20.600 --> 00:04:23.140
essentially mobile device
management on the endpoint side.

87
00:04:23.140 --> 00:04:26.840
So we have that as part of the platform
today, we didn't really have that before.

88
00:04:26.840 --> 00:04:31.530
Service manager, which is our help desk
service level management software.

89
00:04:31.530 --> 00:04:36.220
Think of Heat, think of Remedy,
think of Servicenow, Service Desk.

90
00:04:36.220 --> 00:04:39.230
Products like that,
that are competitive in that space,

91
00:04:39.230 --> 00:04:41.160
that's what service manager does.

92
00:04:41.160 --> 00:04:44.040
SCVMMs, System Center
Virtual Machine Manager.

93
00:04:44.040 --> 00:04:48.210
That is our competitive product
on the Microsoft side for

94
00:04:48.210 --> 00:04:53.320
VMWare's V Center for Citrix,
the Zen Center's N Server, etc.

95
00:04:53.320 --> 00:04:58.240
So that's our centralized management
thought process for hyper V hosts, and

96
00:04:58.240 --> 00:04:59.670
virtualization.

97
00:04:59.670 --> 00:05:05.140
When we more broadly think about the Cloud
today, and think about Microsoft centric

98
00:05:05.140 --> 00:05:09.700
technology around how to use the Cloud,
set a private Clouds, monitor manage.

99
00:05:09.700 --> 00:05:13.740
We link to Virtual Machine manager to
create what we would call the fabric,

100
00:05:13.740 --> 00:05:16.420
control of the network fabric,
the storage fabric,

101
00:05:16.420 --> 00:05:22.290
the public private interfaces to Azure, to
the Cloud fabric, and monitor in manage.

102
00:05:22.290 --> 00:05:25.540
All of that virtualization and
technology through those two products.

103
00:05:25.540 --> 00:05:29.310
And we have what's called System Center
Advisor, System Center Advisor is

104
00:05:29.310 --> 00:05:34.040
an online service that we can connect to
and buy a subscription to, that allows us

105
00:05:34.040 --> 00:05:39.505
to utilize Microsoft Azure to analyze the
configuration of servers and applications.

106
00:05:39.505 --> 00:05:44.625
And interact with them, connect them back
in, to the SCOM products among others and

107
00:05:44.625 --> 00:05:48.115
work with them, so
we have an entire suite of products.

108
00:05:48.115 --> 00:05:51.495
Wait I forgot App Controller as well,
the App Controller lets us manage

109
00:05:51.495 --> 00:05:54.625
the deployment of virtual machines
across public and private clouds.

110
00:05:54.625 --> 00:05:58.203
Another intrical part of what we
talk about in link with SCVMM.

111
00:05:58.203 --> 00:06:02.390
All of these products are now
part of the System Center suite.

112
00:06:02.390 --> 00:06:03.420
As I said before,

113
00:06:03.420 --> 00:06:07.920
a lot of these products along
the historical arc did not even exist.

114
00:06:07.920 --> 00:06:10.270
And as they started to exist, existed and

115
00:06:10.270 --> 00:06:14.120
became parts of what we now think of
as a System Center suite of products.

116
00:06:14.120 --> 00:06:17.540
So when you're thinking about
System Center, you're thinking about,

117
00:06:17.540 --> 00:06:21.450
at this point in time, nine different
products that are linked together.

118
00:06:21.450 --> 00:06:26.480
And that you typically will buy with
an enterprise agreement, some sort of open

119
00:06:26.480 --> 00:06:31.450
license enterprise agreement, or
some sort of arrangement with Microsoft.

120
00:06:31.450 --> 00:06:33.871
There's different ways
to go with licensing,

121
00:06:33.871 --> 00:06:38.104
everything really depends on your seed
count and how you're going to spend money,

122
00:06:38.104 --> 00:06:42.112
whether you want to buy upfront one time,
purchase over three years with a EA.

123
00:06:42.112 --> 00:06:44.712
An enterprise agreements lets
you spread those payments out.

124
00:06:44.712 --> 00:06:48.506
Whether you're going to get software
insurance, so you get update rights and

125
00:06:48.506 --> 00:06:52.460
upgrade rights year over year and so
there's a lot of different ways to go.

126
00:06:52.460 --> 00:06:54.450
Probably need to just do a whole
show just on nothing but

127
00:06:54.450 --> 00:06:55.790
Microsoft licensing in theory.

128
00:06:55.790 --> 00:06:57.320
>> [LAUGH]
>> Cuz it's so complicated and

129
00:06:57.320 --> 00:07:00.160
so diverse, and
rich in terms of the options.

130
00:07:00.160 --> 00:07:04.790
But however you get there, ultimately,
when you buy this product,

131
00:07:04.790 --> 00:07:06.410
you're buying a suite of products.

132
00:07:06.410 --> 00:07:08.240
You're usually not just
buying one product.

133
00:07:08.240 --> 00:07:11.860
You can license just SCOM,
let's say, individually.

134
00:07:11.860 --> 00:07:15.610
But the reality is, you're probably
buying the entire suite as a business.

135
00:07:15.610 --> 00:07:20.220
And then using that suite of products
to be able to drive much broader

136
00:07:20.220 --> 00:07:21.750
across the enterprise or

137
00:07:21.750 --> 00:07:25.630
across the organization integration
of your entire technology stack.

138
00:07:25.630 --> 00:07:27.470
So it's kind of an interesting approach.

139
00:07:27.470 --> 00:07:31.380
When we think about getting started with
SCOM, what we're really thinking about is

140
00:07:31.380 --> 00:07:35.650
how do we take this product,
continuous operational monitoring, and

141
00:07:35.650 --> 00:07:38.550
link it to all of these other
products that we were talking about?

142
00:07:38.550 --> 00:07:40.970
So what I wanted to show you,
just by way of getting started,

143
00:07:40.970 --> 00:07:43.300
if we can go to my machine for
just one second.

144
00:07:43.300 --> 00:07:47.620
Was exactly that, how do we get started
with System Center 12 Ops Manager?

145
00:07:47.620 --> 00:07:50.679
Microsoft's got a bunch of real
estate out there on the web.

146
00:07:50.679 --> 00:07:55.499
Throughout our episodes, throughout all of
the shows associated with this particular

147
00:07:55.499 --> 00:07:59.927
set of topics, we're gonna be taking you
out to a series of Microsoft websites,

148
00:07:59.927 --> 00:08:03.508
all through TechNet primarily,
that are gonna help you to better

149
00:08:03.508 --> 00:08:08.067
understand this product Features of it,
specifications around how to deploy it,

150
00:08:08.067 --> 00:08:10.710
steps involved with
certain aspects of usage.

151
00:08:10.710 --> 00:08:13.270
That way you've got
a complete documentation,

152
00:08:13.270 --> 00:08:17.524
thought process on your side that you can
refer to if you're new to this product.

153
00:08:17.524 --> 00:08:20.025
If you've been using it for
a very long time, but

154
00:08:20.025 --> 00:08:23.442
just need to understand a specific
approach to a certain problem.

155
00:08:23.442 --> 00:08:26.882
If you are dipping your toe in the water
because somebody's already set it

156
00:08:26.882 --> 00:08:27.444
up for you.

157
00:08:27.444 --> 00:08:31.930
And you've been given the task or
the necessary abilities.

158
00:08:31.930 --> 00:08:33.909
Your boss has said hey, Daniel or whoever,

159
00:08:33.909 --> 00:08:37.449
right, you're gonna take this product
over, we need you to get spun up on it.

160
00:08:37.449 --> 00:08:39.412
Well obviously you're in
the right place to do that.

161
00:08:39.412 --> 00:08:43.651
But aside from that, you're gonna wanna
refer back to these particular items and

162
00:08:43.651 --> 00:08:46.220
read up on these a little
bit more in depth.

163
00:08:46.220 --> 00:08:47.925
It's great to listen to us talk, but

164
00:08:47.925 --> 00:08:50.467
the reality is you may wanna
little more specificity.

165
00:08:50.467 --> 00:08:54.389
And keep in mind that over time,
as the product emerges and

166
00:08:54.389 --> 00:08:59.445
then ultimately goes through revisions,
and updates with new features.

167
00:08:59.445 --> 00:09:03.909
There may be a slight difference in what

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Adam continue their tour of Microsoft's System Center Operations Manager(SCOM). Here they look over the key features found in SCOM like Management Servers, Databases, Agents, Reporting, Management Packs, Operations/Web Consoles, and Gateway Servers.

00:16:27.265 --> 00:16:30.824

All those things online, Azure.

We have management packs

So we download those, either from

Typically indirectly cuz you

So you'll either download them and

machine somewhere or

A web-based website,
the Microsoft web-based website,

382
00:19:04.070 --> 00:19:05.480
because that's not redundant, right?

00:19:05.480 --> 00:19:08.780
A website that Microsoft maintains

00:19:08.780 --> 00:19:10.980
System Center management pack catalog.

And we go out and

00:19:11.703 --> 00:19:15.340
we download those management packs

00:19:15.340 --> 00:19:17.280
So we have options, we do that either way.

00:19:17.280 --> 00:19:18.880
We could also create our

we'll take a look at how to

390
00:19:21.200 --> 00:19:26.370
But we'll essentially right-click new
management pack in the ops console,

391
00:19:26.370 --> 00:19:28.030
the administration space.

392
00:19:28.030 --> 00:19:29.590
We'll go to the management pack item.

393
00:19:29.590 --> 00:19:30.117
We'll right click.

394
00:19:30.117 --> 00:19:31.600
We'll create a new management pack.

395
00:19:31.600 --> 00:19:32.850
That is a very simple process.

396
00:19:32.850 --> 00:19:34.100
Takes about three steps.

397
00:19:34.100 --> 00:19:35.010
And we just create a shell.

398
00:19:35.010 --> 00:19:36.750
Essentially, just a container.

399
00:19:36.750 --> 00:19:38.030
That we call a management pack.

400
00:19:38.030 --> 00:19:40.390
But we don't populate it with
anything in that first step.

401
00:19:40.390 --> 00:19:42.871
We just name it,
we may provide some knowledge,

402
00:19:42.871 --> 00:19:45.782
some detailed descriptions of what it is,
and we hit OK.

403
00:19:45.782 --> 00:19:48.727
And then it's created as what's
called an unsealed management pack,

404
00:19:48.727 --> 00:19:50.550
a management pack we can modify.

405
00:19:50.550 --> 00:19:54.360
Management packs we download from
vendors are traditionally sealed.

406
00:19:54.360 --> 00:19:55.750
They have little lock on them,

407
00:19:55.750 --> 00:19:57.880
you can tell the difference

408
00:19:57.880 --> 00:20:02.300
And the idea is that those have to
be modified by creating a copy,

409
00:20:02.300 --> 00:20:05.200
a secondary management pack that's open,
unsealed.

410
00:20:05.200 --> 00:20:06.656
That we put all the changes into or

411
00:20:06.656 --> 00:20:09.523
the overrides that we want to use
against the management packet.

412
00:20:09.523 --> 00:20:11.563
This is language we'll come
to talk more about and

413
00:20:11.563 --> 00:20:13.530
be more comfortable with over time.

414
00:20:13.530 --> 00:20:16.530
But when we create our own management
packs, they're unsealed directly.

415
00:20:16.530 --> 00:20:19.320
We cannot operate on them without
having to create a secondary copy.

416
00:20:19.320 --> 00:20:22.270
And then, we go in and
we go to the authoring workspace and

417
00:20:22.270 --> 00:20:25.950
again we'll take a look at all this in
upcoming episodes in the ops console.

418
00:20:25.950 --> 00:20:31.330
And then, we go in to authoring and we
start to add in all of the various pieces

419
00:20:31.330 --> 00:20:34.750
that we wanna add to the management pack
and we'll walk through how to do this.

420
00:20:34.750 --> 00:20:39.080
Right click new monitor, right click new
rule, right click new task, new view,

421
00:20:39.080 --> 00:20:40.540
whatever the case may be.

422
00:20:40.540 --> 00:20:44.895
And we add them in in the wizard that we
go through depending on the kind of thing

423
00:20:44.895 --> 00:20:46.240
we're doing, add in.

424
00:20:46.240 --> 00:20:49.491
And one of the choices we make after we
name it and we configure it early on is

425
00:20:49.491 --> 00:20:51.970
what management pack do
we wanna associate with.

426
00:20:51.970 --> 00:20:53.350
We'll choose our management pack.

427
00:20:53.350 --> 00:20:57.099
We put all that stuff together and then
the container starts to fill up with all

428
00:20:57.099 --> 00:20:59.241
the objects that we're looking to create.

429
00:20:59.241 --> 00:21:02.727
And this is really the strength,
the value, of this tool is

430
00:21:02.727 --> 00:21:07.472
creating the customized management pack
solution that we want to be able to use or

431
00:21:07.472 --> 00:21:09.230
modify an existing one.

432
00:21:09.230 --> 00:21:13.810
To be able to give us that exact scoped
and tailored fixed capability that we're

433
00:21:13.810 --> 00:21:16.900
looking to achieve and
to be able to hone in just on that.

434
00:21:16.900 --> 00:21:18.790
So we're gonna talk about
how all that happens.

435
00:21:18.790 --> 00:21:20.900
But that's gonna be one of the parts
here that we have to think about

436
00:21:20.900 --> 00:21:22.006
as the management packs.

437
00:21:22.006 --> 00:21:25.280
We also have the aside from
the consoles that are sitting up there

438
00:21:25.280 --> 00:21:29.580
we also have the there's actually
two other consoles I didn't mention.

439
00:21:29.580 --> 00:21:33.310
The application diagnostics and
application advisor consoles.

440
00:21:33.310 --> 00:21:36.650
Those are also going to be used or
at least can be used.

441
00:21:36.650 --> 00:21:40.050
Those are going to provide us
detailed diagnostic capabilities for

442
00:21:40.050 --> 00:21:41.200
application monitoring.

443
00:21:41.200 --> 00:21:43.920
We'll get a little bit more into
those in an upcoming episode.

444
00:21:43.920 --> 00:21:45.730
I just didn't label them and
put them up on the diagram.

445
00:21:45.730 --> 00:21:47.040
Cuz they're not always used,

446
00:21:47.040 --> 00:21:50.640
depending on whether you're doing web
application transaction monitoring or not.

447
00:21:50.640 --> 00:21:53.687
But if you are, we have detailed
consults to let us do that as well.

448
00:21:53.687 --> 00:21:55.017
But the thing we haven't talked about yet

449
00:21:55.017 --> 00:21:57.200
is this thing right over here
called the gateway server.

450
00:21:57.200 --> 00:21:59.310
The gateway server is
an interesting concept.

451
00:21:59.310 --> 00:22:02.786
So if we have a bunch of agents
that are all well-connected,

452
00:22:02.786 --> 00:22:04.772
let's define well-connected.

453
00:22:04.772 --> 00:22:06.631
So, play a game with me, sir, if you will.

454
00:22:06.631 --> 00:22:11.115
When I say to you, well-connected, just
in traditional network infrastructure,

455
00:22:11.115 --> 00:22:12.246
what do you think of?

456
00:22:12.246 --> 00:22:14.869
What are some of the, in your mind,
some of the rules, the concepts,

457
00:22:14.869 --> 00:22:15.635
the warning signs?

458
00:22:15.635 --> 00:22:18.406
We would think of if we talk
about a well connected network.

459
00:22:18.406 --> 00:22:23.086
>> I think a well connected network would
be something that's physically connected

460
00:22:23.086 --> 00:22:27.437
by a high bandwidth media, something
get ethernet, something like that.

461
00:22:27.437 --> 00:22:29.518
>> Right, so a minimum threshold, right?

462
00:22:29.518 --> 00:22:31.180
High is a relative term.

463
00:22:31.180 --> 00:22:34.680
High bandwidth, but let's say low latency
may be another way of thinking about that

464
00:22:34.680 --> 00:22:36.280
which would essentially be the same thing.

465
00:22:36.280 --> 00:22:39.610
And that's the terminology we
actually use in our documentation.

466
00:22:39.610 --> 00:22:43.200
Low latency networks are what we talk
about, but as Daniel rightly said,

467
00:22:43.200 --> 00:22:47.210
essentially dedicated high bandwidth or
consistent bandwidth,

468
00:22:47.210 --> 00:22:50.390
always on,
good connectivity is what we look for.

469
00:22:50.390 --> 00:22:54.310
One of the most important concepts you
have to learn how to manage, master,

470
00:22:54.310 --> 00:22:58.340
define, and understand how to use and
deploy against.

471
00:22:58.340 --> 00:23:02.960
This is the idea of creating low latency
networks to optimize the architecture.

472
00:23:02.960 --> 00:23:06.531
And so when we think about creating
well connected systems with SCOM or

473
00:23:06.531 --> 00:23:10.221
across any of our infrastructure in
Microsoft, and indeed any vendor,

474
00:23:10.221 --> 00:23:11.638
it's not just Microsoft.

475
00:23:11.638 --> 00:23:16.030
But especially here, we often refer to
low latency networks as being important

476
00:23:16.030 --> 00:23:20.470
because the low latency concept allows
the machines that have agents on them to

477
00:23:20.470 --> 00:23:23.280
intact with the management
servers directly, and

478
00:23:23.280 --> 00:23:25.200
to communicate with them in real time.

479
00:23:25.200 --> 00:23:27.728
If we don't have reliable
consistent band width,

480
00:23:27.728 --> 00:23:31.790
the agents will catch data on the local
machines until they can report back up.

481
00:23:31.790 --> 00:23:36.419
If we lose a management server and there's
a failure in the redundancy portion of our

482
00:23:36.419 --> 00:23:39.563
fabric, we'll continue to monitor and
cache locally.

483
00:23:39.563 --> 00:23:42.557
And then we have to reconnect at
some point and upload all that data.

484
00:23:42.557 --> 00:23:45.540
But over time that's gonna grow to
become a burden on the machine.

485
00:23:45.540 --> 00:23:49.217
So we wanna try to keep redundancy there.

486
00:23:49.217 --> 00:23:52.320
Think about latency and
minimize the amount of latency there is.

487
00:23:52.320 --> 00:23:53.292
So we go back to the diagram.

488
00:23:53.292 --> 00:23:56.971
The idea here would be that with
well-connected networks, so the agents,

489
00:23:56.971 --> 00:24:00.879
let's say, that are directly over here if
we think of them behind the firewall On

490
00:24:00.879 --> 00:24:04.974
whatever the corporate LAN would be in
the data center, whatever that represents.

491
00:24:04.974 --> 00:24:08.824
These are connecting directly up
to the management server pool,

492
00:24:08.824 --> 00:24:13.164
because there is low latency and we don't
need to use a proxy of some kind or

493
00:24:13.164 --> 00:24:17.930
a gateway that will connect on their
behalf and facilitate communication.

494
00:24:17.930 --> 00:24:21.410
But when they're outside the agents that
are being monitored over here, as they

495
00:24:21.410 --> 00:24:25.810
are in this diagram, the firewall in
a remote site somewhere, however they're

496
00:24:25.810 --> 00:24:30.870
connected, but we may not have reliable
low latency bandwidth that's consistent.

497
00:24:30.870 --> 00:24:34.930
If we have five or more of those machines
that have to be monitored in a geography,

498
00:24:34.930 --> 00:24:39.120
that's our magic number five in this case,
then recommendation is, hey,

499
00:24:39.120 --> 00:24:40.880
let's put a gateway server out there.

500
00:24:40.880 --> 00:24:43.840
The gateway server's going to
facilitate communication with all of

501
00:24:43.840 --> 00:24:45.510
those remotely managed agents.

502
00:24:45.510 --> 00:24:47.590
Those agents will communicate
through the gateway.

503
00:24:47.590 --> 00:24:51.170
The gateway will then be responsible for
batching that communication back

504
00:24:51.170 --> 00:24:56.340
through whatever the firewall and or
other connectivity systems will be.

505
00:24:56.340 --> 00:25:00.820
Getting into the management server pool
and then facilitating communication.

506
00:25:00.820 --> 00:25:04.280
So the gateway server is gonna
be very important cuz we A,

507
00:25:04.280 --> 00:25:08.070
need to worry about low latency, B,
if there's no Kerberos authentication.

508
00:25:08.070 --> 00:25:10.660
Essentially these are remote
machines outside the domain

509
00:25:10.660 --> 00:25:14.640
that are not directly connected or in a
different domain that doesn't have a trust

510
00:25:14.640 --> 00:25:19.090
relationship through federation or
somehow an exchange of that trust.

511
00:25:19.090 --> 00:25:23.280
Then we need to use the gateway server
to act on behalf of those agents,

512
00:25:23.280 --> 00:25:24.430
gonna be very important.

513
00:25:24.430 --> 00:25:28.790
We use mutual authentication through the
gateway to facilitate this communication.

514
00:25:28.790 --> 00:25:31.920
The gateway server is gonna have
a certificate installed from

515
00:25:31.920 --> 00:25:33.290
the management server pool.

516
00:25:33.290 --> 00:25:36.080
And we're gonna be able to mutually
authenticate across this divide

517
00:25:36.080 --> 00:25:37.140
here, right?

518
00:25:37.140 --> 00:25:39.440
If I do that fast enough,
the firewall option goes away,

519
00:25:39.440 --> 00:25:41.700
and it looks like I'm
communicating in real-time.

520
00:25:41.700 --> 00:25:44.780
But we're going to implement
a communication pathway that's secure for

521
00:25:44.780 --> 00:25:49.150
the use of PKI, Public Key Infrastructure
Digital Certificates being deployed.

522
00:25:49.150 --> 00:25:52.420
And as a result of that,
we need a trusted CA.

523
00:25:52.420 --> 00:25:55.030
Typically, these are self-signed
internally issued

524
00:25:55.030 --> 00:25:56.590
certificates to the domain.

525
00:25:56.590 --> 00:25:58.630
So we're going to be
able to have our domain,

526
00:25:58.630 --> 00:26:02.470
let's say our LDAP provider over
here somewhere, issue certificates,

527
00:26:02.470 --> 00:26:04.980
employ them and
set them up on the gateway server, and

528
00:26:04.980 --> 00:26:09.570
then create a trust relationship that can
authenticate the gateway back in, and then

529
00:26:09.570 --> 00:26:13.120
as a result of that, when we implement the
gateway server and the management server

530
00:26:13.120 --> 00:26:16.990
relationship through these certificates,
we're then able to communicate securely.

531
00:26:16.990 --> 00:26:20.900
And the gateway can then act as that
trusted communication hub for all

532
00:26:20.900 --> 00:26:24.920
the external agents that are not domain
joined and are at a low latency area.

533
00:26:24.920 --> 00:26:29.130
So this removes the need to install
the certificate on every agent,

534
00:26:29.130 --> 00:26:31.040
which is nice cuz we don't
have to go through and

535
00:26:31.040 --> 00:26:34.540
deploy certificates out to all these
machines, deploy it to one central area,

536
00:26:34.540 --> 00:26:37.430
and then we just connect all
the agents up through the gateway, so

537
00:26:37.430 --> 00:26:41.730
it's a much smoother, much cleaner
transition to a managed infrastructure.

538
00:26:41.730 --> 00:26:44.400
So this thought process is new to 2012 R2.

539
00:26:44.400 --> 00:26:47.620
As I said,
we did different things in prior versions.

540
00:26:47.620 --> 00:26:48.300
A little bit cleaner,

541
00:26:48.300 --> 00:26:51.970
a little bit easier, little bit more
streamlined as a result of that.

542
00:26:51.970 --> 00:26:55.570
And it's easier for us,
as administrators, as architects,

543
00:26:55.570 --> 00:27:00.010
as managers, as implementors, people that
are gonna build this infrastructure,

544
00:27:00.010 --> 00:27:02.900
to be able to deploy successfully
out of the gate the first time

545
00:27:02.900 --> 00:27:07.280
cuz we're not messing around with all
of these concerns and issues, and

546
00:27:07.280 --> 00:27:11.230
opening up a lot of different pathways,
and installing certificates, and all that.

547
00:27:11.230 --> 00:27:13.910
Now, there is a fairly
detailed list of ports and

548
00:27:13.910 --> 00:27:17.100
firewall communication
that has to take place.

549
00:27:17.100 --> 00:27:20.360
We will take a look at this, and talk
more about this in an upcoming episode.

550
00:27:20.360 --> 00:27:22.270
It is a long laundry list,
I don't to kid you.

551
00:27:22.270 --> 00:27:24.100
There's a lot of ports.

552
00:27:24.100 --> 00:27:27.580
57, 23, and 24, for instance,
are gonna be big on that list.

553
00:27:27.580 --> 00:27:29.500
We're going to talk about
some others that are there.

554
00:27:29.500 --> 00:27:30.480
But it's a doable list.

555
00:27:30.480 --> 00:27:31.830
It's a manageable list.

556
00:27:31.830 --> 00:27:35.160
And it's only really critical if you're
communicating from the outside in.

557
00:27:35.160 --> 00:27:38.480
If you're on the inside behind
the firewall on the LAN.

558
00:27:38.480 --> 00:27:39.590
These ports are in play.

559
00:27:39.590 --> 00:27:42.560
You want to know them, so you can monitor
traffic and understand what you're seeing.

560
00:27:42.560 --> 00:27:43.160
But the reality is,

561
00:27:43.160 --> 00:27:46.220
you're probably not worried about
passing a lot of this traffic.

562
00:27:46.220 --> 00:27:49.180
Because firewalls are not
being used traditionally

563
00:27:49.180 --> 00:27:50.750
between segments of our network.

564
00:27:50.750 --> 00:27:55.430
There are holistic solutions that do use
firewalls to create protection enclaves,

565
00:27:55.430 --> 00:27:57.870
and carve out secure areas of networks.

566
00:27:57.870 --> 00:28:00.700
And I work with that kind of
infrastructure a lot, government and

567
00:28:00.700 --> 00:28:02.930
military networks, for
instance, are doing this.

568
00:28:02.930 --> 00:28:07.070
So we do wanna know what those firewall
ports are to make sure we can pass them.

569
00:28:07.070 --> 00:28:09.860
You may be running firewalls
on the local machines,

570
00:28:09.860 --> 00:28:11.840
the agent-based machines
that are being monitored.

571
00:28:11.840 --> 00:28:14.700
We may need to open traffic
there to allow communication.

572
00:28:14.700 --> 00:28:16.740
So it will be important
to be aware of that,

573
00:28:16.740 --> 00:28:18.700
but it's not unmanageable by any means.

574
00:28:18.700 --> 00:28:20.550
It's a fairly straightforward process and

575
00:28:20.550 --> 00:28:25.218
as a result we have a pretty easy to
deploy, easy to manage architecture.

576
00:28:25.218 --> 00:28:28.930
Now, correct me if I'm wrong sir,
but that picture that I created,

577
00:28:28.930 --> 00:28:32.300
we're gonna have digitally
signed autograph copies.

578
00:28:32.300 --> 00:28:33.619
>> Yeah, [CROSSTALK].
>> And we're gonna make them available for

579
00:28:33.619 --> 00:28:34.240
everybody, right?

580
00:28:34.240 --> 00:28:35.620
>> [LAUGH] I'll sign anything you want.

581
00:28:35.620 --> 00:28:37.780
>> We are gonna make that available for
you with the show nuts,

582
00:28:37.780 --> 00:28:38.320
if I'm not mistaken.

583
00:28:38.320 --> 00:28:40.100
>> That is correct.
>> They will be able to download that.

584
00:28:40.100 --> 00:28:43.620
You'll have just kind of a ready made,
generic diagram you can refer to.

585
00:28:43.620 --> 00:28:46.610
And if it's helpful just to throw
it up on the wall and to say, yeah,

586
00:28:46.610 --> 00:28:50.110
that's what I'm doing as I'm studying or
I'm applying to whatever, great.

587
00:28:50.110 --> 00:28:52.380
And if it's of value to you, use it.

588
00:28:52.380 --> 00:28:54.030
Can even tell people you made it yourself.

589
00:28:54.030 --> 00:28:56.530
I won't come to your house and
tell them otherwise but

590
00:28:56.530 --> 00:29:00.150
just make sure that you understand that
what I would see that diagram as being,

591
00:29:00.150 --> 00:29:03.350
what I use it with customers to do,
is to start talking about and

592
00:29:03.350 --> 00:29:07.950
sketching out what we're looking to
design, what are the issues that concerns.

593
00:29:07.950 --> 00:29:08.470
In other words,

594
00:29:08.470 --> 00:29:13.210
I use it as a skeleton to sketch out what
my architecture is gonna look like and

595
00:29:13.210 --> 00:29:16.645
I use it for my planning cycles with
customers to drive deployments.

596
00:29:16.645 --> 00:29:19.025
Because the picture
helps them to refer to,

597
00:29:19.025 --> 00:29:22.745
and visually get a reference for
the architecture we're trying to build.

598
00:29:22.745 --> 00:29:24.435
Hopefully it'll do the same for you.

599
00:29:24.435 --> 00:29:27.545
>> Yeah Adam, we'll have to take
one of those old 80s family photos

600
00:29:27.545 --> 00:29:29.405
where it's the black background, and

601
00:29:29.405 --> 00:29:31.915
our heads are just kind of floating,
looking off into the distance.

602
00:29:31.915 --> 00:29:32.765
You remember those?

603
00:29:32.765 --> 00:29:34.350
>> Yeah.
>> He knows the ones I'm talking about.

604
00:29:34.350 --> 00:29:35.500
Look at this, that'll be fun.

605
00:29:35.500 --> 00:29:38.620
But I know you got a little bit more
to go through on this very topic, but

606
00:29:38.620 --> 00:29:40.680
we're out of time for this episode.

607
00:29:40.680 --> 00:29:44.220
So it looks like we're gonna have to
roll this into another part three.

608
00:29:44.220 --> 00:29:44.840
That'll be a lot of fun.

609
00:29:44.840 --> 00:29:46.150
Hopefully, we'll see you guys there.

610
00:29:46.150 --> 00:29:47.720
Thanks, Adam, for this so far.

611
00:29:47.720 --> 00:29:48.230
>> Absolutely.

612
00:29:48.230 --> 00:29:49.720
>> But signing off for ITPRO.TV.

613
00:29:49.720 --> 00:29:51.500
I've been your host, Daniel Lowrie.

614
00:29:51.500 --> 00:29:52.480
>> I'm Adam Gordon.

615
00:29:52.480 --> 00:29:53.829
>> And we'll see you next time.

616
00:29:53.829 --> 00:30:01.030
[MUSIC]

617
00:30:01.030 --> 00:30:04.169
Thank you for watching ITProTV.

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Adam finish their tour of Microsoft's System Center Operations Manager(SCOM). Here they round out their overview of SCOM with some odds and ends like how SCOM focuses on and maintains productivity as well as some documentation for setup.
episodes.title: Overview and Architecture Part 3
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.010 --> 00:00:02.521
Welcome to ITProTV,
I'm your host Don Pezet.

2
00:00:02.521 --> 00:00:08.549
[CROSSTALK]

3
00:00:08.549 --> 00:00:12.100
>> You're watching ITProTV.

4
00:00:12.100 --> 00:00:13.840
>> All right, greetings everyone and

5
00:00:13.840 --> 00:00:16.990
welcome back to another
great episode of ITProTV.

6
00:00:16.990 --> 00:00:18.570
I'm your host, Daniel Lowrie.

7
00:00:18.570 --> 00:00:21.662
In today's episode, that's right,
as Adam has referred to-

8
00:00:21.662 --> 00:00:22.470
>> Part three.

9
00:00:22.470 --> 00:00:24.942
>> We are into a part three on
an overview and architecture.

10
00:00:24.942 --> 00:00:29.707
Things that we need to know to get started
talking about SCOM data center monitoring.

11
00:00:29.707 --> 00:00:31.413
That's what we're all about today.

12
00:00:31.413 --> 00:00:35.290
And obviously, joining me in the studio
is none other Mr Adam Gordon.

13
00:00:35.290 --> 00:00:35.945
Adam, welcome back man.

14
00:00:35.945 --> 00:00:36.675
How's it going?

15
00:00:36.675 --> 00:00:37.642
>> How do you, how do you.

16
00:00:37.642 --> 00:00:42.058
It is going well,
it is cloudrific here at ITPro TV.

17
00:00:42.058 --> 00:00:44.461
I would say data centertastic, but
that just would be over the cloud,

18
00:00:44.461 --> 00:00:44.961
would it not?

19
00:00:44.961 --> 00:00:46.264
>> Cloudy with a chance of monitoring.

20
00:00:46.264 --> 00:00:46.945
[LAUGH].

21
00:00:46.945 --> 00:00:48.867
>> Cloudy with chance of monitoring,
I like that.

22
00:00:48.867 --> 00:00:51.990
So, we're gonna continue our
conversations as Daniel was suggesting.

23
00:00:51.990 --> 00:00:54.230
Wanna go back to that diagram
we had up in the prior episode.

24
00:00:54.230 --> 00:00:55.670
Before we do, just to remind you,

25
00:00:55.670 --> 00:00:59.680
if you have not seen the last two
episodes in this particular series for

26
00:00:59.680 --> 00:01:02.655
the introduction, the overview and
architecture show.

27
00:01:02.655 --> 00:01:05.105
But if you have certainly, great,
we're gonna jump right back in.

28
00:01:05.105 --> 00:01:09.331
If you haven't, especially episode two,
we talked a lot about the architecture,

29
00:01:09.331 --> 00:01:13.276
the set up, the moving parts, and the
building blocks for how to deploy SCOM.

30
00:01:13.276 --> 00:01:16.042
What a management group is,
how that all comes together.

31
00:01:16.042 --> 00:01:19.338
Encourage you to take a look at that, only
cuz you wanna be able to keep track of

32
00:01:19.338 --> 00:01:22.026
what we're about to talk about
now to kind of build on that, and

33
00:01:22.026 --> 00:01:24.498
know where that diagram comes from and
how to explain it.

34
00:01:24.498 --> 00:01:27.237
So if you need to take a few moments,
go back maybe watch that first.

35
00:01:27.237 --> 00:01:28.521
Come on back and join us afterwards.

36
00:01:28.521 --> 00:01:32.521
Great, if not then let's jump right in.

37
00:01:32.521 --> 00:01:34.473
Awesome.
I gotta figure out a way to do it

38
00:01:34.473 --> 00:01:36.827
like this, so that it-
>> Remember, to your right.

39
00:01:36.827 --> 00:01:37.981
>> Yeah, I can never get that right.

40
00:01:37.981 --> 00:01:40.367
>> [LAUGH]
>> But anyway, so that's where we are.

41
00:01:40.367 --> 00:01:42.546
So, I wanted to bring up a few
extra points about this.

42
00:01:42.546 --> 00:01:45.511
We didn't get quite a chance to
cover in our last discussion,

43
00:01:45.511 --> 00:01:49.640
we had run out of time, so
we're doing so many cool things there.

44
00:01:49.640 --> 00:01:51.570
But we talked about the idea
of the best practices,

45
00:01:51.570 --> 00:01:55.890
the low latency concept and using
the gateway server to help manage that.

46
00:01:55.890 --> 00:01:58.674
What I wanted to bring out was
the idea of the resource pool here,

47
00:01:58.674 --> 00:01:59.980
who we've already spoken about.

48
00:01:59.980 --> 00:02:02.329
This is a generic resource
pool in the diagram,

49
00:02:02.329 --> 00:02:06.337
it could be Windows infrastructure,
it could be Linox or Unix infrastructure.

50
00:02:06.337 --> 00:02:12.377
It could be a set of, or monitoring what
I mean to say, the management server.

51
00:02:12.377 --> 00:02:14.483
So, monitoring that
kind of infrastructure.

52
00:02:14.483 --> 00:02:17.945
Could be web infrastructure,
web applications, that kind of thing.

53
00:02:17.945 --> 00:02:22.642
So, the idea would be if we want to be
able to bring together certain kinds

54
00:02:22.642 --> 00:02:25.106
of infrastructure and monitor them,

55
00:02:25.106 --> 00:02:29.964
we may wanna create a resource pool
dedicated for that kind of monitoring.

56
00:02:29.964 --> 00:02:32.834
So that way we have management
servers dedicated just to

57
00:02:32.834 --> 00:02:34.673
that particular thought process.

58
00:02:34.673 --> 00:02:38.959
So, if this group of agent-based
endpoints down here was a group of Unix,

59
00:02:38.959 --> 00:02:43.788
Linux servers, this resource pool, or
this pool of resource management servers,

60
00:02:43.788 --> 00:02:45.980
may be dedicated to monitoring them.

61
00:02:45.980 --> 00:02:48.493
And we may have a separate
pool dedicated to Windows.

62
00:02:48.493 --> 00:02:51.743
Separate pool dedicated to
web based infrastructure.

63
00:02:51.743 --> 00:02:55.652
So, just some things to think about
there from an architecture perspective.

64
00:02:55.652 --> 00:02:57.438
We don't wanna be shy, in other words,

65
00:02:57.438 --> 00:02:59.966
about trying to differentiate
what we're monitoring.

66
00:02:59.966 --> 00:03:04.434
And to be able to do so in a way that
allows for high availability, redundancy,

67
00:03:04.434 --> 00:03:07.361
and survivability in the case
of a system failure.

68
00:03:07.361 --> 00:03:12.197
But by dedicating resource pools of
management servers to that infrastructure,

69
00:03:12.197 --> 00:03:15.349
we can then specifically
understand how to manage and

70
00:03:15.349 --> 00:03:18.586
dig through the data in
a little bit more relevant way.

71
00:03:18.586 --> 00:03:21.425
And a little bit easier for us to keep
track of, cuz we have our consoles that

72
00:03:21.425 --> 00:03:24.373
will connect, and we'll have the ability
to be able to do that kind of stuff.

73
00:03:24.373 --> 00:03:26.891
So, just think about that.

74
00:03:26.891 --> 00:03:30.753
If we're coming from an older
implementation we will,

75
00:03:30.753 --> 00:03:34.041
in upcoming episodes and
some upcoming shows,

76
00:03:34.041 --> 00:03:37.658
talk about the migration/upgrade
path from SCOM,

77
00:03:37.658 --> 00:03:42.522
let's say 2007 install,
and/or 2012, or 2012 SP1.

78
00:03:42.522 --> 00:03:47.732
How do we get up to 2012 R2, and how do
we run the most recent infrastructure?

79
00:03:47.732 --> 00:03:50.448
What does that look like,
what's that path look like?

80
00:03:50.448 --> 00:03:53.146
And we'll talk about
the stair step approach

81
00:03:53.146 --> 00:03:57.193
where we have to be installing and
upgrading in a certain order, and

82
00:03:57.193 --> 00:04:01.030
to a certain general platform build and
then moving from there.

83
00:04:01.030 --> 00:04:02.260
So we'll go through all that, but

84
00:04:02.260 --> 00:04:05.760
the idea is that we do have to worry about
backwards compatibility here as well.

85
00:04:05.760 --> 00:04:10.733
If we are running earlier versions of SCOM
and we have management packs from the 2007

86
00:04:10.733 --> 00:04:15.590
install, let's say, the RMS, the Root
Management Server is no longer available.

87
00:04:15.590 --> 00:04:19.060
That would have been the architectural
thought process in 2007,

88
00:04:19.060 --> 00:04:22.938
mentioned in the prior episode that we
moved away from that in favor of this idea

89
00:04:22.938 --> 00:04:26.614
of grouping our management servers
together equally in a resource pool.

90
00:04:26.614 --> 00:04:30.650
And then spreading the load across
them through load balancing.

91
00:04:30.650 --> 00:04:34.330
And so as a result,
we have a thing about how do we work with,

92
00:04:34.330 --> 00:04:38.420
how do we maintain backwards compatibility
to those older systems, if necessary.

93
00:04:38.420 --> 00:04:42.641
We have a roll called the RMS emulator
that's gonna sit on these management

94
00:04:42.641 --> 00:04:44.659
servers, that is available to us.

95
00:04:44.659 --> 00:04:47.423
It's on the first management
server that we install.

96
00:04:47.423 --> 00:04:49.357
We can move it around if necessary, but

97
00:04:49.357 --> 00:04:52.175
it will be on the first new
management server we bring up.

98
00:04:52.175 --> 00:04:54.912
So, our first server will have
this role assigned to it.

99
00:04:54.912 --> 00:04:56.354
>> Very Microsofty.

100
00:04:56.354 --> 00:04:57.136
>> Very Microsofty.

101
00:04:57.136 --> 00:04:58.911
It's much like the FSMO roles,

102
00:04:58.911 --> 00:05:03.850
Flexible Single Operation Master Roles in
the Windows Active Directory architecture.

103
00:05:03.850 --> 00:05:08.765
I always wondered, by the way, right,
just random aside/thought process here.

104
00:05:08.765 --> 00:05:12.934
But the acronym for the Flexible
Single Operation Master Role, FSMO,

105
00:05:12.934 --> 00:05:15.726
F-S-M-O, is what we often hear people say.

106
00:05:15.726 --> 00:05:20.572
Flexible single management operation
is how you would pronounce FSMO.

107
00:05:20.572 --> 00:05:23.391
It should be FSOM,
flexible single operation master.

108
00:05:23.391 --> 00:05:23.893
>> That's true.

109
00:05:23.893 --> 00:05:28.186
>> If you think about it, F-S-O-M, would
actually be the right way to think about

110
00:05:28.186 --> 00:05:31.923
it, cuz the roles are called flexible
single operation master roles,

111
00:05:31.923 --> 00:05:34.360
not flexible single master of operations.

112
00:05:34.360 --> 00:05:37.420
So, it's not actually
FSMO it's actually FSOM.

113
00:05:37.420 --> 00:05:40.442
But every time I bring that up,
everybody laughs at me and says.

114
00:05:40.442 --> 00:05:41.312
>> You know what he's talking about.

115
00:05:41.312 --> 00:05:42.920
>> Go back and
talk about something more important.

116
00:05:42.920 --> 00:05:44.582
>> [LAUGH]
>> They don't wanna hear about that

117
00:05:44.582 --> 00:05:45.090
kind of stuff.

118
00:05:45.090 --> 00:05:49.238
But it's just funny because that's
the traditional way we hear it pronounced,

119
00:05:49.238 --> 00:05:52.047
the way you see it in all
the Microsoft documentation.

120
00:05:52.047 --> 00:05:54.412
They talk about the FSMO Master Rolls,
five rolls.

121
00:05:54.412 --> 00:05:57.005
But they're actually FSOMs.

122
00:05:57.005 --> 00:05:59.071
>> It's a brutal master, that tradition.

123
00:05:59.071 --> 00:06:02.148
People get stuck into them, and
it's hard to get out of it.

124
00:06:02.148 --> 00:06:06.122
>> It is and it's one of those things,
but it's just one of those.

125
00:06:06.122 --> 00:06:06.907
>> [LAUGH]
>> Anyway,

126
00:06:06.907 --> 00:06:08.601
we're gonna actually get back to
what we're here to talk about.

127
00:06:08.601 --> 00:06:09.499
>> It's a splinter in your brain.

128
00:06:09.499 --> 00:06:11.191
>> We're just gonna forget
about that whole thing and

129
00:06:11.191 --> 00:06:12.219
pretend I didn't mention it.

130
00:06:12.219 --> 00:06:14.515
It's totally irrelevant,
as most things are that we talk about.

131
00:06:14.515 --> 00:06:15.731
More often than not.

132
00:06:15.731 --> 00:06:18.769
All right, so anyway, so the idea was,
we go back here for just a second,

133
00:06:18.769 --> 00:06:19.798
just continue talking.

134
00:06:19.798 --> 00:06:22.091
So, the idea is that we
have this emulator role.

135
00:06:22.091 --> 00:06:26.603
It's gonna sit on the first server, and we
can obviously then go ahead and use that.

136
00:06:26.603 --> 00:06:30.026
By the way, if we do upgrade from 2007,

137
00:06:30.026 --> 00:06:34.016
the first server where
the RMS role was installed.

138
00:06:34.016 --> 00:06:36.906
Whatever that was in
the 2007 architecture,

139
00:06:36.906 --> 00:06:41.046
would have this emulator role as
we upgrade through into 2012 R2.

140
00:06:41.046 --> 00:06:44.557
So, it's gonna be in a different place
depending on where you're coming from.

141
00:06:44.557 --> 00:06:48.050
We can move it between different
management servers using Power Shell.

142
00:06:48.050 --> 00:06:53.766
The command for
it is get-scom management server.

143

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Adam start looking at what it takes to get a new SCOM Management Group deployed. They start by exploring the necessary security account types as well as controlling access to the management groups. Then they move into design factors and working with connected management groups.
episodes.title: Deploying a New SCOM Management Group

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Adam move into looking at installation of a Distributed System Center 2012 R2 Operations Manager Management Group. They explain the specific order that installation should proceed in as well as going over the methods for confirming installation. Finally, they explore the Ops Manager's default configuration, manual Agent installation settings, and Automatic Alert resolution.

00:14:03.979 --> 00:14:07.754

00:14:19.798 --> 00:14:20.730

00:25:55.420 --> 00:25:56.300
We don't approve it,

549
00:25:56.300 --> 00:26:01.070
and we have to setup the review new manual
agent install in pending management view

550
00:26:01.070 --> 00:26:05.500
option and enable it, so we could see the
pending installs and then approve them.

551
00:26:05.500 --> 00:26:09.750
Essentially in the console, we have to go
in, and we have to enable this feature.

552
00:26:09.750 --> 00:26:12.600
And once we do that,
the manually installed agents

553
00:26:12.600 --> 00:26:15.330
that are in a pending state
become visible in the console.

554
00:26:15.330 --> 00:26:17.650
We then can go in, and
we can approve them.

555
00:26:17.650 --> 00:26:20.760
And then we can go in and say okay,
yep, approved, highlight it.

556
00:26:20.760 --> 00:26:23.130
And then we can actually
allow this to occur.

557
00:26:23.130 --> 00:26:25.240
If you're familiar with
System Center Config Manager,

558
00:26:25.240 --> 00:26:29.010
SCCM, another product in
the System Center Suite.

559
00:26:29.010 --> 00:26:32.970
We have the ability to do a manual
install there of the monitoring agent,

560
00:26:32.970 --> 00:26:34.570
the SCCM agent.

561
00:26:34.570 --> 00:26:38.710
Again, if we did that, we would have
to approve that manual install and

562
00:26:38.710 --> 00:26:41.240
allow that installation to be allowed.

563
00:26:41.240 --> 00:26:43.342
Or rather, approve that
install to have it be allowed.

564
00:26:43.342 --> 00:26:45.350
And we would do something similar there.

565
00:26:45.350 --> 00:26:49.060
We enable this globally for all the
management servers, usually by default,

566
00:26:49.060 --> 00:26:50.020
that's how we'll do it.

567
00:26:50.020 --> 00:26:53.290
But we can also do it on each individual
management server separately.

568
00:26:53.290 --> 00:26:56.110
So if we wanna enable this feature for
all servers in the pool,

569
00:26:56.110 --> 00:26:57.350
we could do that globally.

570
00:26:57.350 --> 00:27:00.370
We could do it just for one server,
but not do it for others.

571
00:27:00.370 --> 00:27:04.850
It would really be up to us to decide how
we wanna use that or how we want to think

572
00:27:04.850 --> 00:27:09.204
about that task being used ultimately
allow this activity to take place.

573
00:27:09.204 --> 00:27:12.909
We use the approved task to change
the status from pending to approved, so

574
00:27:12.909 --> 00:27:16.753
there's a highlight of the approved,
or rather, ,the pending install.

575
00:27:16.753 --> 00:27:19.764
We'll highlight that, we'll go over on
the right hand side, choose the task,

576
00:27:19.764 --> 00:27:20.265
approve it.

577
00:27:20.265 --> 00:27:22.287
And then we'll just go ahead,
we'll run that, it gets done,

578
00:27:22.287 --> 00:27:24.056
you could actually right click and
approve it as well.

579
00:27:24.056 --> 00:27:26.033
You don't have to use the task,
but it's up to us.

580
00:27:26.033 --> 00:27:30.299
But keep in mind, if we don't approve
the manually installed agents,

581
00:27:30.299 --> 00:27:32.460
no communication takes place.

582
00:27:32.460 --> 00:27:36.490
So the agent down here is pending and will
not be allowed to start communicating and

583
00:27:36.490 --> 00:27:38.130
talk to the management servers and

584
00:27:38.130 --> 00:27:40.940
be managed,
unless we actually approve that install.

585
00:27:40.940 --> 00:27:43.400
So we do wanna make sure
we're aware of that.

586
00:27:43.400 --> 00:27:45.201
We can get some errors occurring here.

587
00:27:45.201 --> 00:27:48.502
You were talking about errors earlier when
we were talking about in the prior episode

588
00:27:48.502 --> 00:27:50.744
what would happen if we didn't
set this up a certain way.

589
00:27:50.744 --> 00:27:54.250
And if we didn't authorize or
do whatever, would we see errors, right?

590
00:27:54.250 --> 00:27:56.557
And the answer is yes, we're doing
the connected management groups,

591
00:27:56.557 --> 00:27:59.221
if we didn't have it configured the right
way, we would get some concerns there.

592
00:27:59.221 --> 00:28:01.929
You'll get an error ID of 21016,

593
00:28:01.929 --> 00:28:07.426
event ID 21016 is the event ID we would
see when we try to use agent-managed

594
00:28:07.426 --> 00:28:12.730
computers that have manually installed
agents that are not approved.

595
00:28:12.730 --> 00:28:14.560
We will get an error to that effect.

596
00:28:14.560 --> 00:28:17.130
It states something like
Ops Manager was unable to set up

597
00:28:17.130 --> 00:28:20.630
a communication channel to, you'll
insert the management server name there,

598
00:28:20.630 --> 00:28:23.330
to daniel1 or
whatever the management server is.

599
00:28:23.330 --> 00:28:24.500
And there are no failover hosts.

600
00:28:24.500 --> 00:28:27.190
That's roughly the language
you will see in the error.

601
00:28:27.190 --> 00:28:30.430
And when that happens,
wanna make sure we see that.

602
00:28:30.430 --> 00:28:32.620
We document that,
we take action accordingly.

603
00:28:32.620 --> 00:28:35.420
We have to go back,
reverse engineer that process, and

604
00:28:35.420 --> 00:28:37.120
approve the manually installed agent.

605
00:28:37.120 --> 00:28:42.160
We'll also get a log entry with
ID 20000 in the event log,

606
00:28:42.160 --> 00:28:43.900
that'll tell us that
that's an issue as well.

607
00:28:43.900 --> 00:28:47.880
So just keep that in mind,
20000 and, or 21016.

608
00:28:47.880 --> 00:28:51.120
Two different event IDs, depending on what
we're trying to do and what we see there.

609
00:28:51.120 --> 00:28:54.450
So, there may be some errors that
we just wanna make sure we counter.

610
00:28:54.450 --> 00:28:56.200
And when we do see them,
we're aware of them.

611
00:28:56.200 --> 00:28:59.750
So just something to think about cuz
you can see that happening as well.

612
00:28:59.750 --> 00:29:03.855
Also, with the automatic alert resolution,
which is an option a lot of people like,

613
00:29:03.855 --> 00:29:07.676
we determined how many days an alert will
set in the new resolution state remains

614
00:29:07.676 --> 00:29:09.972
active before it's automatically resolved.

615
00:29:09.972 --> 00:29:14.911
So if we are gonna use SCOM and say hey,
for 25 or 30 days, want that alert to stay

616
00:29:14.911 --> 00:29:19.790
there, keep showing up as new and then
auto resolve over time, we can set that.

617
00:29:19.790 --> 00:29:22.630
That's, again, a variable,
we can modify that.

618
00:29:22.630 --> 00:29:26.530
We do have to manipulate that setting and
think about that.

619
00:29:26.530 --> 00:29:30.100
What we'll do is use a,
either in the console, set it up or

620
00:29:30.100 --> 00:29:32.230
use a PowerShell solution to do that.

621
00:29:32.230 --> 00:29:37.760
Set SCOM alert resolution setting is
the commandlet that we would use there,

622
00:29:37.760 --> 00:29:40.380
so set-SCOM alert resolution setting.

623
00:29:40.380 --> 00:29:43.850
Alert auto resolve, days is the parameter.

624
00:29:43.850 --> 00:29:46.630
Set the number to 20, 30,
40, whatever you wanna use.

625
00:29:46.630 --> 00:29:50.950
And then healthy alert auto resolve days
as well, you have two options there, so

626
00:29:50.950 --> 00:29:53.600
we can change one or
both of those parameters.

627
00:29:53.600 --> 00:29:56.310
We could figure automatic
alert resolutions by using

628
00:29:56.310 --> 00:30:00.680
the PowerShell commandlets built into the
monitoring console, so think about that.

629
00:30:00.680 --> 00:30:02.000
Again, these are nips and tucks,

630
00:30:02.000 --> 00:30:06.210
tweaks that we would tend to engage in
that will help us to better understand

631
00:30:06.210 --> 00:30:09.680
how to configure the system to
get it working the way we want.

632
00:30:09.680 --> 00:30:13.382
Remember, out of the box, a lot of these
defaults may be either too aggressive or

633
00:30:13.382 --> 00:30:15.137
not aggressive enough for our needs.

634
00:30:15.137 --> 00:30:19.448
We're just using middle of the road
kind of median thought processes here.

635
00:30:19.448 --> 00:30:22.951
What we wanna do is figure out how once
we get it out of the box, get it up and

636
00:30:22.951 --> 00:30:26.468
running, what the best advantage will
be for us in terms of fine tuning.

637
00:30:26.468 --> 00:30:29.776
And this is where a lot of the time is
spent with the SCOM install, nipping and

638
00:30:29.776 --> 00:30:32.510
tucking and
manipulating these individual settings.

639
00:30:32.510 --> 00:30:35.620
We have active alerts that
are in this resolution state

640
00:30:35.620 --> 00:30:37.545
just sitting there that we can modify.

641
00:30:37.545 --> 00:30:42.080
We also wanna make sure that when
an alert source has remained healthy for

642
00:30:42.080 --> 00:30:45.180
a certain numbers of days,
that we then flip that alert as well.

643
00:30:45.180 --> 00:30:47.010
Those are those two
settings I'm talking about.

644
00:30:47.010 --> 00:30:50.680
The remained healthy for a certain
number of days is one setting, and

645
00:30:50.680 --> 00:30:52.890
the initial alert status
itself is another.

646
00:30:52.890 --> 00:30:55.900
And we could flip one or both of those
using the PowerShell commandlet.

647
00:30:55.900 --> 00:30:58.630
So keep that in mind,
alert auto resolve days and,

648
00:30:58.630 --> 00:31:00.950
or healthy alert auto resolve days.

649
00:31:00.950 --> 00:31:03.030
Flip one or
both of those around as needed.

650
00:31:03.030 --> 00:31:05.030
Remember, the default may be too low for

651
00:31:05.030 --> 00:31:07.400
us, we may wanna extend
that out a little bit.

652
00:31:07.400 --> 00:31:11.490
So just maybe something for
us to think about and consider as well.

653
00:31:11.490 --> 00:31:12.956
All right, I think that's a good amount.

654
00:31:12.956 --> 00:31:14.323
>> Good stuff thus far, yeah.

655
00:31:14.323 --> 00:31:16.697
>> Because we wanna jump in and
do the demo, which we'll do coming up.

656
00:31:16.697 --> 00:31:17.257
>> Excellent.

657
00:31:17.257 --> 00:31:20.660
>> That's probably a lot
of stuff at one sitting for

658
00:31:20.660 --> 00:31:25.235
everybody to keep in mind, so
maybe a good stopping point for us.

659
00:31:25.235 --> 00:31:26.678
>> All right, well,
drinking from a firehose,

660
00:31:26.678 --> 00:31:27.867
that's what we do here at ITPRO.TV.

661
00:31:27.867 --> 00:31:31.540
[LAUGH] We'll put it on full blast and
say drink up, me hearties.

662
00:31:31.540 --> 00:31:35.332
That being said, like Adam said, we're
gonna do some demonstration stuff, so

663
00:31:35.332 --> 00:31:38.251
we definitely have more ahead of us,
so tune back in for that.

664
00:31:38.251 --> 00:31:41.630
As for this episode though,
we are gonna go ahead and call it a day.

665
00:31:41.630 --> 00:31:45.050
Thanks for watching, signing off for
ITProTV, I've been your host,

666
00:31:45.050 --> 00:31:46.150
Daniel Lowrie.

667
00:31:46.150 --> 00:31:48.420
>> I am, who am I,
what am I, I don't know.

668
00:31:48.420 --> 00:31:53.327
I am a management server in a resource
pool, but I am not well connected, so

669
00:31:53.327 --> 00:31:55.830
I'm using the gateway
server to talk to you.

670
00:31:55.830 --> 00:31:57.440
Figure that one out.

671
00:31:57.440 --> 00:31:59.384
Otherwise known as Adam.

672
00:31:59.384 --> 00:32:00.490
Talk to you guys later.

673
00:32:01.550 --> 00:32:02.430
>> And we'll see you next time.

674
00:32:02.430 --> 00:32:05.498
>> There we go.
Okay, that's what we were waiting for.

675
00:32:05.498 --> 00:32:11.493
[MUSIC]

00:32:11.493 --> 00:32:14.756
>> Thank you for watching ITProTV.

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Adam continue their demonstration of deploying a SCOM Management Group. Here they introduce you to the common deployment methods for the Agent, using the Console as well as PowerShell, or through manual installation. They also explore the Agent-less Exception Monitoring feature.
episodes.title: Deploying a New SCOM Management Group Part 3
