episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Adam finish their demonstrating their deployment of a new SCOM Management Group. They start by configuring the Audit Collection Service(ACS) which allows the collection of security events from remote systems and then a bit of administration using the AdtAdmin.exe tool and PowerShell.
episodes.title: Deploying a New SCOM Management Group Part 4
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:02.623
Welcome to ITProTV,
I'm your host Don Pezet-

2
00:00:02.623 --> 00:00:06.658
>> [CROSSTALK]

3
00:00:06.658 --> 00:00:08.345
[MUSIC]

4
00:00:08.345 --> 00:00:12.400
>> You're watching ITProTV.

5
00:00:12.400 --> 00:00:13.920
>> All right, greetings everyone and

6
00:00:13.920 --> 00:00:17.120
welcome to another great
episode of ITProTV.

7
00:00:17.120 --> 00:00:20.960
I'm your host Daniel Lowrie, and
in today's episode we are back with more

8
00:00:20.960 --> 00:00:24.900
on our data center monitoring
with Microsoft SCOM series.

9
00:00:24.900 --> 00:00:29.500
And joining us in the studio, yet again,
our good friend and mentor Mr Adam Gordon.

10
00:00:29.500 --> 00:00:31.890
Adam, welcome back, good sir,
glad to have you again.

11
00:00:31.890 --> 00:00:33.309
>> Always a pleasure,
thank you very much, appreciate it.

12
00:00:33.309 --> 00:00:33.949
>> Very formal here.

13
00:00:33.949 --> 00:00:36.230
[LAUGH]
>> And thank you.

14
00:00:36.230 --> 00:00:37.780
All right, so we're gonna continue.

15
00:00:37.780 --> 00:00:40.340
We're gonna round out our discussions here

16
00:00:40.340 --> 00:00:42.960
with regards of some of
the bedrock foundational elements.

17
00:00:42.960 --> 00:00:46.980
Associated with setting up and
configuring various aspects of SCOM.

18
00:00:46.980 --> 00:00:49.981
And some of the supporting
elements we've been through and

19
00:00:49.981 --> 00:00:52.750
done a series of demos as
individual episodes for you.

20
00:00:52.750 --> 00:00:54.069
On configuring all of the products,

21
00:00:54.069 --> 00:00:55.830
encourage you to take
a look at all of those.

22
00:00:55.830 --> 00:00:58.540
Make sure you go back and
have an opportunity to do so, but

23
00:00:58.540 --> 00:01:00.680
there's one little aspect
we haven't hit on yet.

24
00:01:00.680 --> 00:01:02.600
Always of interest, wanna talk about it.

25
00:01:02.600 --> 00:01:04.574
Always important from
a security standpoint,

26
00:01:04.574 --> 00:01:06.310
an operational management standpoint.

27
00:01:06.310 --> 00:01:08.440
To know where our data's going,
what we're doing with it.

28
00:01:08.440 --> 00:01:11.730
And we are talking, of course,
about audit collection services, or ACS.

29
00:01:11.730 --> 00:01:13.020
How are we collecting data?

30
00:01:13.020 --> 00:01:14.480
Where are we gonna centrally put it?

31
00:01:14.480 --> 00:01:15.940
And how are we gonna manage it?

32
00:01:15.940 --> 00:01:18.210
We may choose to leave it in
the databases that we're using,

33
00:01:18.210 --> 00:01:20.530
the operational database, data warehouse.

34
00:01:20.530 --> 00:01:22.610
We may choose to aggregate it separately.

35
00:01:22.610 --> 00:01:25.201
Put it out on the audit
collection database and

36
00:01:25.201 --> 00:01:27.070
use that to then be able to drive.

37
00:01:27.070 --> 00:01:28.800
Athough, we don't have reports by default.

38
00:01:28.800 --> 00:01:29.769
But we can upload them,

39
00:01:29.769 --> 00:01:32.780
reporting through the audit collection
service from various machines.

40
00:01:32.780 --> 00:01:35.090
So thought it'd be good to just talk
about this for a minute with you.

41
00:01:36.110 --> 00:01:39.450
Walk you through the three component
parts associated with ACS.

42
00:01:39.450 --> 00:01:43.550
Show you quickly how the enablement
of the auto collection capability

43
00:01:43.550 --> 00:01:44.540
is gonna be done.

44
00:01:44.540 --> 00:01:47.394
It's a little task we use,
show you what service that attaches to,

45
00:01:47.394 --> 00:01:49.008
how that's all gonna come together.

46
00:01:49.008 --> 00:01:52.968
Talk to you about the ADT admin tool which
is the command line tool we often use to

47
00:01:52.968 --> 00:01:54.370
administer this.

48
00:01:54.370 --> 00:01:56.551
And in general give you
a review of something that,

49
00:01:56.551 --> 00:01:57.880
although we speak a lot about.

50
00:01:57.880 --> 00:02:00.862
It isn't always self evident and
obvious, let's put it that way.

51
00:02:00.862 --> 00:02:02.617
So I thought we'd spend
a few minutes on it.

52
00:02:02.617 --> 00:02:05.249
So, the ACS components,
the three things that make up ACS,

53
00:02:05.249 --> 00:02:07.285
we have what are called the forwarders.

54
00:02:07.285 --> 00:02:09.525
We have the collectors,
we have the database.

55
00:02:09.525 --> 00:02:13.445
The forwarders are gonna be
the agent service that runs under

56
00:02:13.445 --> 00:02:17.095
the Microsoft Monitoring Agent
that's installed on every machine.

57
00:02:17.095 --> 00:02:19.055
There's a sub service associated with it.

58
00:02:19.055 --> 00:02:21.120
We'll take a look at that in a minute.

59
00:02:21.120 --> 00:02:23.490
This is gonna act as a collector for us.

60
00:02:23.490 --> 00:02:25.820
Not the collector,
we just said, is part two.

61
00:02:25.820 --> 00:02:28.449
But rather, the forwarder
simply aggregates the data for

62
00:02:28.449 --> 00:02:29.850
us on the individual machine.

63
00:02:29.850 --> 00:02:33.097
And that allows us to send that
out to a centralized collector,

64
00:02:33.097 --> 00:02:37.100
which will gather the data from all
the different machines being monitored.

65
00:02:37.100 --> 00:02:39.620
And then send that out and
centralize that in the database.

66
00:02:39.620 --> 00:02:42.530
So we have the forwarders,
we'll take a look at how to enable that.

67
00:02:42.530 --> 00:02:43.730
We have the collectors.

68
00:02:43.730 --> 00:02:48.130
This is the information, the event data
that comes in from the ACS folders.

69
00:02:48.130 --> 00:02:52.060
We process it at the collector and
store the data in the ACS database.

70
00:02:52.060 --> 00:02:55.520
And the database itself is then
what we're gonna also focus on.

71
00:02:55.520 --> 00:02:57.820
Got a little bit of a minimum
requirement hardware,

72
00:02:57.820 --> 00:03:00.450
software kinda thing going
on with the database.

73
00:03:00.450 --> 00:03:01.340
I'll show you a web page.

74
00:03:01.340 --> 00:03:02.630
You can read up on that.

75
00:03:02.630 --> 00:03:06.001
But the important thing to think
about is the fact that we specify and

76
00:03:06.001 --> 00:03:08.141
really do give you some guidance on using.

77
00:03:08.141 --> 00:03:11.886
Or the difference between using standard
versus enterprise on the SQL side for

78
00:03:11.886 --> 00:03:14.180
this database in particular.

79
00:03:14.180 --> 00:03:17.370
Recommendation is to use
Enterprise as opposed to standard,

80
00:03:17.370 --> 00:03:19.080
and there's an interesting reason why.

81
00:03:19.080 --> 00:03:22.340
I'm not gonna put Daniel on
the spot ask him if he knows why,

82
00:03:22.340 --> 00:03:23.790
because I haven't told him why.

83
00:03:23.790 --> 00:03:26.060
And he would then be honest and tell
you I don't know, cuz he doesn't know.

84
00:03:26.060 --> 00:03:30.010
Cuz he doesn't configure this particular
part of SCOM and work with it.

85
00:03:30.010 --> 00:03:32.080
And you may not know either,
and this is pretty common.

86
00:03:32.080 --> 00:03:35.320
A lot of people are not aware of
the reason why we have to do this.

87
00:03:35.320 --> 00:03:36.370
But it's interesting.

88
00:03:36.370 --> 00:03:40.670
When we run the actual daily
maintenance cycles on the database.

89
00:03:40.670 --> 00:03:45.570
If we use standard, we pause the ACS
database in order to do maintenance on it.

90
00:03:45.570 --> 00:03:48.130
And there's a backlog of
information that gets

91
00:03:48.130 --> 00:03:51.960
essentially just backed up at
the collector that cannot be processed.

92
00:03:51.960 --> 00:03:56.390
If we use the enterprise size database or
deploy on the enterprise product.

93
00:03:56.390 --> 00:03:59.081
We don't pause the database
while we're the maintenance or

94
00:03:59.081 --> 00:04:00.630
the daily maintenance cycle.

95
00:04:00.630 --> 00:04:04.480
The database is running and as a result
we can continue information streaming in.

96
00:04:04.480 --> 00:04:08.310
And so it is a performance issue and
there is a specific do,

97
00:04:08.310 --> 00:04:11.100
don't do kind of guidance
that you wanna follow here.

98
00:04:11.100 --> 00:04:13.490
Not saying that if you use
the standard database,

99
00:04:13.490 --> 00:04:15.560
you're gonna necessarily
have bad performance.

100
00:04:15.560 --> 00:04:19.127
But just pointing out that there is
gonna be a backup in the queue and

101
00:04:19.127 --> 00:04:20.410
a delay in processing.

102
00:04:20.410 --> 00:04:22.680
As a result of that daily
maintenance cycle that runs.

103
00:04:22.680 --> 00:04:25.260
That is something you just
wanna think about and consider.

104
00:04:25.260 --> 00:04:27.310
Speak a little bit about that in
the show notes to make sure you're

105
00:04:27.310 --> 00:04:28.300
familiar with that.

106
00:04:28.300 --> 00:04:29.140
Just be aware of that.

107
00:04:29.140 --> 00:04:30.796
Also encrypted by default,

108
00:04:30.796 --> 00:04:35.020
the communication between the ACS
forwarder and the ACS collector.

109
00:04:35.020 --> 00:04:36.910
So we're focusing on security there.

110
00:04:36.910 --> 00:04:39.012
Ensuring that that data is
not gonna be compromised or

111
00:04:39.012 --> 00:04:41.310
made available to anybody
that's not supposed to see it.

112
00:04:41.310 --> 00:04:42.380
So that's important.

113
00:04:42.380 --> 00:04:43.980
But they both have to be on the same or

114
00:04:43.980 --> 00:04:46.180
trusted domain in order
to have that happen.

115
00:04:46.180 --> 00:04:49.320
If it is not the case,
then they will not be encrypted.

116
00:04:49.320 --> 00:04:52.099
And normal default
communication in unencrypted or

117
00:04:52.099 --> 00:04:54.810
rather untrusted
environments is unencrypted.

118
00:04:54.810 --> 00:04:56.540
So just keep that in mind.

119
00:04:56.540 --> 00:05:00.560
We can decide to encrypt, but we have to
be in same domain in order to do that.

120
00:05:00.560 --> 00:05:02.160
So just be aware of that.

121
00:05:02.160 --> 00:05:04.770
Let's take a look at a couple of
supporting elements associated with this

122
00:05:04.770 --> 00:05:06.280
and we'll wrap up our conversation.

123
00:05:06.280 --> 00:05:08.220
I said this is actually
a really quick topic.

124
00:05:08.220 --> 00:05:08.970
I meant that.

125
00:05:08.970 --> 00:05:10.930
Very rare that I say that and
I do mean it.

126
00:05:10.930 --> 00:05:13.078
I normally say that and
we go 30, 40 minutes.

127
00:05:13.078 --> 00:05:15.720
But we're gonna get you in and
out in about two and a half.

128
00:05:15.720 --> 00:05:17.620
And Daniel's gonna keep
me honest on this one.

129
00:05:17.620 --> 00:05:20.150
So let's take a look real quick
look at the machine here.

130
00:05:20.150 --> 00:05:22.865
Before I show you how to enable
the auto collection feature.

131
00:05:22.865 --> 00:05:25.593
Let's just take a look at a couple of
the elements here that are gonna be

132
00:05:25.593 --> 00:05:26.600
important for us.

133
00:05:26.600 --> 00:05:31.069
First thing we're gonna do is just quickly
look at the service that is targeted for

134
00:05:31.069 --> 00:05:33.030
that enable auto collection task.

135
00:05:33.030 --> 00:05:36.388
That turns on the audit collection
on an individual machine,

136
00:05:36.388 --> 00:05:38.590
allows us to aggregate that data.

137
00:05:38.590 --> 00:05:42.450
I mentioned that it was part
of one of the services.

138
00:05:42.450 --> 00:05:45.047
Or it's a subset of the services
that are installed as

139
00:05:45.047 --> 00:05:46.730
the Microsoft Monitoring Agent.

140
00:05:46.730 --> 00:05:49.130
The monitoring software that's
installed on every machine.

141
00:05:49.130 --> 00:05:52.280
So I'm on one of the servers that
we've installed the agent on.

142
00:05:52.280 --> 00:05:54.010
And I'm looking underneath the services.

143
00:05:54.010 --> 00:05:55.140
Now, you've gotta know where to look.

144
00:05:55.140 --> 00:05:57.480
Remember that the agent has been renamed.

145
00:05:57.480 --> 00:06:00.850
It's now called the Microsoft
Monitoring Agent, and the services,

146
00:06:00.850 --> 00:06:02.660
the Audit Forwarding Service.

147
00:06:02.660 --> 00:06:05.650
So it's up under Microsoft
Monitoring Agent Audit Forwarding,

148
00:06:05.650 --> 00:06:07.490
you can see it there, I've highlighted it.

149
00:06:07.490 --> 00:06:11.680
And notice that it is disabled by default,
and so it is not running.

150
00:06:11.680 --> 00:06:14.980
And in order for this to be configured
properly and turned on, and

151
00:06:14.980 --> 00:06:16.780
configured to run automatically.

152
00:06:16.780 --> 00:06:20.150
We're gonna go, execute a task
In the office manager console.

153
00:06:20.150 --> 00:06:23.323
That will configure all the agents
we highlight to have this turned on

154
00:06:23.323 --> 00:06:24.040
the right way.

155
00:06:24.040 --> 00:06:26.610
I'm gonna show you how to
do that in just a moment.

156
00:06:26.610 --> 00:06:30.200
But this is the service that we're
gonna target with that task.

157
00:06:30.200 --> 00:06:32.040
That task is sitting right here.

158
00:06:32.040 --> 00:06:33.480
Could we go full screen for
a minute just so

159
00:06:33.480 --> 00:06:35.090
we can see this in a little more detail?

160
00:06:35.090 --> 00:06:37.190
Cuz I wanna show you where this task is.

161
00:06:37.190 --> 00:06:40.540
It's not self-evident, and it's not
the most obvious thing in the world.

162
00:06:40.540 --> 00:06:42.660
And you gotta drill through
the management packs.

163
00:06:42.660 --> 00:06:46.970
And the monitoring specifically
work space with the management pack

164
00:06:46.970 --> 00:06:49.140
information that's loaded to find that.

165
00:06:49.140 --> 00:06:50.130
How am I doing on time by the way?

166
00:06:50.130 --> 00:06:51.260
>> You're good.

167
00:06:51.260 --> 00:06:53.525
>> That's not what I was hoping to hear,
I was hoping to hear a minute left or

168
00:06:53.525 --> 00:06:54.541
something, Mr. Timekeeper.

169
00:06:54.541 --> 00:06:55.436
>> 13 seconds.

170
00:06:55.436 --> 00:06:57.019
>> You're good, you're good, that's all.

171
00:06:57.019 --> 00:06:58.420
This is why I'm not gonna run over.

172
00:06:58.420 --> 00:06:59.040
>> I'll warn you.

173
00:06:59.040 --> 00:07:01.729
>> I'm gonna run over, I know I'm gonna
run over it's gonna be like five minutes

174
00:07:01.729 --> 00:07:02.686
you're not gonna tell me.

175
00:07:02.686 --> 00:07:05.660
>> All right, so let's take a look real
quick at where we are, five seconds.

176
00:07:05.660 --> 00:07:06.650
>> Thank you very much.

177
00:07:06.650 --> 00:07:07.760
I appreciate that, sir.

178
00:07:07.760 --> 00:07:09.610
So we're in the monitoring workspace.

179
00:07:09.610 --> 00:07:11.950
And what we'll see as we scroll down,

180
00:07:11.950 --> 00:07:14.900
we have to open up
the operations manager folder.

181
00:07:14.900 --> 00:07:17.310
Underneath that we have
to go into Agent Details.

182
00:07:17.310 --> 00:07:19.550
Underneath that, Agent Health Status.

183
00:07:19.550 --> 00:07:22.080
We're drilling into this
particular dashboard.

184
00:07:22.080 --> 00:07:24.500
Here we have a two-pane dashboard and

185
00:07:24.500 --> 00:07:28.040
we could see we have the agent's status
from health service that we're monitoring.

186
00:07:28.040 --> 00:07:30.090
And then the Agent State itself.

187
00:07:30.090 --> 00:07:33.340
We're gonna go to the right pane and
choose Agent State.

188
00:07:33.340 --> 00:07:34.948
I've highlighted both agents.

189
00:07:34.948 --> 00:07:37.670
PLABVMMBUILD and the DC1.

190
00:07:37.670 --> 00:07:42.710
When I do that, I get the appropriate
Health Service Tasks over here.

191
00:07:42.710 --> 00:07:46.710
And one of them, I'll put at the very top
just about, is enable audit collection.

192
00:07:46.710 --> 00:07:48.834
And then when I do this,
this will go out and

193
00:07:48.834 --> 00:07:51.730
configure that service we just
looked at on that machine.

194
00:07:51.730 --> 00:07:53.930
And set it up so
that it runs the right way.

195
00:07:53.930 --> 00:07:57.900
And then once I've done that down here.

196
00:07:57.900 --> 00:08:00.270
And I can't really scroll down cuz
that's the bottom of the screen.

197
00:08:00.270 --> 00:08:03.480
But I can then run
the Start Audit Collection task.

198
00:08:03.480 --> 00:08:05.907
That will then actually
enable the collection,

199
00:08:05.907 --> 00:08:08.440
allow the forwarder to
start gathering data.

200
00:08:08.440 --> 00:08:12.080
Send it to the collector,
allow the collector to process it, and

201
00:08:12.080 --> 00:08:14.260
ultimately send it into the database.

202
00:08:14.260 --> 00:08:17.050
So this is what we're talking
about when we set this up.

203
00:08:17.050 --> 00:08:21.170
Now, the way we administer
this on a command line level,

204
00:08:21.170 --> 00:08:25.770
on an individual machine level
is using the adt admin.exe tool.

205
00:08:25.770 --> 00:08:28.260
Thought I'd quickly show you about that.

206
00:08:28.260 --> 00:08:31.820
Let me just go in here real quick and
show you one thing before we do that.

207
00:08:31.820 --> 00:08:35.940
If you need to know where to go to enable
the Audit Collection Services Forwarders,

208
00:08:35.940 --> 00:08:37.180
which is what I just showed you how to do.

209
00:08:37.180 --> 00:08:39.770
Got a little webpage here
to help you to do that.

210
00:08:39.770 --> 00:08:40.584
At the bottom,

211
00:08:40.584 --> 00:08:44.545
it's got links to all the other elements
associated with how to set up ACS.

212
00:08:44.545 --> 00:08:47.807
Including which I often get asked about,
how to set it up for UNIX and

213
00:08:47.807 --> 00:08:50.795
Linux gathering, and
filtering events from UNIX and Linux.

214
00:08:50.795 --> 00:08:54.155
So you have very detailed and
very good information there.

215
00:08:54.155 --> 00:08:57.465
We have a link to the Audit
Collection Services ADT admin page.

216
00:08:57.465 --> 00:08:59.855
We just click here,
we can grab that real quick.

217
00:09:01.150 --> 00:09:05.730
This will allow us to understand
how to use the ADT admin tool.

218
00:09:05.730 --> 00:09:09.350
Gives us information on all
of the syntax and switches.

219
00:09:09.350 --> 00:09:13.320
Shows us how to set this up, and ensure
that we understand how to administer,

220
00:09:13.320 --> 00:09:15.220
along with all the sub parameters here.

221
00:09:15.220 --> 00:09:18.980
Has links back to all the other
information we were taking a look at.

222
00:09:18.980 --> 00:09:21.170
The other thing that I thought
would just be helpful quickly.

223
00:09:21.170 --> 00:09:23.670
We haven't really looked
under the hood at SQL at all.

224
00:09:23.670 --> 00:09:26.330
But just to show you what
SQL databases look like.

225
00:09:26.330 --> 00:09:29.460
And you could see we haven't set
up an ACS collector database.

226
00:09:29.460 --> 00:09:34.090
But you could see that we do have the
other databases here from our installs.

227
00:09:34.090 --> 00:09:36.740
We do have our app controller database.

228
00:09:36.740 --> 00:09:41.070
We have our ops manager, ops manager
data warehouse database orchestrator,

229
00:09:41.070 --> 00:09:43.900
our report server,
our Virtual Machine manager.

230
00:09:43.900 --> 00:09:46.400
All the different databases from
all the installs we've done.

231
00:09:46.400 --> 00:09:49.425
And all of our different episodes where
we did all of our installs are all

232
00:09:49.425 --> 00:09:50.140
sitting there.

233
00:09:50.140 --> 00:09:53.940
We can interact with them, of course, and
work with any of the ones we may need.

234
00:09:53.940 --> 00:09:54.810
Run queries against them.

235
00:09:54.810 --> 00:09:55.700
Do whatever we need.

236
00:09:55.700 --> 00:09:57.220
This is SQL 12, by the way.

237
00:09:57.220 --> 00:09:59.270
We're just in the Admin Studio,
taking a look.

238
00:09:59.270 --> 00:10:01.420
And that's what it will look like
under the hood if we had to go in and

239
00:10:01.420 --> 00:10:03.090
actually play around with one or
more of them.

240
00:10:03.090 --> 00:10:07.382
So just a little insight to ACS,
there are no reports loaded, by the way,

241
00:10:07.382 --> 00:10:08.570
by default for ACS.

242
00:10:08.570 --> 00:10:12.200
If we wanna actually run ACS reports,
we have to upload them and

243
00:10:12.200 --> 00:10:13.510
make them available.

244
00:10:13.510 --> 00:10:16.305
We have to import them into
SQL Reporting Services,

245
00:10:16.305 --> 00:10:18.410
so report them into reporting server.

246
00:10:18.410 --> 00:10:22.140
Or import them, I should say,
into reporting server.

247
00:10:22.140 --> 00:10:23.236
If we go back to my machine for

248
00:10:23.236 --> 00:10:26.230
just a minute to show you the picture
we've been referencing here and there.

249
00:10:26.230 --> 00:10:30.292
We would have to import the reports
into the SSRS area here,

250
00:10:30.292 --> 00:10:33.030
load them up, make them available.

251
00:10:33.030 --> 00:10:34.670
We do that from a command prompt.

252
00:10:34.670 --> 00:10:37.130
We can then run a command
order to import them.

253
00:10:37.130 --> 00:10:41.360
And then once we've done that,
using the upload audit reports command.

254
00:10:41.360 --> 00:10:44.400
We would then be able to go in and
access them and make them available.

255
00:10:44.400 --> 00:10:45.740
Then we will be able to see them.

256
00:10:45.740 --> 00:10:47.010
But they're not loaded by default.

257
00:10:47.010 --> 00:10:50.750
We'd have to actually import them and make
them available as a separate step as well.

258
00:10:50.750 --> 00:10:54.300
Again, refer you back to some of
the steps that I called that quickly and

259
00:10:54.300 --> 00:10:57.950
showed on the web pages associated
with configuration of ACS.

260
00:10:57.950 --> 00:11:00.510
Walks you through all the details
including how to set up and

261
00:11:00.510 --> 00:11:01.860
import those reports.

262
00:11:01.860 --> 00:11:05.140
So it gives you just a full featured view
of everything we're gonna do with ACS.

263
00:11:05.140 --> 00:11:09.160
>> Wow, I'm flabbergasted you actually
did get us in under 30 minutes.

264
00:11:09.160 --> 00:11:10.960
I don't know what to say.

265
00:11:10.960 --> 00:11:12.890
Thanks for watching everyone.

266
00:11:12.890 --> 00:11:13.830
No, we do thank you Adam.

267
00:11:13.830 --> 00:11:16.620
We are having a little fun
here at Adam's expense.

268
00:11:16.620 --> 00:11:22.910
We've gone from beginning to end,
to creating this whole system.

269
00:11:22.910 --> 00:11:25.352
It's been a long, arduous journey.

270
00:11:25.352 --> 00:11:27.620
There are a lot of moving parts involved,
a lot of bits and

271
00:11:27.620 --> 00:11:30.550
pieces that you have to kinda
get your mind wrapped around.

272
00:11:30.550 --> 00:11:32.718
Understand how to use per se,

273
00:11:32.718 --> 00:11:37.070
that's why we have multiple
parts to this part of the show.

274
00:11:37.070 --> 00:11:40.331
But once you get this
from beginning to end,

275
00:11:40.331 --> 00:11:46.730
you'll definitely be able to create and
deploy an new SCOM management group.

276
00:11:46.730 --> 00:11:49.630
At least we hope,
that was our goal anyway.

277
00:11:49.630 --> 00:11:50.880
So if you don't understand something,

278
00:11:50.880 --> 00:11:54.000
make sure you rewatch over and over
again until you understand what it is.

279
00:11:54.000 --> 00:11:56.210
Obviously you can hit us up
in our forums for anything.

280
00:11:56.210 --> 00:11:58.620
If you have any questions,
we can get those to Adam, or

281
00:11:58.620 --> 00:12:00.560
if we can answer them ourselves,
we'll definitely do that.

282
00:12:00.560 --> 00:12:02.960
>> Absolutely.
>> But Adam, we totally appreciate this.

283
00:12:02.960 --> 00:12:07.110
This is something that's very complex and
you have the knowledge.

284
00:12:07.110 --> 00:12:10.810
We were the learners,
we came to the fountain to drink today.

285
00:12:10.810 --> 00:12:14.150
And we appreciate that
quenching of the thirst.

286
00:12:14.150 --> 00:12:16.000
That being said,
looks like it is time for us.

287
00:12:16.000 --> 00:12:18.912
It's weird to cut an episode so short,
but that's what we're gonna do today,

288
00:12:18.912 --> 00:12:20.011
it's time for us to sign off.

289
00:12:20.011 --> 00:12:22.564
>> Cheers.
>> Cheers, yes, yes, call it a day.

290
00:12:22.564 --> 00:12:23.751
>> Awesome, drink to knowledge,
outstanding.

291
00:12:23.751 --> 00:12:26.864
>> To you good people, thanks for
watching, signing off for ITProTV,

292
00:12:26.864 --> 00:12:28.643
I've been your host, Daniel Lowrie.

293
00:12:28.643 --> 00:12:30.793
>> I'm Adam Gordon,
come back and join us soon.

294
00:12:30.793 --> 00:12:32.168
>> That's right, and
we'll see you next time.

295
00:12:32.168 --> 00:12:32.980
>> Another episode.
>> Bye.

296
00:12:32.980 --> 00:12:34.495
>> Take care, everybody.

297
00:12:34.495 --> 00:12:41.230
[MUSIC]

298
00:12:41.230 --> 00:12:44.822
Thank you for watching ITProTV.

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Adam demonstrate how to install the Virtual Machine Management Server. They start by looking at the prerequisites that are necessary for the installation. Then they take you step-by-step through the installation, explaining each of the options in detail.
episodes.title: Install Virtual Machine Management Server
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.008 --> 00:00:02.824
Welcome to ITProTV,
I'm your host Don Pezet-

2
00:00:02.824 --> 00:00:06.807
>> [CROSSTALK].

3
00:00:06.807 --> 00:00:08.051
[MUSIC]

4
00:00:08.051 --> 00:00:12.555
>> You're watching ITProTV.

5
00:00:12.555 --> 00:00:14.456
>> All right, greetings everyone and

6
00:00:14.456 --> 00:00:17.150
welcome to another exciting
episode of ITProTV.

7
00:00:17.150 --> 00:00:19.190
I'm your host Daniel Lowrie,
and in today's episode,

8
00:00:19.190 --> 00:00:24.320
we are back with more of our data center
monitoring with Microsoft SCOM series.

9
00:00:24.320 --> 00:00:28.300
And joining me back in the studio again
today is our good friend Mr. Adam Gordon.

10
00:00:28.300 --> 00:00:29.320
Adam, glad to have you back, sir.

11
00:00:29.320 --> 00:00:29.910
How's it going?

12
00:00:29.910 --> 00:00:31.010
>> It is going well.

13
00:00:31.010 --> 00:00:32.898
I am feeling like installing something.

14
00:00:32.898 --> 00:00:34.418
We've been talking about doing.

15
00:00:34.418 --> 00:00:37.442
I'm actually feeling a hankering
as they say in the deep south,

16
00:00:37.442 --> 00:00:40.590
I have a hankering to install something,
what should we install?

17
00:00:40.590 --> 00:00:41.617
>> Yeah.

18
00:00:41.617 --> 00:00:44.450
>> We gave it away because we already
set up on the third, but if you didn't

19
00:00:44.450 --> 00:00:47.350
see that or you're just tuning in,
what do you think we should install?

20
00:00:47.350 --> 00:00:51.582
>> I'm having a hankering for
some Virtual Machine Manager.

21
00:00:51.582 --> 00:00:52.244
How's that?

22
00:00:52.244 --> 00:00:57.845
>> SCVMM, a little SCVMM, so we're gonna
do exactly that for you in this episode.

23
00:00:57.845 --> 00:01:01.220
We are going to, we threw all the names
of the Microsoft products in the hat.

24
00:01:01.220 --> 00:01:05.110
Daniel got to pick and he chose system
center Virtual Machine Manager, so

25
00:01:05.110 --> 00:01:07.560
we are gonna deploy SCVMM for you.

26
00:01:07.560 --> 00:01:10.860
Show you how that's done
start to finish as they say.

27
00:01:10.860 --> 00:01:14.970
If we can make with the magic,
let me see if I can get this right,

28
00:01:14.970 --> 00:01:16.820
I gotta go this way and up, so I gotta.

29
00:01:16.820 --> 00:01:17.448
>> To your right.

30
00:01:17.448 --> 00:01:20.528
>> We are going to, awesome!

31
00:01:20.528 --> 00:01:21.428
>> There you go.

32
00:01:21.428 --> 00:01:25.337
>> You are the best, we are gonna
actually begin our demonstration by just

33
00:01:25.337 --> 00:01:28.680
talking about some of
the background pre-reqs real quick.

34
00:01:28.680 --> 00:01:31.640
Yeah, we do some of the background work
just to make things run a little quicker.

35
00:01:31.640 --> 00:01:34.570
We've created,
I've created two install accounts.

36
00:01:34.570 --> 00:01:36.830
I'm gonna show you what those are and
how I did those real quick.

37
00:01:36.830 --> 00:01:40.340
But speaking of background work, you gotta
do and pre-reqs to make this run well.

38
00:01:40.340 --> 00:01:43.530
There is some software that
we have to have installed

39
00:01:43.530 --> 00:01:47.270
on the target box where we're
gonna install the VMM product.

40
00:01:47.270 --> 00:01:48.926
Let's just run through that for
you quickly.

41
00:01:48.926 --> 00:01:52.760
You should be running at least
Windows Server 12 or better, 12,

42
00:01:52.760 --> 00:01:55.390
12 R2 Server 16 as the underlying OS.

43
00:01:55.390 --> 00:01:58.660
You gotta have SQLServer 12 SP1 or
better there.

44
00:01:58.660 --> 00:02:04.144
So SQL12 SP1, SQL 14, SQL 16, etc.

45
00:02:04.144 --> 00:02:09.820
Gotta have Microsoft .NET framework
version 4.5, so you gotta be running that.

46
00:02:09.820 --> 00:02:11.390
And you need the Windows Assessment and

47
00:02:11.390 --> 00:02:16.030
Deployment kit, the WADK,
version either for Windows 8.

48
00:02:16.030 --> 00:02:20.510
Excuse me, or version for Windows 8.1 or
the newer newer version for Windows 10.

49
00:02:20.510 --> 00:02:21.360
So you need that.

50
00:02:21.360 --> 00:02:25.260
We're gonna fast forward and actually show
you how to install that as part of what

51
00:02:25.260 --> 00:02:29.640
we're doing here after we get the service
accounts explained to you really quickly.

52
00:02:29.640 --> 00:02:33.410
So what I've done to install
the service accounts is the following.

53
00:02:33.410 --> 00:02:35.270
I've gone in and

54
00:02:35.270 --> 00:02:39.200
I have copied and you can do this
in the real world if you choose to.

55
00:02:39.200 --> 00:02:41.830
I have copied the admin account.

56
00:02:41.830 --> 00:02:44.530
So I went into the domain controller,
opened up our domain.

57
00:02:44.530 --> 00:02:47.080
You'll see practicelabs.com right here.

58
00:02:47.080 --> 00:02:49.420
Went ahead, just went to the users OU.

59
00:02:49.420 --> 00:02:53.250
Went ahead and grabbed the admin account,
right-click copy.

60
00:02:53.250 --> 00:02:54.240
Chose the admin account.

61
00:02:54.240 --> 00:02:57.480
In other words, as a template,
has all the rights necessary for

62
00:02:57.480 --> 00:02:59.560
us to use to do the install.

63
00:02:59.560 --> 00:03:02.710
But created a separate instantiated

64
00:03:02.710 --> 00:03:06.130
version of that account that is
separate with its own password.

65
00:03:06.130 --> 00:03:09.810
That way, if we change the domain admin
password, we're not modifying the service

66
00:03:09.810 --> 00:03:12.720
account but we have all the properties
necessary to do the install.

67
00:03:12.720 --> 00:03:15.230
This is what I spoke about
in the earlier episodes

68
00:03:15.230 --> 00:03:17.870
when I talked about
planning to be successful.

69
00:03:17.870 --> 00:03:21.930
Setting up the answers to the questions
who, what, where, why, and how.

70
00:03:21.930 --> 00:03:25.620
Who is gonna be doing the install,
what credentials do they have?

71
00:03:25.620 --> 00:03:28.150
But also what are those
service accounts we need and

72
00:03:28.150 --> 00:03:30.970
how are we gonna map those out,
what rights do they need?

73
00:03:30.970 --> 00:03:34.960
And so we've done that, we've created
an account called VMM service account.

74
00:03:34.960 --> 00:03:36.720
Pretty obvious hopefully
what that one does.

75
00:03:36.720 --> 00:03:40.210
That's gonna be our Virtual Machine
Manager service account for our install.

76
00:03:40.210 --> 00:03:43.540
In an upcoming demo, we're gonna be
doing an install and configuring and

77
00:03:43.540 --> 00:03:45.420
discussing the app controller.

78
00:03:45.420 --> 00:03:48.850
Got a service account set up for that,
just so that we have that ready to go.

79
00:03:48.850 --> 00:03:50.030
So we have all of that there,

80
00:03:50.030 --> 00:03:52.730
so what we're gonna do is flip
over from our domain controller.

81
00:03:54.170 --> 00:03:59.490
Over to our box where our Virtual Machine
Manager install is gonna take place.

82
00:03:59.490 --> 00:04:03.220
I've already gone ahead and
just spun up the Windows Assessment and

83
00:04:03.220 --> 00:04:05.340
Deployment kit for Windows 8.1.

84
00:04:05.340 --> 00:04:08.940
Loaded the software initially,
got the initial screen there, so

85
00:04:08.940 --> 00:04:09.810
you could see that running.

86
00:04:09.810 --> 00:04:12.830
Let me just move this over
just a wee bit over here, so

87
00:04:12.830 --> 00:04:14.860
you can see the full screen on that.

88
00:04:14.860 --> 00:04:19.770
And what you'll see is that we
specify a location for the install.

89
00:04:19.770 --> 00:04:24.684
We'll just take the default install
C:\\Program Files\x86\WindowsKits,

90
00:04:24.684 --> 00:04:27.270
and then 8.1 and then the directory.

91
00:04:27.270 --> 00:04:28.550
So we're gonna go ahead and do that.

92
00:04:28.550 --> 00:04:31.710
Need about 6 GB of space approximately
to get that up and running.

93
00:04:31.710 --> 00:04:32.870
We'll hit Next there.

94
00:04:32.870 --> 00:04:34.190
We're gonna decide whether or

95
00:04:34.190 --> 00:04:37.010
not we wanna join the customer
experience improvement program.

96
00:04:37.010 --> 00:04:39.570
Obviously, in the real world,
you may choose to opt into that.

97
00:04:39.570 --> 00:04:43.000
For our purposes of demonstration,
we'll say no, which is the default.

98
00:04:43.000 --> 00:04:44.220
We'll hit Next there.

99
00:04:44.220 --> 00:04:46.990
Then we're gonna accept the end
user license agreement.

100
00:04:46.990 --> 00:04:48.110
So we'll hit Accept.

101
00:04:48.110 --> 00:04:49.690
>> You made sure to read that, right?

102
00:04:49.690 --> 00:04:50.555
>> [LAUGH]
>> I speed read.

103
00:04:50.555 --> 00:04:53.776
>> Yeah. [LAUGH] >> I was able to scan
that entire thing like that without even

104
00:04:53.776 --> 00:04:55.796
having to move, that's how quick I am.

105
00:04:55.796 --> 00:04:57.024
>> You got the whole thing
memorized [CROSSTALK].

106
00:04:57.024 --> 00:04:57.696
>> I do actually.

107
00:04:57.696 --> 00:04:58.998
>> [LAUGH]
>> Just I know it all, so

108
00:04:58.998 --> 00:04:59.815
I don't even have to worry about it.

109
00:04:59.815 --> 00:05:04.682
So, on the select your features you wanna
install screen here as you can see,

110
00:05:04.682 --> 00:05:09.322
we're gonna take off the SQL Server
2012 Express item at the bottom.

111
00:05:09.322 --> 00:05:12.982
That's also gonna deselect
the Windows Assessment Services,

112
00:05:12.982 --> 00:05:15.512
we don't need those for
the purposes of our demonstration.

113
00:05:15.512 --> 00:05:19.412
We're running a SQL Server system already,
so we've got that up and running,

114
00:05:19.412 --> 00:05:22.502
we're not gonna do the express,
which is the all in one install.

115
00:05:22.502 --> 00:05:25.422
We're gonna be able to use that
separately if necessary, so

116
00:05:25.422 --> 00:05:27.590
we're gonna just go ahead and
let that run.

117
00:05:27.590 --> 00:05:29.570
So we're gonna do install here,

118
00:05:29.570 --> 00:05:34.080
that drops the estimated down to
about 3.2 gigs of estimated space.

119
00:05:34.080 --> 00:05:37.270
We're gonna let that run for
just a minute using our time wisely,

120
00:05:37.270 --> 00:05:41.339
we're gonna come back and we're gonna take
a look at that as soon as it finishes up.

121
00:05:41.339 --> 00:05:43.179
Then we're gonna pick up
the install right from here.

122
00:05:44.540 --> 00:05:47.600
All right, so now that we've finished
the install of the Windows Assessment and

123
00:05:47.600 --> 00:05:48.450
Deployment Kit.

124
00:05:48.450 --> 00:05:49.945
We're gonna go ahead,
we'll just close that,

125
00:05:49.945 --> 00:05:51.443
we're not gonna bother
launching it right now.

126
00:05:51.443 --> 00:05:53.416
Just wanna make sure it's
installed ready to go.

127
00:05:53.416 --> 00:05:58.155
What we're gonna do next is open up our
File Explorer and what I've done is I've

128
00:05:58.155 --> 00:06:01.990
actually just gone ahead and
loaded up the SCVMM install media.

129
00:06:01.990 --> 00:06:05.110
So you would download the iso,
burn it, have it available.

130
00:06:05.110 --> 00:06:08.090
So you open that up,
we're gonna right-click on the setup.

131
00:06:08.090 --> 00:06:11.140
Just make sure we run as administrator,
wanna make sure we get that installed

132
00:06:11.140 --> 00:06:13.980
the right way the first time
without having any issues.

133
00:06:13.980 --> 00:06:18.360
You'll see there SCVMM 2012 R2,
Virtual Machine Manager.

134
00:06:18.360 --> 00:06:21.810
We've got the Install option,
we're gonna click that, get that going.

135
00:06:21.810 --> 00:06:23.820
So let's just go ahead and
get that up and running.

136
00:06:23.820 --> 00:06:26.080
We're gonna go ahead and select
the features we're gonna wanna install.

137
00:06:26.080 --> 00:06:28.010
We'll give that a second just to spin up.

138
00:06:30.070 --> 00:06:33.070
And once that just loads,
quickly does a little preload.

139
00:06:33.070 --> 00:06:36.150
Puts itself in memory checks to make
sure that we have the right version,

140
00:06:36.150 --> 00:06:37.140
that kind of stuff.

141
00:06:37.140 --> 00:06:39.150
Are we on the right version of the OS.

142
00:06:39.150 --> 00:06:41.990
All those background pre-req
checks that we talked about.

143
00:06:41.990 --> 00:06:42.860
Once that comes up,

144
00:06:42.860 --> 00:06:46.450
then what'll we do is we get our
Select features to install window.

145
00:06:46.450 --> 00:06:49.620
Just move up here a smidge, so
we can just kind of see that.

146
00:06:49.620 --> 00:06:51.510
You'll see we have
the Setup bar at the top.

147
00:06:51.510 --> 00:06:54.910
We're gonna go through, we obviously are
gonna build out those blue items as we go.

148
00:06:54.910 --> 00:06:59.870
Select features to install, notice we
have the VMM Server and the VMM Console.

149
00:06:59.870 --> 00:07:02.010
So we're gonna want to do both here.

150
00:07:02.010 --> 00:07:04.470
Choose the VMM Server and
notice once we do that,

151
00:07:04.470 --> 00:07:06.330
it automatically selects the console.

152
00:07:06.330 --> 00:07:08.420
Because we don't have
a server already installed,

153
00:07:08.420 --> 00:07:10.470
we can't install the console separately.

154
00:07:10.470 --> 00:07:13.060
Gotta be able to do both together,
so we're gonna do that.

155
00:07:13.060 --> 00:07:14.420
If we don't know what
the requirements are,

156
00:07:14.420 --> 00:07:16.510
it does tell us what they are right there.

157
00:07:16.510 --> 00:07:18.450
We ran through them already,
told you what they were.

158
00:07:18.450 --> 00:07:21.350
We can click View all install
requirements gives us a list,

159
00:07:21.350 --> 00:07:24.580
tells us what we need to make sure
we have all the requirements.

160
00:07:24.580 --> 00:07:27.190
Same thing for the VMM console there.

161
00:07:27.190 --> 00:07:30.300
>> Interesting, no installing
the server without the console at all.

162
00:07:31.620 --> 00:07:35.046
Or at least that's what it seems to be
cuz it grays out the ability to uncheck.

163
00:07:35.046 --> 00:07:36.420
>> Right, you need both.

164
00:07:36.420 --> 00:07:38.867
Yeah, you need that in order to do that
cuz you have to be able to manage it.

00:17:44.060 --> 00:17:46.980

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Adam demonstrate how to install the SCOM App Controller. They start by looking at the prerequisites that are necessary for the installation. Then they take you step-by-step through the installation, explaining each of the options in detail.

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Adam demonstrate how to install the Operations Manager on a single server. 802

That being said, I'm looking at our clock.

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Adam demonstrate how to install the System Center Data Protection Manager. They start by looking at the prerequisites that are necessary for the installation. Then they take you step-by-step through the installation, explaining each of the options in detail.
episodes.title: Install Data Protection Manager

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Adam demonstrate how to install the Service Manager on Single Server. They start by looking at the prerequisites that are necessary for the installation. Then they take you step-by-step through the installation, explaining each of the options in detail.
episodes.title: Install Service Manger on a Single Server

141
00:06:41.000 --> 00:06:43.110
We got a little installation summary.

142
00:06:43.110 --> 00:06:46.313
Gonna let that sit there for a second,
just so you can see what you're doing.

143
00:06:46.313 --> 00:06:49.720
Give you the standard reminder I've been
giving you in every episode around this.

144
00:06:49.720 --> 00:06:52.080
Screen capture this,
use it for your documentation.

145
00:06:52.080 --> 00:06:57.220
Make your auditors and make your IA
professionals in your organizations happy,

146
00:06:57.220 --> 00:06:58.760
make sure you have good documentation.

147
00:06:58.760 --> 00:07:02.780
It's gonna help you when it comes to BCDR,
business continuity disaster recovery,

148
00:07:02.780 --> 00:07:05.360
around this or
any of our products that we're installing.

149
00:07:05.360 --> 00:07:08.180
You can never go wrong with having too
much documentation when it comes to how

150
00:07:08.180 --> 00:07:09.220
you install and configure.

151
00:07:09.220 --> 00:07:11.070
So take advantage of that, right?

152
00:07:11.070 --> 00:07:14.320
All right, we're gonna click Install,
we're gonna wait for that to go out and

153
00:07:14.320 --> 00:07:14.910
do its thing.

154
00:07:14.910 --> 00:07:16.970
It is gonna take a few
minutes as you can see.

155
00:07:16.970 --> 00:07:18.320
We're gonna let that cook.

156
00:07:18.320 --> 00:07:20.870
When we come back, we're gonna
have this all set up ready to go,

157
00:07:20.870 --> 00:07:22.170
and we'll take a look at it for you.

158
00:07:23.650 --> 00:07:27.760
All right, so we can see the Service
Manager Setup Wizard has completed.

159
00:07:27.760 --> 00:07:29.590
This time,
it's white circles with green checks.

160
00:07:29.590 --> 00:07:33.600
I love it when we get this randomization
of completion and success, right?

161
00:07:33.600 --> 00:07:36.040
We normally have green circle,
white check.

162
00:07:36.040 --> 00:07:38.165
We now have white circle, green check, and

163
00:07:38.165 --> 00:07:40.935
remember, we had just the check
in one of the other ones.

164
00:07:40.935 --> 00:07:43.170
So it is just a potpourri,

165
00:07:43.170 --> 00:07:48.850
a cornucopia of random success
markers here, as we go through.

166
00:07:48.850 --> 00:07:50.010
But we do see success, and

167
00:07:50.010 --> 00:07:52.530
the interesting thing about this one,
we're not actually done yet.

168
00:07:52.530 --> 00:07:54.200
We are in the sense we've installed.

169
00:07:54.200 --> 00:07:57.770
But we have to go through and
have to run the encryption key backup and

170
00:07:57.770 --> 00:08:01.670
restore wizard, so that we can back up the
encryption keys for Service Level Manager.

171
00:08:01.670 --> 00:08:03.970
I'm gonna show you how
to do that right now.

172
00:08:03.970 --> 00:08:05.910
We do have the open encryption backup and

173
00:08:05.910 --> 00:08:08.650
restore wizard check mark
down at the bottom selector.

174
00:08:08.650 --> 00:08:11.490
We're gonna leave that there,
we're not gonna open the console yet,

175
00:08:11.490 --> 00:08:12.960
we're gonna run this first.

176
00:08:12.960 --> 00:08:15.430
And then where we double
take a look at the console.

177
00:08:15.430 --> 00:08:17.286
So we're gonna go ahead and click Close.

178
00:08:17.286 --> 00:08:19.274
This is gonna launch the wizard for us,

179
00:08:19.274 --> 00:08:22.540
I'm just gonna kill the installation
media in the background.

180
00:08:22.540 --> 00:08:25.920
Just get that out of the way, so
we have a little room on the screen.

181
00:08:25.920 --> 00:08:29.220
Let me just bring this over,
kind of centered, so we can see that.

182
00:08:29.220 --> 00:08:35.640
We'll offset that just a little bit, so
we can see what that says right there,

183
00:08:35.640 --> 00:08:40.260
encrypting key, backup or restore wizard,
we're gonna click Next on this.

184
00:08:40.260 --> 00:08:42.430
We're gonna go ahead and
decide what we're doing.

185
00:08:42.430 --> 00:08:44.440
We haven't backed up the key yet,
so obviously,

186
00:08:44.440 --> 00:08:47.160
backing up first, restoring second, right?

187
00:08:47.160 --> 00:08:48.700
So we're gonna go ahead, and
we're gonna back up the key.

188
00:08:48.700 --> 00:08:52.880
Notice by default, it is selected and
that is the option we're gonna go for.

189
00:08:52.880 --> 00:08:53.910
We'll click Next.

190
00:08:53.910 --> 00:08:57.150
We have to browse and
specify where we're gonna put this.

191
00:08:57.150 --> 00:09:01.830
We're gonna go ahead, and
we're gonna specify or just browse, and

192
00:09:01.830 --> 00:09:03.570
use the default path.

193
00:09:03.570 --> 00:09:06.050
We'll do it in our documents
directory locally for

194
00:09:06.050 --> 00:09:08.540
the user logged on that's
doing the install.

195
00:09:08.540 --> 00:09:11.160
For you, you would obviously
put this somewhere more secure.

196
00:09:11.160 --> 00:09:14.980
Specify a place where you're gonna be able
to store that key or retrieve it, and

197
00:09:14.980 --> 00:09:17.270
then use it from there when necessary.

198
00:09:17.270 --> 00:09:20.240
I'm just gonna call mine SM for
Service Manager key.

199
00:09:20.240 --> 00:09:23.060
So I'm gonna call the file SM key,
all right.

200
00:09:23.060 --> 00:09:24.440
So we'll put that in there.

201
00:09:24.440 --> 00:09:26.140
You'll see it's in the directory,

202
00:09:26.140 --> 00:09:30.850
My Documents directory, where we did the
demo, if you remember, for setting up and

203
00:09:30.850 --> 00:09:34.610
taking a look at various things and
downloading and putting them in.

204
00:09:34.610 --> 00:09:37.430
We may have information floating
around a variety of places.

205
00:09:37.430 --> 00:09:38.480
So we're just gonna store it here.

206
00:09:38.480 --> 00:09:41.480
We'll click Open, got that in there.

207
00:09:41.480 --> 00:09:44.710
Populates that path for us,
really nice, we'll click Next.

208
00:09:44.710 --> 00:09:46.410
Are we gonna use a password with that?

209
00:09:46.410 --> 00:09:48.880
If we wanna use a password,
assign one to the file.

210
00:09:48.880 --> 00:09:51.090
So we'll put our password in there.

211
00:09:51.090 --> 00:09:55.510
Just hit Tab for that,
we'll do that, click Next.

212
00:09:55.510 --> 00:09:58.190
And then, just wait for
that, we'll click Complete.

213
00:09:58.190 --> 00:10:02.040
So, we have that all set up, ready to go,
really, nothing more involved than that.

214
00:10:02.040 --> 00:10:03.730
It's just that way, we have the key.

215
00:10:03.730 --> 00:10:07.040
And if there's a problem,
we can obviously run the restore procedure

216
00:10:07.040 --> 00:10:10.660
using the same program, and run it
the opposite way and restore the key.

217
00:10:10.660 --> 00:10:12.780
We're gonna go in and
load the console now.

218
00:10:12.780 --> 00:10:15.360
So, we're gonna go to our Start workspace.

219
00:10:15.360 --> 00:10:18.510
We'll see that we do not have
it installed here as a tile.

220
00:10:18.510 --> 00:10:19.720
We haven't added it in.

221
00:10:19.720 --> 00:10:22.070
We have added in some of the other
ones we've been working with.

222
00:10:22.070 --> 00:10:25.830
We can either go browse for it, or
we can just search for it either way.

223
00:10:25.830 --> 00:10:29.570
So if we just search right from here,
start typing service,

224
00:10:29.570 --> 00:10:34.650
you'll see Service Manager Console comes
up right down here, about halfway down.

225
00:10:34.650 --> 00:10:39.370
Gonna right click on that, we'll do a pin
to start just so we can see it right here.

226
00:10:39.370 --> 00:10:42.915
Get out of there, we'll right click,
we'll do pin to task bar, so we have it.

227
00:10:42.915 --> 00:10:46.120
And we'll do a run as administrator,
right?

228
00:10:46.120 --> 00:10:48.070
So we're gonna load that up real quick.

229
00:10:48.070 --> 00:10:51.421
We could see that when we do that,
we are then prompted for the connect to,

230
00:10:51.421 --> 00:10:53.708
what's the server name
we're gonna connect to.

231
00:10:53.708 --> 00:10:56.910
Gonna connect to our server
where we did the install.

232
00:10:56.910 --> 00:10:59.370
Assuming all the services are running,
everything's running well,

233
00:10:59.370 --> 00:11:02.140
should be able to get in there
after just a momentary pause.

234
00:11:02.140 --> 00:11:04.450
It's loading up right now,
you'll see that come up.

235
00:11:04.450 --> 00:11:09.400
Once it does, you'll see that we have the
Service Level Management console in here.

236
00:11:09.400 --> 00:11:12.410
We've got some workspace areas
we can quickly identify.

237
00:11:12.410 --> 00:11:14.350
We've got the administration workspace.

238
00:11:14.350 --> 00:11:18.230
We have the library workspace,
work items, and configuration items.

239
00:11:18.230 --> 00:11:20.650
We'll be going through and
take a look at this product and

240
00:11:20.650 --> 00:11:23.250
talking more about it some
of our upcoming episodes.

241
00:11:23.250 --> 00:11:27.592
But remember, this is where we're gonna be
able to take the output of Ops Manager,

242
00:11:27.592 --> 00:11:30.180
once we create the configuration

243
00:11:30.180 --> 00:11:33.230
that binds these two products
together through a connector.

244
00:11:33.230 --> 00:11:37.424
And allow the alerts that are generated
there to actually then come over here and

245
00:11:37.424 --> 00:11:40.490
open up configuration items,
work items, tickets, and

246
00:11:40.490 --> 00:11:43.822
do resolution, or
walk through the resolution chains for us.

247
00:11:43.822 --> 00:11:46.430
So we're gonna see this synergy
starting to take place.

248
00:11:46.430 --> 00:11:50.434
We'll have some upcoming episodes where
we talk about how do we configure all

249
00:11:50.434 --> 00:11:54.825
the interaction and the interconnection
that is required between these products.

250
00:11:54.825 --> 00:11:57.893
So they could talk to each other, and
we'll be setting that up here and

251
00:11:57.893 --> 00:11:59.330
being able to work with it.

252
00:11:59.330 --> 00:12:00.500
And once we've done that,

253
00:12:00.500 --> 00:12:03.480
we'll then be able to see
the information flowing back and forth.

254
00:12:03.480 --> 00:12:06.550
So we'll be taking a look at that
some of our upcoming discussions, but

255
00:12:06.550 --> 00:12:08.183
you can see as we get in and set this up,

256
00:12:08.183 --> 00:12:11.538
this one does take a little bit longer
than most of the others to instantiate.

257
00:12:11.538 --> 00:12:13.980
It's about a 15 minute install,
give or take.

258
00:12:13.980 --> 00:12:15.700
It's amazing how that time just flies by.

259
00:12:15.700 --> 00:12:17.270
>> [LAUGH]
>> It's like nothing.

260
00:12:17.270 --> 00:12:18.910
But it does take a little
bit longer than the other.

261
00:12:18.910 --> 00:12:22.620
So don't be surprised when you go
to install Service Level Manager

262
00:12:22.620 --> 00:12:23.550
that it does take longer.

263
00:12:23.550 --> 00:12:26.390
The main reason, and
I was talking about this with Daniel while

264
00:12:26.390 --> 00:12:31.390
we were waiting on it to finish, is the
need to import all the management packs.

265
00:12:31.390 --> 00:12:35.750
You could see we have 137 of them sitting
there that have been imported by default,

266
00:12:35.750 --> 00:12:37.730
and there's quite a number of them for

267
00:12:37.730 --> 00:12:40.630
Service Level Manager and this is what
takes the longest amount of time.

268
00:12:40.630 --> 00:12:43.480
It's gonna copy all of that information,
bring it in, and

269
00:12:43.480 --> 00:12:46.480
set it up the right way as part of
configuration of the tool initially.

270
00:12:46.480 --> 00:12:48.970
So this is why it does tend
to take a little bit longer

271
00:12:48.970 --> 00:12:51.460
than some of the other programs
that we've done the demos for.

272
00:12:51.460 --> 00:12:53.110
So just so you have a sense of that.

273
00:12:53.110 --> 00:12:53.870
>> All right, well, Adam,

274
00:12:53.870 --> 00:12:57.420
thanks for walking us through
installing the Service Manager.

275
00:12:57.420 --> 00:12:59.070
Like you said, not too difficult, but

276
00:12:59.070 --> 00:13:04.590
a little bit of time consuming on the
plate there, so just be prepared for that.

277
00:13:04.590 --> 00:13:07.070
That being said, looks like we've
come to the end of this episode.

278
00:13:07.070 --> 00:13:08.810
Adam, thanks so much for joining us today.

279
00:13:08.810 --> 00:13:10.410
We do thank our audience for watching,

280
00:13:10.410 --> 00:13:14.270
but signing off for ITPRO.TV,
I've been your host, Daniel Lowrie.

281
00:13:14.270 --> 00:13:15.372
>> I'm Adam Gordon.

282
00:13:15.372 --> 00:13:17.883
>> And we'll see you next time.

283
00:13:17.883 --> 00:13:23.860
[MUSIC]

284
00:13:23.860 --> 00:13:26.710
>> Thank you for watching ITPRO.TV.

topics.title: Deploying System Center 2012 R2 Ops Management Group

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Adam show you the resources you'll need to successfully upgrade your Operations Manager Server. They begin by explaining the proper upgrade paths as well as making the distinction between upgrades and migrations. Then they point you toward documentation from Microsoft that guides each upgrade type.
episodes.title: Upgrading Operations Manager
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.280 --> 00:00:05.918
Welcome to ITProTV,
I'm your host [CROSSTALK].

2
00:00:05.918 --> 00:00:08.216
[MUSIC]

3
00:00:08.216 --> 00:00:10.736
>> You're watching ITProTV.

4
00:00:10.736 --> 00:00:12.257
[MUSIC]

5
00:00:12.257 --> 00:00:14.077
>> All right, greetings everyone and

00:00:14.077 --> 00:00:17.040
welcome to another great
episode of ITProTV.

I'm your host Daniel Lowrie and
in today's episode,

00:00:19.160 --> 00:00:24.280
we're back with more of our series on data
center monitoring using Microsoft SCOM.

9
00:00:24.280 --> 00:00:27.980
And joining us back in the studio,
our good friend, Mr. Adam Gordon.

00:00:27.980 --> 00:00:29.900
Adam, welcome back, so
glad to have you again, today.

>> Always glad to be here, hanging out

00:00:34.160 --> 00:00:36.495
audience folk out there,
and I expert TV event.

13
00:00:36.495 --> 00:00:39.355
We're gonna continue our conversations,
come take a look at

14
00:00:39.355 --> 00:00:43.535
one of the interesting, important,
although often underrated topics,

15
00:00:43.535 --> 00:00:46.975
associated with using SCOM which is,
how do we migrate?

16
00:00:46.975 --> 00:00:52.117
How do we get from SCOM 2007,
let's say hypothetically or

17
00:00:52.117 --> 00:00:59.208
12 or 12 SP1 into 12 R2, we have a very
clearly defined pathway have to follow.

18
00:00:59.208 --> 00:01:02.221
Got some information that'll
make that helpful for you,

19
00:01:02.221 --> 00:01:05.861
the basic concept is real simple,
I'm gonna give it to you right now.

20
00:01:05.861 --> 00:01:08.955
And then essentially we're done,
it's like a 30 second episode.

21
00:01:08.955 --> 00:01:10.139
>> [LAUGH].
>> Which we've never done before but

22
00:01:10.139 --> 00:01:12.653
we're gonna extend that, we're not
really gonna do a 30 second episode.

23
00:01:12.653 --> 00:01:16.438
But I could literally tell you everything
you need to know in 30 seconds.

24
00:01:16.438 --> 00:01:19.755
Which is going from SCOM 2007,

25
00:01:19.755 --> 00:01:25.173
2012 and/or 2012 SP1 is
really very specific,

26
00:01:25.173 --> 00:01:30.588
very easily defined,
very linear path, which is you must

27
00:01:30.588 --> 00:01:36.460
stop at every version up through 2012 R2,
on your way.

28
00:01:36.460 --> 00:01:42.185
So, to go from SCOM 2007, you can't go
right to 12 R2, you got to go to 12,

29
00:01:42.185 --> 00:01:47.348
then 12SP1, then 12 R2,
if you're in 12, you gotta go 12 SP1,

30
00:01:47.348 --> 00:01:52.129
then 12 R2, if you're in 12 SP1,
you gotta go SP1 to 12 R2.

31
00:01:52.129 --> 00:01:56.631
So, how you do it is really just
a question of degrees, right?

32
00:01:56.631 --> 00:02:01.113
It's a question of going through,
doing as many as three rounds of

33
00:02:01.113 --> 00:02:04.967
upgrades along the way,
if you're gonna be doing that.

34
00:02:04.967 --> 00:02:09.004
And as you're doing that,
as opposed to installing brand new,

35
00:02:09.004 --> 00:02:13.491
you are just adding in,
all the additional capabilities, features,

36
00:02:13.491 --> 00:02:16.886
binary bits, updates,
etc that bring you current.

37
00:02:16.886 --> 00:02:20.717
And we'll talk about and show you just
some of the guidance associated with that.

38
00:02:20.717 --> 00:02:24.287
There's some real good documentation
out on the web, it's real simple to do,

39
00:02:24.287 --> 00:02:27.022
we'll point out some things for
you'll want to be aware of.

40
00:02:27.022 --> 00:02:32.799
Got to make sure you're at a certain
starting point level in SCOM 2007, you

41
00:02:32.799 --> 00:02:39.111
gotta be 2007 R2 cumulative update four
in order to start down that upgrade path.

42
00:02:39.111 --> 00:02:42.377
So, you just wanna know that, that may
not apply to a lot of you, by the way.

43
00:02:42.377 --> 00:02:46.080
A lot of you may already be running
newer iterations of the product, so,

44
00:02:46.080 --> 00:02:49.640
that's fine, no big deal, but
if you're running all the version,

45
00:02:49.640 --> 00:02:51.570
got to make sure you read
at least that version.

46
00:02:51.570 --> 00:02:54.404
If you're not, got to go
download the appropriate updates,

47
00:02:54.404 --> 00:02:56.375
make sure you have that capability there.

48
00:02:56.375 --> 00:03:00.710
But once you're at 2007 R2
cumulative update four, we call CU,

49
00:03:00.710 --> 00:03:04.240
cumulative update four,
you're ready to start going.

50
00:03:04.240 --> 00:03:10.213
You go from there to 12, from 12 to 12SP1,
and then from 12SP1 into 12R2.

51
00:03:10.213 --> 00:03:14.012
So, It is a bit of a convoluted process,
you remember, we do movies all the time,

52
00:03:14.012 --> 00:03:16.450
we don't really,
I don't think we've ever done-

53
00:03:16.450 --> 00:03:17.470
>> We do love the movies.

54
00:03:17.470 --> 00:03:18.251
>> We do love the movies.

55
00:03:18.251 --> 00:03:19.897
>> [LAUGH]
>> And I've got a different approach for

56
00:03:19.897 --> 00:03:22.833
you at the movies, we've never
really done old school video games,

57
00:03:22.833 --> 00:03:23.802
as opposed to movies.

58
00:03:23.802 --> 00:03:24.941
>> Okay.

59
00:03:24.941 --> 00:03:28.702
>> But when I, I'm old enough that-
>> [LAUGH]

60
00:03:28.702 --> 00:03:30.021
>> I remember when Pong first came

61
00:03:30.021 --> 00:03:30.583
out, okay?

62
00:03:30.583 --> 00:03:31.490
>> I don't think I was alive.

63
00:03:31.490 --> 00:03:33.246
[LAUGH]
>> Yeah, I was, so,

64
00:03:33.246 --> 00:03:35.650
that's a whole generational thing.

65
00:03:35.650 --> 00:03:39.320
But I mean, I remember, cuz we had
restaurants when I was growing up.

66
00:03:39.320 --> 00:03:41.920
For many years my family's been
in the restaurant business and

67
00:03:41.920 --> 00:03:45.580
I remember in one of our sub
shops we actually had one of

68
00:03:45.580 --> 00:03:47.480
the first tabletop Pong
games when they came out.

00:03:47.480 --> 00:03:51.390
It was like a big deal, you put your food

70
00:03:51.390 --> 00:03:53.060
I remember playing that when I was a kid.

71

So, Pong is not thing I'm

but you remember playing Frogger?

>> Yeah, yeah.
>> You remember?

So, you remember you have to jump like

across and not get run over by the mad
trucker or get swept down the stream.

>> It was a fun game.

77

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Adam continue their conversation about Fabric and Application monitoring. They pick up by talking about targeting your rules for specific outcomes.
