00:29:23.660 --> 00:29:26.110
We can see a little bit of
the detail here real quick.

686
00:29:26.110 --> 00:29:29.570
We've got, and again, we're running
this in just a demo environment.

687
00:29:29.570 --> 00:29:31.760
We are not really doing any
heavy duty monitoring right now.

688
00:29:31.760 --> 00:29:34.150
We're just in and out of certain features,
just showing you stuff.

689
00:29:34.150 --> 00:29:36.290
So there's a limited amount
of data in the database,

690
00:29:36.290 --> 00:29:40.770
but even then we do have information
on the different management packs.

691
00:29:40.770 --> 00:29:44.320
We can see percent of total
in terms of data volume.

692
00:29:44.320 --> 00:29:46.080
How much each management
pack is taking up.

693
00:29:46.080 --> 00:29:48.940
And the largest one is
the health library there.

694
00:29:48.940 --> 00:29:52.800
Not very big but it's using
the largest amount of data overall.

695
00:29:52.800 --> 00:29:55.790
It's got 106 state changes
that have taken place,

696
00:29:55.790 --> 00:29:57.970
whereas most of the others are very small.

697
00:29:57.970 --> 00:30:00.490
The System Center Core Library
is right up there,

698
00:30:00.490 --> 00:30:03.670
about half the size overall
the number of state changes.

699
00:30:03.670 --> 00:30:07.664
But we could go in, and we can click
through, let just pull down here so

700
00:30:07.664 --> 00:30:10.466
you can see some of this
before we click through.

701
00:30:10.466 --> 00:30:15.002
But we do have these nice graphs below
that are gonna show us the actual data

702
00:30:15.002 --> 00:30:19.538
count, the discovery data submitted
by date, generated alerts by day,

703
00:30:19.538 --> 00:30:20.725
that kinda thing.

704
00:30:20.725 --> 00:30:24.721
So we could see that graphic and if we had
more data and we did a larger time span

705
00:30:24.721 --> 00:30:28.980
other than a single day, we'd also have
a more impressive set of visuals there.

706
00:30:28.980 --> 00:30:34.350
It's fairly limited overall, but we can
click through on the health library.

707
00:30:34.350 --> 00:30:36.350
Just click on that one management pack.

708
00:30:36.350 --> 00:30:37.990
It'll then take as down and

709
00:30:37.990 --> 00:30:43.140
show us specific information on this
particular instance within the report.

710
00:30:43.140 --> 00:30:46.210
So we can drill down here,
get more information.

711
00:30:46.210 --> 00:30:48.120
Whether or
not there's data in this one instance,

712
00:30:48.120 --> 00:30:50.840
that we would see charted,
obviously depends, right.

713
00:30:50.840 --> 00:30:53.100
But in general you could see,
we could drill in.

714
00:30:53.100 --> 00:31:00.780
We could Continue to drill down,
give that just a second.

715
00:31:00.780 --> 00:31:03.580
And if we drill through here,

716
00:31:04.610 --> 00:31:09.710
just on the number of the actual
state changes that occurred,

717
00:31:09.710 --> 00:31:12.540
we can see they're broken out,
and they're broken out by type.

718
00:31:12.540 --> 00:31:16.260
Entity health, availability,
config performance, count for

719
00:31:16.260 --> 00:31:19.970
each, percentage of data
volume total is listed here.

720
00:31:19.970 --> 00:31:23.050
We get that charted, so
we can actually see that.

721
00:31:23.050 --> 00:31:27.210
And we see an actual instance by
class of all the different counts.

722
00:31:27.210 --> 00:31:28.967
I mean this is detail reporting,

723
00:31:28.967 --> 00:31:31.870
this is just an out of the box
report by the way right?.

724
00:31:31.870 --> 00:31:35.190
This is not one, we would create and
customize on our own.

725
00:31:35.190 --> 00:31:39.400
But rather simply, an out of the box
instance of the reports that are generated

726
00:31:39.400 --> 00:31:43.330
and created as part of the importation
of the standard management packs.

727
00:31:43.330 --> 00:31:45.450
Remember reports are part
of management packs,

728
00:31:45.450 --> 00:31:48.950
they come in as part of
the association when we import them.

729
00:31:48.950 --> 00:31:49.950
And as a result,

730
00:31:49.950 --> 00:31:53.660
we're getting this detailed data
coming back from the data warehouse.

731
00:31:53.660 --> 00:31:56.555
All we have to do is be smart enough
to figure out what reports are there,

732
00:31:56.555 --> 00:31:58.198
understand how they can be leveraged and

733
00:31:58.198 --> 00:32:00.002
we can get this kind
of detailed reporting.

734
00:32:00.002 --> 00:32:03.734
And if we need to customize,
we can go ahead and customize reports,

735
00:32:03.734 --> 00:32:07.935
create our own queries, our own data
sources, link to the various tables.

736
00:32:07.935 --> 00:32:11.297
As long as we have a little bit
of background with the design and

737
00:32:11.297 --> 00:32:15.565
the layout and we understand the SQL query
language for the SQL structure query

738
00:32:15.565 --> 00:32:19.980
language that we would be using, we could
do just about anything we wanted here.

739
00:32:19.980 --> 00:32:20.859
So this is a very,

740
00:32:20.859 --> 00:32:24.205
very powerful element of the management
pack that we also wanna make

741
00:32:24.205 --> 00:32:28.290
sure we're aware of and we're thinking
about as part of this conversation.

742
00:32:28.290 --> 00:32:32.092
>> Definitely a fairly robust monitoring
system that we've built in here,

743
00:32:32.092 --> 00:32:35.598
interesting stuff, we can dive into
that very deeply if we need to.

744
00:32:35.598 --> 00:32:40.621
And speaking of deep dives, guess what,
we are at the end of time for

745
00:32:40.621 --> 00:32:45.577
this episode and we're well out of
O2 when it comes for this show.

746
00:32:45.577 --> 00:32:48.306
So we'll have to roll this into a part 3,
continue this conversation and

747
00:32:48.306 --> 00:32:50.033
then we got a couple more
things to talk about.

748
00:32:50.033 --> 00:32:52.382
In this regards,
move onto fabric as well so

749
00:32:52.382 --> 00:32:55.370
that will definitely be
an interesting conversation.

750
00:32:55.370 --> 00:32:56.890
You should totally come back for that.

751
00:32:56.890 --> 00:33:01.000
Adam, we thank you for getting us here so
far, now it's time to refill the tanks,

752
00:33:01.000 --> 00:33:02.350
recharge the batteries.

753
00:33:02.350 --> 00:33:04.280
And come back for that part 3 and
see the rest of it.

754
00:33:04.280 --> 00:33:05.250
So join us there.

755
00:33:05.250 --> 00:33:07.610
As for this episode thanks for watching.

756
00:33:07.610 --> 00:33:10.940
I've been your host Daniel Lawry for
ITPro.TV.

757
00:33:10.940 --> 00:33:13.200
>> Remember I'm Adam Gordan and
when you're out of air,

758
00:33:13.200 --> 00:33:15.720
always follow the bubbles
up as opposed to down.

759
00:33:15.720 --> 00:33:17.123
>> Wise words.
And we'll see you next time.

760
00:33:17.123 --> 00:33:18.456
>> See you next time everybody.

761
00:33:18.456 --> 00:33:26.527
Take care.
[MUSIC]

762
00:33:26.527 --> 00:33:29.059
Thank you for watching ITPro.TV.

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Adam finish their conversation about Fabric and Application monitoring. They start with configuring network device monitoring then jump over to setting up Fabric monitoring.
episodes.title: Fabric and Application Monitoring Part 3
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.008 --> 00:00:01.230
Welcome to ITPRO.TV.

2
00:00:01.230 --> 00:00:02.403
I'm your host, Don Pezet.

3
00:00:02.403 --> 00:00:06.381
>> [CROSSTALK]

4
00:00:06.381 --> 00:00:08.344
[MUSIC]

5
00:00:08.344 --> 00:00:12.149
>> You're watching ITPRO.TV.

6
00:00:12.149 --> 00:00:14.088
>> All right, greetings everyone and

7
00:00:14.088 --> 00:00:16.960
welcome to another exciting
episode of ITPRO.TV.

8
00:00:16.960 --> 00:00:20.030
I'm your host Daniel Lowrie, and in
today's episode we are coming back at you

9
00:00:20.030 --> 00:00:24.730
with more On our data center
monitoring with Microsoft SCOM series.

10
00:00:24.730 --> 00:00:28.510
And just when you thought
it was safe to go back

11
00:00:28.510 --> 00:00:32.880
into the monitoring of the fabric end,
the network applications, guess what?

12
00:00:32.880 --> 00:00:34.600
We're back for a more of a,
sort of, part three.

13
00:00:34.600 --> 00:00:37.410
And joining us on that part
three to round out the series,

14
00:00:37.410 --> 00:00:40.880
the mini-series inside the series,
our good friend Mr. Adam Gordon.

15
00:00:40.880 --> 00:00:42.450
Adam, welcome back, man.

16
00:00:42.450 --> 00:00:43.400
Where are we going today?

17
00:00:43.400 --> 00:00:45.500
[LAUGH]
>> I'm still trying to wrap my head around

18
00:00:45.500 --> 00:00:48.030
the series inside the series
inside the series.

19
00:00:48.030 --> 00:00:49.130
>> It's like a Russian doll.

20
00:00:49.130 --> 00:00:51.190
>> It is, the dolls, those are awesome.

21
00:00:51.190 --> 00:00:55.980
I actually have a set of political
dolls from Russia from right before

22
00:00:55.980 --> 00:00:58.362
the wall came down.

23
00:00:58.362 --> 00:01:00.113
The Berlin Wall,
the dissolution of the Soviet Union, and

24
00:01:00.113 --> 00:01:02.510
I have all the leaders going all the way
back and all the way up through Gorbechov.

25
00:01:02.510 --> 00:01:04.373
>> That's actually kind of cool.

26
00:01:04.373 --> 00:01:08.760
>> Hand painted from Moscow, it's one
of my thesis advisors when I was in

27
00:01:08.760 --> 00:01:11.370
school brought it back for me cuz he
was stationed over there for awhile.

28
00:01:11.370 --> 00:01:12.100
>> How about that?

29
00:01:12.100 --> 00:01:12.930
>> Yeah, it's actually.

30
00:01:12.930 --> 00:01:14.173
>> Very cool.
>> It's very, very cool.

31
00:01:14.173 --> 00:01:16.560
So anyway, [CROSSTALK]
>> So what are we doing today?

32
00:01:16.560 --> 00:01:17.680
>> What?
>> So what are we doing today?

33
00:01:17.680 --> 00:01:18.850
>> Yeah, I was just gonna say,
we're not here.

34
00:01:18.850 --> 00:01:20.440
It's like Antique Road Show.

35
00:01:20.440 --> 00:01:21.300
We're not here to do that.

36
00:01:21.300 --> 00:01:24.570
We are here, however,
to continue talking as Daniel said,

37
00:01:24.570 --> 00:01:29.210
part three cuz you know one and two were
just not enough and strangely enough,

38
00:01:29.210 --> 00:01:31.680
if you add one and
two together, you get three.

39
00:01:31.680 --> 00:01:33.590
>> That's true.

40
00:01:33.590 --> 00:01:35.810
>> That's how we got here
cuz we took parts one and

41
00:01:35.810 --> 00:01:40.110
part two, didn't have enough in there to
finish up and we added it together and

42
00:01:40.110 --> 00:01:43.820
we're about to add some knowledge
to your heads as we see.

43
00:01:43.820 --> 00:01:47.480
We're gonna talk about monitoring,
and device monitoring and discovery.

44
00:01:47.480 --> 00:01:49.060
Specifically network monitoring and

45
00:01:49.060 --> 00:01:51.950
configuring that fabric Daniel keeps
hinting at and talking about with SCVMM.

46
00:01:51.950 --> 00:01:54.450
We're just gonna talk
through some of that.

47
00:01:54.450 --> 00:01:57.460
We've then got a series of episodes coming
up right after this where we're gonna demo

48
00:01:57.460 --> 00:01:59.460
some of this for
you in a little bit more detail.

49
00:01:59.460 --> 00:02:03.750
Take in through network discovery,
show you how that works, where to demo.

50
00:02:03.750 --> 00:02:07.980
How to set up and configure VMM and
integrate it so we have pro monitoring

51
00:02:07.980 --> 00:02:11.950
taking place and the SQL analysis and
all that kinda stuff that we need.

52
00:02:11.950 --> 00:02:13.940
So we're gonna do some cool things for
you there.

53
00:02:13.940 --> 00:02:16.300
But first we're gonna talk
a bit more about monitoring.

54
00:02:16.300 --> 00:02:17.845
So when we think about
monitoring with SCOM,

55
00:02:17.845 --> 00:02:20.035
we've can talk a lot
about it in this setup.

56
00:02:20.035 --> 00:02:23.165
Since we're talking about management
packs, how we configured all that.

57
00:02:23.165 --> 00:02:26.245
We also could do discovery and
find network devices.

58
00:02:26.245 --> 00:02:28.545
And this is one of the other
things that's kinda cool.

59
00:02:28.545 --> 00:02:33.457
Network device monitoring allows us
to go out and find using either SNMP,

60
00:02:33.457 --> 00:02:38.107
Simple Network Management Protocol version
one, version two, and/or version three.

61
00:02:38.107 --> 00:02:40.737
And includes the ability to be
able to use both IPv4 and IPv6,

62
00:02:40.737 --> 00:02:46.097
the ability to be able to find devices
from over 80 manufactures currently and

63
00:02:46.097 --> 00:02:49.527
even more to come, so
continue to evolve this product over time.

64
00:02:49.527 --> 00:02:53.910
We can discover using seven different
views and we can then go out and

65
00:02:53.910 --> 00:02:55.410
figure out what's out there.

66
00:02:55.410 --> 00:02:59.410
And not just manager,
not just manage computers, but

67
00:02:59.410 --> 00:03:00.820
also manage network endpoints.

68
00:03:00.820 --> 00:03:06.025
So routers, switches, things like that
can be discovered and brought in as well.

69
00:03:06.025 --> 00:03:09.805
We extend the monitoring for
process, for memory consumption.

70
00:03:09.805 --> 00:03:13.705
So we're looking at performance, and we're
looking at health as a result of that.

71
00:03:13.705 --> 00:03:16.555
So we have capabilities that
are gonna go deep and wide there.

72
00:03:16.555 --> 00:03:19.235
So if we take a look over here for
just a minute, what we'll see is,

73
00:03:19.235 --> 00:03:22.660
we do have a little primer on this for
you up on the web.

74
00:03:22.660 --> 00:03:24.510
Thank you to Microsoft, once again, for

75
00:03:24.510 --> 00:03:28.480
doing such a great job with getting all
the documentation out there for us.

76
00:03:28.480 --> 00:03:31.440
We got different network device
views that we wanna be aware of, and

77
00:03:31.440 --> 00:03:34.010
I'm gonna show these to
you here in just a minute.

78
00:03:34.010 --> 00:03:39.365
But we talk about here, we've got
the host's view, legacy network devices.

79
00:03:39.365 --> 00:03:42.835
We've got router switches,
DLANs, something called HSRP,

80
00:03:42.835 --> 00:03:47.575
the hot standby router protocol,
Cisco proprietary protocol,

81
00:03:47.575 --> 00:03:50.665
going to have a little website up here
I'll show you in just a sec which

82
00:03:50.665 --> 00:03:54.555
gives you some detailed information
direct from Cisco on their protocol.

83
00:03:54.555 --> 00:03:57.535
Probably important for you to read up
on that if you're not familiar with it.

84
00:03:57.535 --> 00:04:02.220
Essentially a redundancy protocol that
we use for establishing gateways so

85
00:04:02.220 --> 00:04:04.580
that we can take a look at making
sure everything stays up and

86
00:04:04.580 --> 00:04:05.540
we're able to communicate with it.

87
00:04:05.540 --> 00:04:09.670
We don't lose the interaction we need
to be able to cross the gateway and

88
00:04:09.670 --> 00:04:12.120
be able to communicate with the device,
important for us.

89
00:04:13.240 --> 00:04:13.840
We're up to,

90
00:04:13.840 --> 00:04:17.030
if I'm not mistaken, version two of
the protocol if I remember correctly.

91
00:04:17.030 --> 00:04:23.390
Version one originally comes out
through RFC, wanna say 2281 if

92
00:04:23.390 --> 00:04:27.915
I remember correctly, and I know I'm
correct cuz it's in my notes right there.

93
00:04:27.915 --> 00:04:28.637
>> [LAUGH] It's right there.

94
00:04:28.637 --> 00:04:32.860
>> [LAUGH] But it's RFC 2281 that was
the original version of the protocol, and

95
00:04:32.860 --> 00:04:34.610
we have that ability to then
be able to set this up.

96
00:04:34.610 --> 00:04:37.690
So you probably wanna read up on that
just a little bit, you'll be able to find

97
00:04:37.690 --> 00:04:39.680
that information here,
I'll show it to you in just a second.

98
00:04:39.680 --> 00:04:43.000
But we've got this little primer here on
all the different capabilities we use,

99
00:04:43.000 --> 00:04:46.220
we could scroll through and
you could see how to get this going.

100
00:04:46.220 --> 00:04:49.450
We do have some required management
packs that have to be in place to drive

101
00:04:49.450 --> 00:04:50.180
Discovery.

102
00:04:50.180 --> 00:04:52.480
We've got
the Microsoft Windows Server Network and

103
00:04:52.480 --> 00:04:55.990
Client Network Discover Management packs,
we've talked extensively about to get

104
00:04:55.990 --> 00:04:59.380
those, where you get the from,
how to import them, what to do with them.

105
00:04:59.380 --> 00:05:01.940
So now you have all of that information.

106
00:05:01.940 --> 00:05:06.260
You may wanna also bring in older versions
of the operating system management packs

107
00:05:06.260 --> 00:05:12.420
to support older deployments, Server 2003,
Server 2008, Windows 7, Windows Vista.

108
00:05:12.420 --> 00:05:16.190
Notice by the way, Windows XP,
suspiciously absent there.

109
00:05:16.190 --> 00:05:19.940
Not suspiciously, because we no longer
support it, but do keep that in mind.

110
00:05:19.940 --> 00:05:25.200
But yet, even though we don't support 2003
anymore, cuz it also is out of warranty

111
00:05:25.200 --> 00:05:28.510
as we say, no longer sport officially,
and it's still on the active list because

112
00:05:28.510 --> 00:05:32.560
there's still so much of that deployed
in the server stacks, just so you know.

113
00:05:32.560 --> 00:05:34.020
That is still there for the moment.

114
00:05:34.020 --> 00:05:35.280
However, moving forward,

115
00:05:35.280 --> 00:05:39.290
moving into 2016 and beyond,
that stuff's going to go away over time.

116
00:05:39.290 --> 00:05:40.870
So keep that in mind and

117
00:05:40.870 --> 00:05:44.970
stay on that track to make sure you're
upgrading that infrastructure as required.

118
00:05:44.970 --> 00:05:47.310
We do have a little primer on how
Network Discovery works down here.

119
00:05:47.310 --> 00:05:49.930
We're going to take you through and
show a little bit of it here.

120
00:05:49.930 --> 00:05:52.500
I'll go a little deeper in the demo
we're going to do in a separate episode

121
00:05:52.500 --> 00:05:55.970
momentarily, but
you will be able to see it here and

122
00:05:55.970 --> 00:05:57.970
be able to see the information on it.

123
00:05:57.970 --> 00:06:01.580
If we are gonna go out and discover
network devices through opps managers,

124
00:06:01.580 --> 00:06:02.830
I'm gonna show you how to do.

125
00:06:02.830 --> 00:06:05.350
We have a little website here,
a little webpage again.

126
00:06:05.350 --> 00:06:07.400
That shows us some of
the basic information.

127
00:06:07.400 --> 00:06:09.480
How to set up our network devices,
discovery rule.

128
00:06:09.480 --> 00:06:11.510
I'm gonna walk you through
how to do this right now, and

129
00:06:11.510 --> 00:06:14.640
show you in the administration
workspace using discovery wizard

130
00:06:14.640 --> 00:06:15.560
how we actually do that.

131
00:06:15.560 --> 00:06:17.770
So we'll just take a look at the high
level, then we'll come back,

132
00:06:17.770 --> 00:06:19.090
we'll do a demo on that.

133
00:06:19.090 --> 00:06:23.970
We do have a hot standby router protocol
feature and functionality documentation.

134
00:06:23.970 --> 00:06:27.000
I promised you we'd put that up for
you just to show you where it is.

135
00:06:27.000 --> 00:06:29.820
We do have the URL for you in the show
notes on that so you can go and

136
00:06:29.820 --> 00:06:30.500
you can take a look.

137
00:06:30.500 --> 00:06:32.180
But we're gonna be able
to walk through and

138
00:06:32.180 --> 00:06:35.930
see all the information we need in order
to be able to figure out how this works.

139
00:06:35.930 --> 00:06:38.310
So let's go in real quick,
we'll take a look.

140
00:06:39.800 --> 00:06:41.710
Just minimize that, sorry about that.

141
00:06:41.710 --> 00:06:44.980
Let's go ahead and just take a look,
here inside the console, real quick.

142
00:06:44.980 --> 00:06:47.420
In the Admin work space,
Network Management,

143
00:06:47.420 --> 00:06:49.200
we do have our discovery rules here.

144
00:06:49.200 --> 00:06:50.460
Notice, we don't have any.

145
00:06:50.460 --> 00:06:53.610
Gonna right click, run the Discovery

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Adam show you how to deploy SCOM Agent configuration and discovery. They will demonstrate installation of the Operations Manager Agent on a computer as well as discover network devices in the Operations Manager.
episodes.title: SCOM Agent Configuration and Discovery

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Adam show you how to import an Operations Manager Management Pack from the catalogue. They quickly walk you through the steps of finding an Management Pack, downloading, and importing with the Ops Manager.
episodes.title: Import Ops Manager Management Pack

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Adam show you how to connect the Virtual Machine Manager(VMM) with the Ops Manager and enable Performance and Resource Optimization(PRO). They also demonstrate configuring SQL Server Analysis Service for VMM.
episodes.title: Linking VMM SCOM and PRO

on the left here, in the nav area.

379
00:19:38.760 --> 00:19:41.060
We're able to fill in some parameters so

380
00:19:41.060 --> 00:19:43.430
we can figure out how we wanna filter and
group.

381
00:19:43.430 --> 00:19:47.210
And then over here,
we're able to see issues and concerns.

382
00:19:47.210 --> 00:19:49.550
We're then able to drill down on these.

383
00:19:49.550 --> 00:19:51.568
Find information out by going through and

384
00:19:51.568 --> 00:19:55.208
essentially drilling through these
items and reading up more about them.

385
00:19:55.208 --> 00:19:59.760
And we could then go in and we can, based
on what we see, decide to take action.

386
00:19:59.760 --> 00:20:02.210
Or, whatever the case may be.

387
00:20:02.210 --> 00:20:04.930
So we can go in,
you'll see that it shows grouping

388
00:20:04.930 --> 00:20:07.265
application orders by
different functionally groups.

389
00:20:07.265 --> 00:20:09.290
You'll see here Computers, Applications,

390
00:20:09.290 --> 00:20:14.875
Events, Advisor, with different categories
and workspaces we can interact around.

391
00:20:14.875 --> 00:20:18.903
And so we're able to go in and
get detailed diagnostic

392
00:20:18.903 --> 00:20:23.838
information when we are using one
of these particular consoles.

393
00:20:23.838 --> 00:20:28.127
We can also prioritize alerts by
using the Application Advisor.

394
00:20:28.127 --> 00:20:32.325
So we can go in and say hey, these
particular alerts are gonna be important.

395
00:20:32.325 --> 00:20:33.407
Let's pay attention them.

396
00:20:33.407 --> 00:20:36.327
We can go ahead and
scope and run this report.

397
00:20:36.327 --> 00:20:39.613
Filter it in such a way that we're
able to tell exactly what it is

398
00:20:39.613 --> 00:20:40.676
we are looking for.

399
00:20:40.676 --> 00:20:44.207
And so when we do this, down here, oops.

400
00:20:44.207 --> 00:20:45.988
We can go through,
it's pretty straightforward.

401
00:20:45.988 --> 00:20:48.070
We don't have a pretty
picture on this one.

402
00:20:48.070 --> 00:20:52.651
But we can go in, we can use the console
to then be able to generate a list

403
00:20:52.651 --> 00:20:54.748
prioritized based on issues and

404
00:20:54.748 --> 00:20:58.334
concerns that we can then
create action items around.

405
00:20:58.334 --> 00:21:02.250
And then use either SCOM itself or
other tools associated with SCOM.

406
00:21:02.250 --> 00:21:04.920
I'm thinking service manager for instance.

407
00:21:04.920 --> 00:21:08.800
I'm thinking virtual machine manager for
private cloud fabric.

408
00:21:08.800 --> 00:21:11.140
And we can go in,
perhaps data protection manager,

409
00:21:11.140 --> 00:21:14.330
if we have an issue where we have to
ensure we have a backup going on.

410
00:21:14.330 --> 00:21:17.460
System Center config manager, if we
have to worry about doing a deployment

411
00:21:17.460 --> 00:21:21.100
of an application or a virtual machine or
something to that end.

412
00:21:21.100 --> 00:21:25.998
Whatever the case may be, we can go ahead
and we can use those to then be able

413
00:21:25.998 --> 00:21:30.355
to drill down and achieve more
focused remediation if required.

414
00:21:30.355 --> 00:21:33.170
We also have the ability to
be able to use IntelliTrace.

415
00:21:33.170 --> 00:21:37.010
So we'll talk about IntelliTrace,
couple of different areas.

416
00:21:37.010 --> 00:21:41.753
We talk about it specifically because
we can use IntelliTrace to collect and

417
00:21:41.753 --> 00:21:45.914
get debug logs from applications,
part of this thought process.

418
00:21:45.914 --> 00:21:50.466
And we can then throw those
over into Visual Studio.

419
00:21:50.466 --> 00:21:53.805
And we can use them in Visual Studio,

420
00:21:53.805 --> 00:21:59.208
through Visual Studio to TFS,
Team Foundation Services.

421
00:21:59.208 --> 00:22:02.526
And with Team Foundation Services,
or the TFS server,

422
00:22:02.526 --> 00:22:06.833
what we can do is we can create work
items for managing our dev cycles in our

423
00:22:06.833 --> 00:22:10.659
workflow in the dev environment,
out of the IntelliTrace log.

424
00:22:10.659 --> 00:22:14.278
So that we can actually use the debugging
to create the opportunity for

425
00:22:14.278 --> 00:22:18.580
us to then tell our dev team, hey, we
need to go in and deal with these issues.

426
00:22:18.580 --> 00:22:20.696
And so we can link these two together and

427
00:22:20.696 --> 00:22:23.722
this is again one of the strengths
of this kind of a tool.

428
00:22:23.722 --> 00:22:25.953
Because when we go in and we collect and

429
00:22:25.953 --> 00:22:30.647
you can see right here historical data
from System Center using IntelliTrace.

430
00:22:30.647 --> 00:22:34.090
We do have to turn this on and
it does have to be enabled.

431
00:22:34.090 --> 00:22:38.660
But once we've done this, we can take
this data and we can then have it spawn

432
00:22:38.660 --> 00:22:43.290
work items in our workflow for
us in our thought process on the dev side.

433
00:22:43.290 --> 00:22:44.940
This is essentially DevOps, right.

434
00:22:44.940 --> 00:22:48.590
This is what we do, we link the Dev and
the Ops environment together and

435
00:22:48.590 --> 00:22:50.290
this is our way of doing this.

436
00:22:50.290 --> 00:22:53.170
This is a very powerful
thought process here as well,

437
00:22:53.170 --> 00:22:55.414
because we can do historical profiling.

438
00:22:55.414 --> 00:22:59.352
Grab these snapshots and
then move them over to the dev team and

439
00:22:59.352 --> 00:23:02.240
give them the opportunity
to work with them.

440
00:23:02.240 --> 00:23:04.390
>> This is a really powerful tool, Adam.

441
00:23:04.390 --> 00:23:07.100
We're able to take and
remove the guesswork out of it.

442
00:23:07.100 --> 00:23:09.089
We're able to obtain quantitative data.

443
00:23:09.089 --> 00:23:14.169
And really get a clear overview and
as-is picture about what's going on,

444
00:23:14.169 --> 00:23:16.517
what issues need to be addressed.

445
00:23:16.517 --> 00:23:18.255
>> That was just me pausing for
a simple water while Cherokee was talking.

446
00:23:18.255 --> 00:23:19.124
>> Sorry.

447
00:23:19.124 --> 00:23:19.741
>> No problem.

448
00:23:19.741 --> 00:23:21.399
>> I should've given you
an extra second Adam [LAUGH].

449
00:23:21.399 --> 00:23:23.233
>> That's the magic behind
the scene you don't see,

450
00:23:23.233 --> 00:23:24.520
that's why we go to a small screen.

451
00:23:24.520 --> 00:23:27.843
If you saw the whole screen, you'd see
all the other people running around in

452
00:23:27.843 --> 00:23:31.490
the studio you never see that are back
behind us making all the magic happen.

453
00:23:31.490 --> 00:23:34.220
So yes, it is such a powerful tool.

454
00:23:34.220 --> 00:23:38.974
And it is the ability for us to be able
to really create an end to end, this is

455
00:23:38.974 --> 00:23:44.450
the thought process we have in end to end
service monitor for the lifecycle, right?

456
00:23:44.450 --> 00:23:47.645
And we're looking at not just
taking debug log information but

457
00:23:47.645 --> 00:23:49.337
real time performance metrics.

458
00:23:49.337 --> 00:23:53.881
And all sorts of data points together to
then be able to take this idea of APM,

459
00:23:53.881 --> 00:23:58.570
the application performance monitoring,
and use it to bracket and filter and

460
00:23:58.570 --> 00:24:01.870
then drive our discussions
around remediation.

461
00:24:01.870 --> 00:24:02.629
For web services.

462
00:24:02.629 --> 00:24:04.577
So it is a very valuable
thought process for us.

463
00:24:04.577 --> 00:24:09.390
One that we wanna make sure
we take maximum advantage of.

464
00:24:09.390 --> 00:24:12.320
How we can integrate
our operations manager,

465
00:24:12.320 --> 00:24:15.100
as I was saying,
with our dev thought processes here.

466
00:24:15.100 --> 00:24:17.370
It's kind of the last

467
00:24:17.370 --> 00:24:20.260
This idea of integrating with TFS,
as I suggested,

00:24:20.260 --> 00:24:25.050
we support this in TFS 2010,

469
00:24:25.050 --> 00:24:29.640
So the more recent versions, we're up

470
00:24:29.640 --> 00:24:31.720
But we do support interaction and

471
00:24:31.720 --> 00:24:35.940
integration with the platform out through
the most recent revs of these products.

472
00:24:35.940 --> 00:24:39.770
And we are linking System Center,
specifically Ops Manager, which really

473
00:24:39.770 --> 00:24:44.000
becomes the hub of communication and
information exchange outs.

474
00:24:44.000 --> 00:24:48.160
All of the peripheral elements, not
just of System Center, but of the other

00:24:48.160 --> 00:24:53.050
supporting products outside of System
Center like Visual Studio, like TFS.

476
00:24:53.050 --> 00:24:56.360
Some of you may not work in an environment
where you do a lot of internal dev.

477
00:24:56.360 --> 00:25:00.032
So you may not be in a big enough business
where you have your own internal app

00:25:00.032 --> 00:25:00.810

479
00:25:00.810 --> 00:25:03.030
You may outsource app
dev to another entity.

480
00:25:03.030 --> 00:25:04.890
That doesn't mean you can't

00:25:04.890 --> 00:25:07.600
it just means you may not have a need for

482
00:25:07.600 --> 00:25:10.980
If you're not in the hey,

00:25:10.980 --> 00:25:14.990
then APM just may not be technology

484
00:25:14.990 --> 00:25:17.760
But most of us without exception

00:25:17.760 --> 00:25:21.740

486
00:25:21.740 --> 00:25:22.850
The question is not so

488
00:25:26.270 --> 00:25:30.399
The question is, who's gonna do the

489
00:25:30.399 --> 00:25:31.500
In other words, right?

490
00:25:31.500 --> 00:25:36.780
Because if we're hosting this in Azure,

00:25:36.780 --> 00:25:41.240

a Microsoft Center Solution, that's okay.

492
00:25:41.240 --> 00:25:44.210
There is a world outside of Microsoft,

493
00:25:44.210 --> 00:25:46.810
Wherever you're hosting
your web applications,

494
00:25:46.810 --> 00:25:50.680
that vendor has to provide this

495
00:25:50.680 --> 00:25:56.860
We've talked about, in other episodes,

496
00:25:56.860 --> 00:26:01.651
And the ability to use essentially your

00:26:01.651 --> 00:26:03.050

498
00:26:03.050 --> 00:26:06.610
Either from the user fabric
down into your private cloud,

00:26:06.610 --> 00:26:09.240
if you're hybrid hosting in both places.

500
00:26:09.240 --> 00:26:13.140
From your on-prem into the cloud,
if you're hosting with Microsoft but

501
00:26:13.140 --> 00:26:15.620
maintain monitoring
infrastructure on-prem.

502
00:26:15.620 --> 00:26:20.010
Or if you're doing private cloud,
only monitor on-prem yourself.

503
00:26:20.010 --> 00:26:23.240
Well we've talked about the ability
to use the Azure fabric and

504
00:26:23.240 --> 00:26:26.050

505
00:26:26.050 --> 00:26:30.290
Azure Analytics and
Azure Log Data Monitoring and

506
00:26:30.290 --> 00:26:34.405
Azure Recovery and all of the different
things we went through in that discussion.

507
00:26:34.405 --> 00:26:36.710
There's a lot of value in
leveraging the web today.

508
00:26:36.710 --> 00:26:40.230
And it's not just about,
I need to install, have it local and

509
00:26:40.230 --> 00:26:41.300
that's all I do anymore.

510
00:26:41.300 --> 00:26:43.750
It's about, where is my data?

511
00:26:43.750 --> 00:26:45.320
Where are my applications?

512
00:26:45.320 --> 00:26:47.050
How am I gonna monitor them and

513
00:26:47.050 --> 00:26:50.000
how am I gonna understand
what's happening with them.

514
00:26:50.000 --> 00:26:52.960
So you gotta figure out ultimately
what the best approach is.

515
00:26:52.960 --> 00:26:56.260
And it may not be
System Center Ops Manager on-prem,

516
00:26:56.260 --> 00:27:00.310
isolated running a privately
hosted private cloud on-prem.

517
00:27:00.310 --> 00:27:03.740
You may very well today have a private
cloud that's hosted by a third-party

518
00:27:03.740 --> 00:27:05.550

519
00:27:05.550 --> 00:27:08.480
You could still use these tools
to monitor into the cloud.

520
00:27:08.480 --> 00:27:10.880
We talked about the usual
management packs and

521
00:27:10.880 --> 00:27:14.850
the integration of the Azure fabric
into your monitoring solution.

522
00:27:14.850 --> 00:27:18.240
This concept with APM is just
another ripple in that fabric,

523
00:27:18.240 --> 00:27:21.800
another extension of
that monitoring out and

524
00:27:21.800 --> 00:27:25.320
taking advantage of the web and
web-related application services.

525
00:27:25.320 --> 00:27:27.470
Just a matter of how you
choose to approach that.

526
00:27:27.470 --> 00:27:29.098
>> Well thank you Adam for
taking the time to explain.

527
00:27:29.098 --> 00:27:31.780
I now know what application
performance monitoring is, and

528
00:27:31.780 --> 00:27:34.850
I really just can't wait to get
some hands-on demonstration here.

529
00:27:34.850 --> 00:27:38.620
So ladies and gentlemen, stay tuned,
we have more information headed your way.

530
00:27:38.620 --> 00:27:40.510
But for this show we're gonna go ahead and
sign off.

531
00:27:40.510 --> 00:27:41.980
I'm Cherokee Boose.

532
00:27:41.980 --> 00:27:43.080
>> That would be me.

533
00:27:43.080 --> 00:27:47.500
I'm not Cherokee Boose, but I am wearing a
very bright lovely, from what I was told.

534
00:27:47.500 --> 00:27:48.530
>> Yes!
>> Lovely,

535
00:27:48.530 --> 00:27:51.867
lovely bright shirt which
makes me Mister Lovely.

536
00:27:51.867 --> 00:27:54.703
>> [LAUGH] See you next time here ITProTV.

537
00:27:54.703 --> 00:27:55.808
Bye.

538
00:27:55.808 --> 00:27:56.349
>> Take care everybody.

539
00:27:56.349 --> 00:28:03.401
[MUSIC]

00:28:03.401 --> 00:28:06.047
>> Thank you for watching ITProTV.

episodes.description: In this show, Cherokee and Adam thumb-wrestle to determine who will demonstrate how to use Application Performance Monitoring (APM) to monitor new applications.

1.1 is what I meant to say on HTTP.

347
00:16:18.495 --> 00:16:23.315
We can look at the HTTP method GET, HEAD,
POST and program in information for

348
00:16:23.315 --> 00:16:24.335
each of those.

349
00:16:24.335 --> 00:16:29.005
And then we also have information that we
could specify down here about the HTTP

350
00:16:29.005 --> 00:16:32.005
headers and how we're gonna deal with
them and what headers we want to see.

351
00:16:32.005 --> 00:16:33.850
So this is very detailed.

352
00:16:33.850 --> 00:16:36.590
Very, very detailed
diagnostics in here right?

353
00:16:36.590 --> 00:16:40.490
So it's interesting that we have
the ability to really detail out and

354
00:16:40.490 --> 00:16:45.200
spec out almost every aspect of
the interaction across the web server

355
00:16:45.200 --> 00:16:49.850
divide here from the monitor to watch
your node to the web server and back and

356
00:16:49.850 --> 00:16:51.630
then draw down all that data.

357
00:16:51.630 --> 00:16:53.840
So this is actually a really, really and

358
00:16:53.840 --> 00:16:56.238
I'm going to use a very
highly technical term here.

359
00:16:56.238 --> 00:16:56.748
Right?

360
00:16:56.748 --> 00:16:57.258
Nifty.

361
00:16:57.258 --> 00:17:00.080
>> [LAUGH]
>> This is a very nifty

362
00:17:00.080 --> 00:17:01.610
feature that we have.

363
00:17:01.610 --> 00:17:05.700
So it is really kind of cool that
we have the ability to do GSM,

364
00:17:05.700 --> 00:17:07.580
Global Service Monitoring, now.

365
00:17:07.580 --> 00:17:11.350
Because this is one of the big
competitive landscape points for

366
00:17:11.350 --> 00:17:14.580
Microsoft and the system center stack,
and the ops manager stack.

367
00:17:14.580 --> 00:17:17.390
There's a lot of other products,
you've heard me talk about them in some

368
00:17:17.390 --> 00:17:19.410
other episodes,
in other areas in the show.

369
00:17:20.610 --> 00:17:25.020
Things like HP OpenView, IBM Tivoli,
SolarWinds, the Orion product,

370
00:17:25.020 --> 00:17:27.630
all sorts of different products out
there that essentially do this, and

371
00:17:27.630 --> 00:17:29.090
specialize in doing this.

372
00:17:29.090 --> 00:17:31.350
And we do it too, and we do it very well.

373
00:17:31.350 --> 00:17:34.600
So being able to delve into this feature
a little bit and see it is helpful,

374
00:17:34.600 --> 00:17:37.330
especially if you haven't really
had to set this up yourself or

375
00:17:37.330 --> 00:17:40.290
don't understand the capabilities of this.

376
00:17:40.290 --> 00:17:45.160
This is really under the hood a very
valuable set of tests that we can run and

377
00:17:45.160 --> 00:17:47.570
very valuable information we
can get back as a result.

378
00:17:47.570 --> 00:17:49.120
So we're gonna finish out here.

379
00:17:49.120 --> 00:17:50.110
We're gonna leave this here.

380
00:17:50.110 --> 00:17:51.900
We're gonna click Next.

381
00:17:51.900 --> 00:17:53.830
We're then just gonna
get our summary screen.

382
00:17:53.830 --> 00:17:56.780
As I've told you in other episodes,
I'll remind you of this here,

383
00:17:56.780 --> 00:18:00.030
It's always a good idea to capture
the information on the summary screen for

384
00:18:00.030 --> 00:18:02.660
documentation purposes, a screen capture,

385
00:18:02.660 --> 00:18:06.010
a picture, do a little selfie,
do one of these camera, right there.

386
00:18:06.010 --> 00:18:09.490
I can actually do it face on because I'm
standing there, so we'll just pretend.

387
00:18:09.490 --> 00:18:12.560
Tend to take a picture,
let me get it in frame, click, right?

388
00:18:12.560 --> 00:18:13.790
So you have that and

389
00:18:13.790 --> 00:18:18.340
then with that you can put that into your
documentation so you've got an exact

390
00:18:18.340 --> 00:18:21.010
reproduction of what the settings
were when you configure this thing,

391
00:18:21.010 --> 00:18:23.990
very important for you to think about
that and make sure you're doing that.

392
00:18:23.990 --> 00:18:24.950
We're gonna click create.

393
00:18:26.170 --> 00:18:28.100
Give that just a minute to come up.

394
00:18:28.100 --> 00:18:31.650
And then when this done,
we'll have our monitor.

395
00:18:31.650 --> 00:18:34.790
It will show up, and we'll, again, we may
have to refresh to get it to be there.

396
00:18:34.790 --> 00:18:36.120
But trust me, it will be there.

397
00:18:36.120 --> 00:18:38.500
But we can go in, and
we'll have this available.

398
00:18:38.500 --> 00:18:42.770
And we'll just go ahead and we'll refresh
here real quick, to get this in there.

399
00:18:42.770 --> 00:18:44.260
Just give it a second.

400
00:18:44.260 --> 00:18:47.410
And then once we do that, there we go.

401
00:18:47.410 --> 00:18:49.420
There's our web monitor right there.

402
00:18:49.420 --> 00:18:52.710
Then we will have it available, and
then we'll be able to go ahead and

403
00:18:52.710 --> 00:18:54.950
deploy this and actually use this, right?

404
00:18:54.950 --> 00:19:01.125
So, this will then allow us to be able to
go in and ultimately check our web status.

405
00:19:01.125 --> 00:19:02.675
Right?
We'll be able to go in,

406
00:19:02.675 --> 00:19:06.745
and we'll be able to go to monitoring
up under the web application so we'll

407
00:19:06.745 --> 00:19:11.015
transition over here, see the output of
this, essentially see where it goes live.

408
00:19:11.015 --> 00:19:13.725
We go in here,
we'll go into application monitoring.

409
00:19:13.725 --> 00:19:18.530
We went in here when we were doing
the .NET setup in the .NET framework

410
00:19:18.530 --> 00:19:21.670
transaction template and
doing APM, we went in and

411
00:19:21.670 --> 00:19:23.590
showed you what the output
would look like here.

412
00:19:23.590 --> 00:19:26.670
It's gonna be the same idea, we're
gonna go up under web applications, so

413
00:19:26.670 --> 00:19:28.935
let's just scroll down here real quick,
and

414
00:19:28.935 --> 00:19:31.575
we've got our web application
availability monitoring.

415
00:19:31.575 --> 00:19:33.265
We did our .NET monitoring last time,

416
00:19:33.265 --> 00:19:37.115
and you'll see we can go in
under web application status.

417
00:19:37.115 --> 00:19:40.143
And eventually, we'll get our status
to update, and then remember,

418
00:19:40.143 --> 00:19:41.875
it takes a little bit of time.

419
00:19:41.875 --> 00:19:46.405
I preloaded the application when we did
the .NET application monitoring demo.

420
00:19:46.405 --> 00:19:47.545
So we actually had it run for

421
00:19:47.545 --> 00:19:50.980
about 20 minutes behind the scenes,
before we actually brought it out and

422
00:19:50.980 --> 00:19:54.580
showed it to you so you actually
would be able to see some status.

423
00:19:54.580 --> 00:19:56.750
But eventually we will get a status here,

424
00:19:56.750 --> 00:19:59.620
we'll be able to see the state
test status as well.

425
00:19:59.620 --> 00:20:02.890
If there are any active alerts,
we won't have any right now but

426
00:20:02.890 --> 00:20:05.660
eventually, if we do have anything
we'll be able to see them.

427
00:20:05.660 --> 00:20:10.210
But over time we will be able to get this
up and running, and it will show up,

428
00:20:10.210 --> 00:20:14.160
and we will see our monitor or
our application running there.

429
00:20:14.160 --> 00:20:15.990
Our web application status will show up.

430
00:20:15.990 --> 00:20:19.260
Hopefully it will show up as healthy
once it spins up and starts running.

431
00:20:19.260 --> 00:20:22.840
And then once we have that up and
running, we're able to go in and look at

432
00:20:22.840 --> 00:20:28.870
the diagram view on it if we choose to,
so we actually can go in and we can,

433
00:20:28.870 --> 00:20:32.800
let me just see if we can refresh one more
time, see if we can get that in there.

434
00:20:32.800 --> 00:20:35.040
See the Web App Monitor's
starting to build but

435
00:20:35.040 --> 00:20:38.220
it's gonna take time to come online and
actually be available to us.

436
00:20:38.220 --> 00:20:41.200
But in the meantime, what we could do
because we at least have it up and

437
00:20:41.200 --> 00:20:43.610
running now in the sense
that it's out there,

438
00:20:43.610 --> 00:20:47.040
we can either go over here to
the right to our diagram view.

439
00:20:47.040 --> 00:20:49.500
I want to show the diagram view
in the .NET APM monitor remember?

440
00:20:49.500 --> 00:20:51.170
You were pretty excited about that.

441
00:20:51.170 --> 00:20:52.700
>> Yes.
>> That was the interactive diagram.

442
00:20:52.700 --> 00:20:54.160
We'll show that again here.

443
00:20:54.160 --> 00:20:55.020
Same idea.

444
00:20:55.020 --> 00:20:57.810
This is one of the benefits
we get from linking this

445
00:20:57.810 --> 00:21:01.290
to our default management pack, we have
all these objects already built out and

446
00:21:01.290 --> 00:21:05.440
we're then able to use them as we set
up the monitor and start to deploy it.

447
00:21:05.440 --> 00:21:09.480
So all the objects from the management
pack like these views are then

448
00:21:09.480 --> 00:21:10.860
available to us to actually deploy.

449
00:21:10.860 --> 00:21:12.270
>> Nice.
>> Which is one of the values, right?

450
00:21:12.270 --> 00:21:12.840
>> Yeah.

451
00:21:12.840 --> 00:21:14.990
>> So we're gonna right-click
here just to show this to you.

452
00:21:14.990 --> 00:21:17.480
We did do the Health Explorer
in our last demo.

453
00:21:17.480 --> 00:21:20.580
I'm not gonna walk through that
whole thing again, but the idea was

454
00:21:20.580 --> 00:21:23.040
that we'll then, and we're not gonna have
any data in the Health Explorer right now.

455
00:21:23.040 --> 00:21:24.670
We're still spinning up the monitor.

456
00:21:24.670 --> 00:21:28.385
But eventually we will get the ability to
walk through all the state changes and

457
00:21:28.385 --> 00:21:31.205
look at information about
how healthy we are over

458
00:21:31.205 --> 00:21:32.505
a period of time with Health Explorer.

459
00:21:32.505 --> 00:21:35.295
So that's gonna be very important for
us to think about.

460
00:21:35.295 --> 00:21:38.595
We do have the ability to run our reports,
and by the way, these report tasks,

461
00:21:38.595 --> 00:21:41.877
can we go full screen for a minute so
we can see what's behind my bot?

462
00:21:41.877 --> 00:21:46.247
These report tabs right here are the same
ones that are sitting over here right.

463
00:21:46.247 --> 00:21:47.787
>> What's a different way to access them?

464
00:21:47.787 --> 00:21:50.567
>> Same way to get to them just a matter
of where you want to see them from.

465
00:21:50.567 --> 00:21:53.241
>> Cool.
>> But all of this stuff here is the same

466
00:21:53.241 --> 00:21:56.257
as over here and
if we go to navigation and

467
00:21:56.257 --> 00:22:00.278
see the views,
all those views right there, right?

468
00:22:00.278 --> 00:22:01.323
So we're going to bring up,

469
00:22:01.323 --> 00:22:03.590
let me just refresh one more
time to see if we have it.

470
00:22:03.590 --> 00:22:06.250
Another status update
before we do anything else.

471
00:22:06.250 --> 00:22:08.030
It's starting to go,
it went from gray to green.

472
00:22:08.030 --> 00:22:09.570
Now you may not be able to see that, but

473
00:22:09.570 --> 00:22:13.360
the circle's now green which means it's
initializing, so we're getting data.

474
00:22:13.360 --> 00:22:16.030
Eventually we'll get a green
check there that says healthy.

475
00:22:16.030 --> 00:22:19.000
But we can go in and
we can do our diagram view.

476
00:22:20.210 --> 00:22:23.490
And when we do this,
we will then see our web app monitor, and

477
00:22:23.490 --> 00:22:25.740
we've got our interactive diagram.

478
00:22:25.740 --> 00:22:28.960
There's no status there yet, because
again, the monitor's still spinning up,

479
00:22:28.960 --> 00:22:32.850
but over time,
we will be able to go in and see.

480
00:22:32.850 --> 00:22:36.510
Now we saw the green status go on
the circle there, the top circle went to

481
00:22:36.510 --> 00:22:41.270
green, as I said a moment ago,
shows us that the monitor's initializing.

482
00:22:41.270 --> 00:22:43.480
It's not healthy or unhealthy yet,
it's just turning on.

483
00:22:43.480 --> 00:22:46.610
But this stuff once you deploy it,
takes about 20 to 30 minutes,

484
00:22:46.610 --> 00:22:50.740
maybe even longer depending on what kind
of monitoring you're doing to come online.

485
00:22:50.740 --> 00:22:51.930
So you do have to be patient.

486
00:22:51.930 --> 00:22:53.438
It's not gonna happen right away and

487
00:22:53.438 --> 00:22:55.990
it will not happen during
the course of our demo fully.

488
00:22:55.990 --> 00:22:58.390
We're just showing you the outline
of how to set this up.

489
00:22:58.390 --> 00:23:03.520
But over time, this will come online and
over time we then will be able to monitor.

490
00:23:03.520 --> 00:23:06.700
And if you look we have MSM there,
we have ITPro.TV.

491
00:23:06.700 --> 00:23:09.970
Every one of our URLs is
set up as its own instance.

492
00:23:09.970 --> 00:23:12.510
We have our web app monitor information.

493
00:23:12.510 --> 00:23:15.660
And all of this essentially will
now be monitored and come online.

494
00:23:15.660 --> 00:23:19.050
We'll be able to see the status of it and
interact with it along the way.

495
00:23:19.050 --> 00:23:20.140
Okay?

496
00:23:20.140 --> 00:23:23.230
>> Well folks there you have it,
web application availability

497
00:23:23.230 --> 00:23:26.050
monitoring brought to you by
the distinguished Adam Gordon.

498
00:23:26.050 --> 00:23:29.250
So thank you so much Adam for
being here today and thank you ladies and

499
00:23:29.250 --> 00:23:30.130
gentlemen for tuning in.

500
00:23:30.130 --> 00:23:32.960
But stay tuned we have more
information headed your way.

501
00:23:32.960 --> 00:23:36.610
For this show I'll go ahead and sign out
as your host, remember I'm Cherokee Boose.

502
00:23:36.610 --> 00:23:37.770
>> I'm the distinguished-
>> [LAUGH]

503
00:23:37.770 --> 00:23:39.040
>> Adam Gordon apparently, but

504
00:23:39.040 --> 00:23:41.285
it's always a pleasure to
be with you nonetheless.

505
00:23:41.285 --> 00:23:42.957
Take care everybody,
come back and see us soon.

506
00:23:42.957 --> 00:23:45.011
>> Bye.

507
00:23:45.011 --> 00:23:50.645
[MUSIC]

508
00:23:50.645 --> 00:23:53.699
>> Thank you for watching, ITProTV.

episodes.description: In this show, watch Adam explain how to view distributed applications.
episodes.title: Viewing Distributed Applications
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.008 --> 00:00:03.608
Welcome to ITProTV, I'm your host,
Don Pezet [CROSSTALK]

2
00:00:03.608 --> 00:00:06.532
>> [CROSSTALK]

3
00:00:06.532 --> 00:00:08.196
[MUSIC]

4
00:00:08.196 --> 00:00:11.893
>> You're watching ITProTV.

5
00:00:11.893 --> 00:00:13.590
>> Welcome, ladies and gentlemen,

6
00:00:13.590 --> 00:00:16.970
to your Datacenter Monitoring
with Microsoft SCOM series.

7
00:00:16.970 --> 00:00:18.790
I'm your show host, Cherokee Boose.

8
00:00:18.790 --> 00:00:22.460
In this episode,
we'll be viewing distributed applications.

9
00:00:22.460 --> 00:00:25.200
And with us today, we have Mr.
Adam Gordon in studios.

10
00:00:25.200 --> 00:00:26.980
Thank you for joining us today, Adam.

11
00:00:26.980 --> 00:00:27.792
>> Hello.

12
00:00:27.792 --> 00:00:28.400
>> Hello.

13
00:00:28.400 --> 00:00:32.702
>> Hello, so we're gonna continue our
conversations around showing you different

14
00:00:32.702 --> 00:00:35.758
aspects of the System Center Ops Manager
capabilities for

15
00:00:35.758 --> 00:00:37.930
monitoring application health.

16
00:00:37.930 --> 00:00:39.220
We've taken a look at APM.

17
00:00:39.220 --> 00:00:40.873
We've talked about inside out and

18
00:00:40.873 --> 00:00:44.243
outside in transaction monitoring
with global service monitoring.

19
00:00:44.243 --> 00:00:47.968
We've taken a look at and talked about
how to deal with event notifications,

20
00:00:47.968 --> 00:00:49.127
alert notifications.

21
00:00:49.127 --> 00:00:52.610
How we do Run As Accounts,
Run As Profiles and deal with that.

22
00:00:52.610 --> 00:00:56.650
We're gonna now put the capstone in place,
talk about distributed applications.

23
00:00:56.650 --> 00:01:00.325
How we can diagram out or
essentially create a visual reference for

24
00:01:00.325 --> 00:01:03.680
our application stack and
then monitor against that stack.

25
00:01:03.680 --> 00:01:05.390
So we're gonna start off in the console.

26
00:01:05.390 --> 00:01:09.991
Take a look here if you don't mind
joining me over here in the left wing of

27
00:01:09.991 --> 00:01:12.072
the ITProTV demo environment.

28
00:01:12.072 --> 00:01:13.546
I've already gone ahead and

29
00:01:13.546 --> 00:01:17.320
created an app we can just look at
first just to show you some things.

30
00:01:17.320 --> 00:01:18.810
We'll then go ahead and go back and

31
00:01:18.810 --> 00:01:22.840
show you how to create this using
distributed application wizard.

32
00:01:22.840 --> 00:01:26.493
But we call this distributed
app ITProTV Test App 1.

33
00:01:26.493 --> 00:01:31.360
You can see we've opened up or
exploded out our diagram.

34
00:01:31.360 --> 00:01:34.446
This is like that network diagram
view that we've looked at in some of

35
00:01:34.446 --> 00:01:37.795
the other episodes where we've looked
at the health status monitoring and

36
00:01:37.795 --> 00:01:39.941
the update in real time
around those elements.

37
00:01:39.941 --> 00:01:42.016
And this is gonna be the same idea.

38
00:01:42.016 --> 00:01:45.560
And we'll see underneath here,
I've added in two elements.

39
00:01:45.560 --> 00:01:47.680
One that's called All Computers.

40
00:01:47.680 --> 00:01:51.632
And I have All Windows computers
as objects listed here that I can

41
00:01:51.632 --> 00:01:52.519
monitor for.

42
00:01:52.519 --> 00:01:54.349
I have an object called Server, and

43
00:01:54.349 --> 00:01:57.590
I've added a specific instance
of a Windows server here.

44
00:01:57.590 --> 00:02:00.500
And when I hover,
what you will notice is we get a pop out.

45
00:02:00.500 --> 00:02:01.420
And I'll select this,

46
00:02:01.420 --> 00:02:05.230
and that information will show up at
the bottom pane in just a minute.

47
00:02:05.230 --> 00:02:09.800
But I get a pop out hover indicates that,
hey, I wanna know some information.

48
00:02:09.800 --> 00:02:13.420
And when I do that, if I can get it to do
that again, I get this nice little pop out

49
00:02:13.420 --> 00:02:16.990
box that gives me all the information
about the object in question.

50
00:02:16.990 --> 00:02:19.130
But it's only there for
about ten seconds, hard to read.

51
00:02:19.130 --> 00:02:20.692
So if you highlight that,

52
00:02:20.692 --> 00:02:24.249
all that information shows up
down here in the lower third.

53
00:02:24.249 --> 00:02:27.826
Now we could see the name,
the Display Name, Principal Name, DNS,

54
00:02:27.826 --> 00:02:30.110
the NET.BIOS Name, the IP Address.

55
00:02:30.110 --> 00:02:33.160
All the information about
this object is here.

56
00:02:33.160 --> 00:02:37.000
The Network Name,
we have the Active Directory information,

57
00:02:37.000 --> 00:02:38.520
if it's domain joined.

58
00:02:38.520 --> 00:02:44.090
We have the number of logical processors
and physical processors available here.

59
00:02:44.090 --> 00:02:45.950
We have quite a bit of information.

60
00:02:45.950 --> 00:02:49.450
If it is a virtual machine,
we can tell that it's a virtual machine.

61
00:02:49.450 --> 00:02:53.030
All that stuff would be available to us,
so all of that is here.

62
00:02:53.030 --> 00:02:56.270
In addition, on these diagrams,
they are fully interactive.

63
00:02:56.270 --> 00:03:01.124
We can go in,
we can open up any of the views.

64
00:03:01.124 --> 00:03:02.349
Can we go full-screen just so

65
00:03:02.349 --> 00:03:05.540
we can this as it pops out cuz it's kind
of hidden behind me a little bit there.

episodes.description: Watch Adam and Cherokee discuss several Source Management Pack Templates. They review some of the concrpts covered in previous episodes such as distributed applications  and global service while previewing new concepts such as configuration overrides and synthetic transaction web monitoring. Lastly, toy will learn about real-time Visio Dashboards and the way they integrate many System Center features.

Down here, about halfway,

00:23:51.809 --> 00:23:56.614

Japan, so they're in every major region.

00:23:59.384 --> 00:23:59.932
>> A good representation there.

00:23:59.932 --> 00:24:03.919

so you can subscribe in.

But you're then gonna be able to leverage

00:24:20.882 --> 00:24:22.720

We're taking advantage of the Azure

So there's a little bit of work you gotta

So we've had this ability to do

00:26:02.580 --> 00:26:06.810

With the SharePoint 2010

So one of the key value propositions

As a result of that and allows us then to

The biggest thing you gotta remember here

episodes.description: Cherokee and Adam break down a step-by-step demonstration to configure overrides. Tune in to learn how to use one of the many integrated overrides or create you own custom ones.

And an override exactly as

Whatever the monitoring is cuz we're

Whatever the monitoring

We're gonna put on top of what that

And then, we're going to apply that

31

So I'm gonna invite you to sit back,

So, what I've done is we've gone into

We're still in the authoring area because

00:01:41.570 --> 00:01:46.800
have to configure, change, modify, apply,

the templates that exist for
monitoring are gonna be taking place.

37

And so, we've been in and
out of here doing demonstrations for you,

have a whole bunch of episodes, where

Distributed applications, we created

we used that to be able to do

But now,
what we're gonna do is take a look,

Remember, all the things that go into

pack objects, and so
we got a list of them here.

We've got attributes,
we've got monitors, we've got overrides,

48
00:02:24.685 --> 00:02:29.170
object discoveries, rules, Service
Level Tracking, all that kind of stuff.

49
00:02:29.170 --> 00:02:30.820
We're gonna look at monitors,

50
00:02:31.890 --> 00:02:34.960
I've come in, I've gone to the computer

00:02:34.960 --> 00:02:38.040
in where I can choose what kind

00:02:38.040 --> 00:02:41.241
So, the computer category, Entity Health,

So, I'm just gonna Highlight

00:02:43.645 --> 00:02:45.175
This is what we're gonna use.

00:02:45.175 --> 00:02:49.034
And we're going to, you could see,

00:02:49.034 --> 00:02:50.950

00:02:50.950 --> 00:02:54.710
And then, we have the ability to disable
the monitor, that would be an override,

00:02:56.777 --> 00:02:58.367
We don't really call that an override.

Disabling is just that, disabling.

00:03:10.231 --> 00:03:12.900
And we classified that
differently than overriding.

00:03:12.900 --> 00:03:15.120
So we also have override the monitor.

66
00:03:15.120 --> 00:03:17.594
Keep the monitor on but
make the change in some way.

67
00:03:17.594 --> 00:03:20.960

00:03:24.510 --> 00:03:27.050

Can we go full screen, just so

While we're talking you'll see

00:03:39.450 --> 00:03:41.390
This would be a specific computer.

difference between them, right?

So, we wanna make sure

We're gonna choose for a group.

80
00:03:56.260 --> 00:03:59.070
We'll go in and then we'll search for

81
00:03:59.070 --> 00:04:02.840
You can see that we have
a whole list of items

that are going to be considered groups.

83

Categories of different computers

00:15:33.080 --> 00:15:35.650
A apps manager pack overrider or whatever.

312
00:15:35.650 --> 00:15:39.720
These are all the management packs
that are unsealed that we can store

313
00:15:39.720 --> 00:15:40.840
our overrides in.

314
00:15:40.840 --> 00:15:41.940
So we create a new one.

315
00:15:41.940 --> 00:15:46.320
It's easier for us to then bind to that or
we can use one of the existing ones.

316
00:15:46.320 --> 00:15:49.860
Now, the default management pack is
considered an unsealed management pack,

317
00:15:49.860 --> 00:15:51.110
we could store stuff there.

318
00:15:51.110 --> 00:15:53.608
But, we also have the one
specific to overrides,

319
00:15:53.608 --> 00:15:57.310
client monitoring override management
pack, the one I selected first.

320
00:15:57.310 --> 00:15:59.859
And we can do either one of those or
create our own, and

321
00:15:59.859 --> 00:16:02.700
then we just name it accordingly,
you know what it is.

322
00:16:02.700 --> 00:16:08.150
So it is up to us to decide ultimately,
whether or not we want to use the specific

323
00:16:08.150 --> 00:16:13.590
management pack or once we figure out what
management pack, we want to be able to do.

324
00:16:13.590 --> 00:16:16.950
We'll go ahead,
we can enable this, set it up.

325
00:16:16.950 --> 00:16:21.480
Specify it is gonna be true and then turn
on whatever other options we may want.

326
00:16:21.480 --> 00:16:24.130
And we're off to the races and
we're set to go, okay.

327
00:16:24.130 --> 00:16:26.660
So, just keep that in mind.

328
00:16:26.660 --> 00:16:29.730
We are not going to save our changes
'cuz we don't care about that one.

329
00:16:29.730 --> 00:16:31.400
And that's how we would
create an override.

330
00:16:31.400 --> 00:16:34.280
We'll just keep going through that
creating as many overrides as we need.

331
00:16:34.280 --> 00:16:36.392
>> All right configuring overrides 101.

332
00:16:36.392 --> 00:16:37.569
Thank you so much, Adam,

333
00:16:37.569 --> 00:16:40.520
for showing us how to walk through
that step-by-step process.

334
00:16:40.520 --> 00:16:42.260
And thank you ladies and
gentlemen for tuning in.

335
00:16:42.260 --> 00:16:42.954
But stay tuned.

336
00:16:42.954 --> 00:16:45.224
We have more demonstrations
headed your way.

337
00:16:45.224 --> 00:16:46.590
For this show,
we'll go ahead and sign out.

338
00:16:46.590 --> 00:16:48.230
Remember, I'm Cherokee Boose.

339
00:16:48.230 --> 00:16:49.298
>> And I'm Adam Gordon.

340
00:16:49.298 --> 00:16:51.968
>> See you next time here at ITPRO.TV.

341
00:16:51.968 --> 00:16:57.648
[MUSIC]

342
00:16:57.648 --> 00:17:00.985
>> Thank you for watching ITPRO.TV.

episodes.description: SCOM  6-3 Synthetic Transaction Web Monitoring In this show, Adam walks through the steps ho use synthetic transaction monitoring to monitor a web site URL.

16

So Cherokee did a great job,

And I demoed and

But then I specified that little check box
there in the corner that we're not gonna

00:01:14.370 --> 00:01:15.919
We're gonna take a look at that right now,

Cuz they always stay put, and therefore,

34
00:01:35.319 --> 00:01:36.526
>> [LAUGH]
>> Okay,

You can see this down on the bottom,

We have to now provide a name,

We'll call this Test Web App, Monitor.

And then select our management pack,

Come on, there we go,

Now I've gone ahead, and

We're using this in the test environment.

64

65

66

>> No, I wasn't lying,
you don't have to type that for real.

67

So this, we're gonna go to the localhost,

cuz we are paying homage to the absolute

69
00:03:19.348 --> 00:03:22.520
And then we're gonna do Microsoft.System
Monitoring ViewFolder.Root.

70
00:03:22.520 --> 00:03:26.060
This is gonna allow us to do just some

71
00:03:26.060 --> 00:03:27.000
and understand it.

72

So we're using this merely for

73

In the real word, just let me

In the real world, let me just
paste while we're talking as well,

75
00:03:38.715 --> 00:03:45.330
you would wanna go ahead and you would
wanna be able to actually use a website.

00:03:45.330 --> 00:03:48.750
That is going to, or
a web application, I should say,

77
00:03:48.750 --> 00:03:51.460
against the website that you

78

This is us essentially just setting up a

to demo for you, but this is not what you

In the real world, you would actually

And you would use that url here,

to actually then run the test again.

84

So we're gonna test this to

85
00:04:15.080 --> 00:04:17.536
I've already tested it, so

86

So we're gonna just wait for this to come

00:04:21.260 --> 00:04:21.818
It will then come back.

88
00:04:21.818 --> 00:04:24.960
It will show us just the output here.

89

Show us that we are successful.

You can see it there.

00:04:28.270 --> 00:04:30.480
Boy, that would've been so

92

And they're like, yeah,

00:04:31.180 --> 00:04:34.740
we're gonna show you, you tested it,
boop, not gonna happen, right?

But luckily-

95
00:04:35.603 --> 00:04:36.590
>> It happens.

96
00:04:36.590 --> 00:04:39.080
It does, sometimes,
more often than we care to admit.

97
00:04:39.080 --> 00:04:43.230
But you'll see here we do, or
we are successful, you'll see.

And let's just zoom in or

We'll go back, we talked about response

00:04:48.870 --> 00:04:52.290

00:04:52.290 --> 00:04:57.186
And we talked about the different

102
00:04:57.186 --> 00:04:59.870
>> Right.
>> Maybe custom codes that would be there.

103
00:04:59.870 --> 00:05:03.560
So you could see the response code 200

104
00:05:03.560 --> 00:05:04.870
I was able to connect.

105
00:05:04.870 --> 00:05:09.110
You'll see DNS resolution time,
about 1.3 milliseconds,

106
00:05:09.110 --> 00:05:12.660
total response time, about 7,
almost 8 milliseconds.

107
00:05:12.660 --> 00:05:15.740
So you could see here that we're
getting some general information.

108
00:05:15.740 --> 00:05:19.029
Now the cool thing is,
we can go into details here.

109
00:05:19.029 --> 00:05:20.729
We'll just pull this off to the side, so

00:05:20.729 --> 00:05:23.560
you can kind of see what we're

111
00:05:23.560 --> 00:05:25.370
So I just went in, went to details.

112
00:05:25.370 --> 00:05:27.320
I'm drilling down on this data,

113
00:05:27.320 --> 00:05:31.540
getting more response information back in

114
00:05:31.540 --> 00:05:35.310
So I can see the general information

115
00:05:35.310 --> 00:05:37.800
I can see the HTTP request, so

00:05:37.800 --> 00:05:41.110
I can actually get request and

117
00:05:41.110 --> 00:05:44.730
This is HTTP version 1.1,
as opposed to 1.0.

118
00:05:44.730 --> 00:05:46.080
So I can see that here.

119
00:05:46.080 --> 00:05:48.660
I can see the HTTP response
that's coming back.

120
00:05:48.660 --> 00:05:51.480
This is the actual code

121
00:05:51.480 --> 00:05:52.520
And this is what I'm seeing.

122
00:05:52.520 --> 00:05:56.240
And it's telling me that
I'm running IS version 8.5.

123
00:05:56.240 --> 00:05:59.730
So I'm running 2012 R2, for
instance, under the hood.

124
00:05:59.730 --> 00:06:02.830
And it's giving me information,
ASP.net, which is what we

125
00:06:02.830 --> 00:06:06.620
would expect to see with Microsoft
certainly, but it's giving us information.

126
00:06:06.620 --> 00:06:09.140
Also day and time and
the size of the cache and

127
00:06:09.140 --> 00:06:10.500
other stuff that may be valuable.

128
00:06:10.500 --> 00:06:13.540
So we're just recording
all this just to set up

129
00:06:13.540 --> 00:06:16.230
the demonstration in the sense
that we did the test.

130
00:06:16.230 --> 00:06:19.370
This is just the data that comes back

131
00:06:19.370 --> 00:06:21.810
the things that we need to understand and
make sure are there.

132
00:06:21.810 --> 00:06:24.130
So we always wanna take a look
at the request details,

133
00:06:24.130 --> 00:06:25.720
make sure everything
looks the way it should.

134
00:06:25.720 --> 00:06:27.033
>> It really is a lot of information.

135
00:06:27.033 --> 00:06:31.091
And I know, Adam, you are very well versed

136
00:06:31.091 --> 00:06:33.664
into consideration when we
do have this [CROSSTALK]

137
00:06:33.664 --> 00:06:34.785
>> We don't pay attention to that stuff.

138
00:06:34.785 --> 00:06:35.505
That's just a waste of time.

139
00:06:35.505 --> 00:06:36.107
>> [LAUGH] Okay.

140
00:06:36.107 --> 00:06:37.768
>> Who cares about security?

141
00:06:37.768 --> 00:06:39.351
That's not important.
Cherokee raises a really [CROSSTALK]

142
00:06:39.351 --> 00:06:40.933
>> I mean, you're showing me all this

143
00:06:40.933 --> 00:06:43.290
information in one stop shop,
and it's like wow.

144
00:06:43.290 --> 00:06:46.060
>> Cherokee raises a really important
point, which is security is so

145
00:06:46.060 --> 00:06:47.400
important in everything we do.

146
00:06:47.400 --> 00:06:48.764
We talk a lot about it, and

147
00:06:48.764 --> 00:06:51.690
it is certainly one of the areas
I do a lot of work in.

148
00:06:51.690 --> 00:06:54.310
I'm passionate about it,
as I know many of you are.

149
00:06:54.310 --> 00:06:58.220
And you know how important it is to make
sure that we safeguard this information.

150
00:06:58.220 --> 00:07:01.060
Some of the stuff that we were just
showing, version number, for instance,

151
00:07:01.060 --> 00:07:04.940
of what operating system is running, can
be extrapolated from understanding what

152
00:07:04.940 --> 00:07:08.170
version of web services are being
presented, as I explained, right?

153
00:07:08.170 --> 00:07:11.580
And so those kind of things definitely
could be problematic in the wrong hands,

154
00:07:11.580 --> 00:07:14.490
and Cherokee's right to stop us here for
a second and say, hey wait a second.

155
00:07:14.490 --> 00:07:16.000
Is there some concern here?

156
00:07:16.000 --> 00:07:17.970
Should we be keeping track of this stuff?

157
00:07:17.970 --> 00:07:19.860
Do we have to do something
to deal with it?

158
00:07:19.860 --> 00:07:22.270
Remember that this information
is coming back to us

159
00:07:22.270 --> 00:07:24.880
right now in a kind of secure environment,
right?

160
00:07:24.880 --> 00:07:27.014
We're in the land behind our firewalls, so

161
00:07:27.014 --> 00:07:29.792
let's just take a look at
a little diagram here, right?

162
00:07:29.792 --> 00:07:32.020
We're sitting here, right?

163
00:07:32.020 --> 00:07:37.700
And we're behind this firewall, imagine
this as our external entity, our perimeter

164
00:07:37.700 --> 00:07:42.730
of defense, if you will, our outer area
of our defense and death architecture.

165
00:07:42.730 --> 00:07:47.190
All the stuff we're doing is taking place
back in this area, over here to the right,

166
00:07:47.190 --> 00:07:49.800
we're interacting with
the ops manager database.

167
00:07:49.800 --> 00:07:52.370
We have our agent managed
servers down here.

168
00:07:52.370 --> 00:07:55.541
We have our agent managed infrastructure,
I should say.

169
00:07:55.541 --> 00:07:57.636
We have our management servers here,

170
00:07:57.636 --> 00:08:00.917
all the stuff we're doing is
taking place inside the land.

171
00:08:00.917 --> 00:08:04.186
Hopefully, and again,
everything is relative, of course.

172
00:08:04.186 --> 00:08:08.326
But hopefully behind the protection
perimeter, that is deep enough,

173
00:08:08.326 --> 00:08:13.225
wide enough, broad enough, and architected
sufficiently and strongly enough and

174
00:08:13.225 --> 00:08:17.641
hardened enough to be able to withstand
inbound detached from the outside so

175
00:08:17.641 --> 00:08:20.860
we hope this data would
not see the light of day.

176
00:08:20.860 --> 00:08:24.840
I would be certainly concerned about
the fact that data's out there but

177
00:08:24.840 --> 00:08:26.248
it's sitting in our databases.

178
00:08:26.248 --> 00:08:28.700
We would wanna make sure
that we are taking steps

179
00:08:28.700 --> 00:08:30.650
to prevent physical
access to the database.

180
00:08:30.650 --> 00:08:34.605
It's standard stuff we would normally do,
I don't let on access.

181
00:08:34.605 --> 00:08:37.955
Unauthorized users without
proper access control oversight.

182
00:08:37.955 --> 00:08:41.977
Get into these systems remotely and/or
physically by walking in the data center,

183
00:08:41.977 --> 00:08:45.025
interacting with something that
they're not supposed to do,

184
00:08:45.025 --> 00:08:47.108
let's make sure we encrypt that traffic.

185
00:08:47.108 --> 00:08:49.442
If it is flowing across the wire.

186
00:08:49.442 --> 00:08:53.732
We didn't choose HTTPS in the demo here,
but if we were using HTTPS,

187
00:08:53.732 --> 00:08:57.082
we'd be securing that transactional
data cuz we would obviously,

188
00:08:57.082 --> 00:09:01.552
hopefully benefit from the use of SSLTLS
to be able to encrypt that string.

189
00:09:01.552 --> 00:09:04.360
So there are definitely some
considerations and concerns,

190
00:09:04.360 --> 00:09:07.397
as Cherokee is reminding us of
that we'd wanna think about here.

191
00:09:07.397 --> 00:09:10.111
But I think that we're probably okay for
the moment,

192
00:09:10.111 --> 00:09:14.810
in the sense that this is happening inside
right now, and we're monitoring inside.

193
00:09:14.810 --> 00:09:18.030
We're gonna use a watcher node
that is inside right now, so

194
00:09:18.030 --> 00:09:20.200
