like we were just doing.

428
00:20:31.338 --> 00:20:37.714
Let's start our capture one more time.

429
00:20:37.714 --> 00:20:42.459
[NOISE]
And

430
00:20:47.960 --> 00:20:49.476
Hold on, let me get out.

431
00:20:49.476 --> 00:20:51.567
Try that one more, there we go,

432
00:20:51.567 --> 00:20:56.296
just got to have a back space key that
works the right way for that to work.

433
00:20:56.296 --> 00:20:58.400
All right so
let me try that one more time.

434
00:20:58.400 --> 00:21:00.696
So if we go out and,
I'll do something like that,

435
00:21:00.696 --> 00:21:02.292
that should be there from before.

436
00:21:02.292 --> 00:21:07.061
All right so we'll just click
back through there one more time.

437
00:21:19.952 --> 00:21:22.970
We could review something like that,
whatever the case might be.

438
00:21:22.970 --> 00:21:23.854
>> Just generating that traffic and
responses.

439
00:21:23.854 --> 00:21:25.752
>> Yeah, just whatever the case may be.

440
00:21:25.752 --> 00:21:26.370
It doesn't really matter.

441
00:21:26.370 --> 00:21:28.398
All right, so
then when we've done all that,

442
00:21:28.398 --> 00:21:32.040
you see it just takes us back to the same
place if you launch it from outside.

443
00:21:32.040 --> 00:21:34.901
We can see and take a look at.

444
00:21:34.901 --> 00:21:35.473
We finish the capture.

445
00:21:35.473 --> 00:21:39.485
And then at that point we don't have cuz
we're not going to the site that's set up

446
00:21:39.485 --> 00:21:40.375
for monitoring.

447
00:21:40.375 --> 00:21:42.390
Remember when we do the capture this way.

448
00:21:42.390 --> 00:21:45.780
We're not really going to the real site
we've programmed the web app monitor for.

449
00:21:45.780 --> 00:21:48.050
So I'm not really gathering any data.

450
00:21:48.050 --> 00:21:50.175
No requests, groups, all that information.

451
00:21:50.175 --> 00:21:50.969
I'm not seeing that.

452
00:21:50.969 --> 00:21:53.425
But In the real world if I
was actually doing this,

453
00:21:53.425 --> 00:21:55.775
then what I would see is
I would see the request.

454
00:21:55.775 --> 00:21:59.870
I'd be able to see the tracking
of all that information.

455
00:21:59.870 --> 00:22:02.394
And be able to interact with it
against the real site that I've set up

456
00:22:02.394 --> 00:22:03.207
the monitoring for.

457
00:22:03.207 --> 00:22:07.582
I'm just using essentially a proxy site to
show you the idea of starting the monitor.

458
00:22:07.582 --> 00:22:10.210
Just so you could see what
the capture would look like.

459
00:22:10.210 --> 00:22:11.795
But you'll see if we
launch it from outside,

460
00:22:11.795 --> 00:22:13.500
it's essentially done the same way.

461
00:22:13.500 --> 00:22:15.417
Takes us back to the same place,
we run the capture and

462
00:22:15.417 --> 00:22:17.688
then we're able to view the results
when we're done, right.

463
00:22:17.688 --> 00:22:19.863
So that's what we just
wanted to show you quickly.

464
00:22:19.863 --> 00:22:24.293
Just let me not save our changes there and
just come back out to our default, or

465
00:22:24.293 --> 00:22:26.010
rather, our standard view.

466
00:22:26.010 --> 00:22:27.078
We see our Web App Monitor.

467
00:22:27.078 --> 00:22:29.360
Now we could just stack these monitors up.

468
00:22:29.360 --> 00:22:33.220
Obviously name them in a way that makes
sense for you so that you can see them.

469
00:22:33.220 --> 00:22:36.210
And then we're able to do our
end-to-end service monitoring.

470
00:22:36.210 --> 00:22:40.602
But in this particular case we're focusing
on the synthetic transaction monitoring.

471
00:22:40.602 --> 00:22:42.648
Or ability to set up a web app monitor and

472
00:22:42.648 --> 00:22:46.809
to then look at the interaction with
the website from the user's perspective.

473
00:22:46.809 --> 00:22:50.542
And test the response time and
all the different things that go with it.

474
00:22:50.542 --> 00:22:53.300
>> There are a lot of different monitoring
capabilities within this particular

475
00:22:53.300 --> 00:22:56.020
utility so thank you for
taking the time to show us that.

476
00:22:56.020 --> 00:22:59.290
And thank you ladies and gentlemen for
joining us on this wonderful day.

477
00:22:59.290 --> 00:23:01.405
But stay tuned we do have more
information headed your way.

478
00:23:01.405 --> 00:23:02.645
We're gonna go ahead and sign out.

479
00:23:02.645 --> 00:23:04.112
Remember, I'm Cherokee Boose.

480
00:23:04.112 --> 00:23:05.869
>> I am Adam Gordon.

481
00:23:05.869 --> 00:23:07.969
>> See you next time here at ITProTV.

482
00:23:07.969 --> 00:23:15.596
[MUSIC]

483
00:23:15.596 --> 00:23:17.924
>> Thank you for watching ITProTV.

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Adam begin discussing and demonstrating Scorecards, Dashboards, and Reporting available in SCOM. They start by showing you the Reporting service. Here they show you how to configure reports, automate report generation, and setting up report delivery through methods like email and SMS.
episodes.title: Scorecards Dashboards and Reporting
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.008 --> 00:00:01.190
Welcome to ITPRO.TV.

2
00:00:01.190 --> 00:00:06.845
I'm your host [CROSSTALK]

3
00:00:06.845 --> 00:00:08.605
[MUSIC]

4
00:00:08.605 --> 00:00:10.925
>> You're watching ITPRO.TV.

5
00:00:10.925 --> 00:00:12.383
[MUSIC]

6
00:00:12.383 --> 00:00:14.308
>> All right, greetings everyone and

7
00:00:14.308 --> 00:00:16.970
welcome to another great
episode of ITPRO.TV.

8
00:00:16.970 --> 00:00:19.790
I'm your host Daniel Lowrie and
in today's episode, we are back.

9
00:00:19.790 --> 00:00:25.180
That's right, with more on our data center
monitoring with Microsoft SCOM series.

10
00:00:25.180 --> 00:00:28.670
And joining us in the studio again today
is our good friend and mentor, Mr.

11
00:00:28.670 --> 00:00:29.790
Adam Gordon.

12
00:00:29.790 --> 00:00:30.710
Adam, welcome back, sir.

13
00:00:30.710 --> 00:00:32.150
We're glad to have you again.

14
00:00:32.150 --> 00:00:33.270
>> How do, how do, how do?

15
00:00:33.270 --> 00:00:37.245
Or as we say in SQL Server Reporting
Services, how do with a query?

16
00:00:37.245 --> 00:00:38.067
>> [LAUGH]
>> So

17
00:00:38.067 --> 00:00:39.975
we're gonna talk about reporting
services a little bit.

18
00:00:39.975 --> 00:00:42.538
And we're gonna speak in
this particular episode, and

19
00:00:42.538 --> 00:00:44.509
probably at least one more after this one.

20
00:00:44.509 --> 00:00:46.700
Just to show you some of
the stuff we're gonna talk about.

21
00:00:46.700 --> 00:00:48.120
Talk a bit about how to configure and

22
00:00:48.120 --> 00:00:51.050
manage reporting in
the ops manager console.

23
00:00:51.050 --> 00:00:55.986
Your reporting is gonna be unfortunately
sometimes seen as an afterthought.

24
00:00:55.986 --> 00:00:59.490
Meaning, we setup SCOM,
we've got all that stuff going on, but

25
00:00:59.490 --> 00:01:02.990
then we got to remember and
remind ourselves of the fact.

26
00:01:02.990 --> 00:01:05.720
Let me just show you the picture we've
been referring to from time to time,

27
00:01:05.720 --> 00:01:06.610
we can take a look.

28
00:01:06.610 --> 00:01:10.389
We have to remind ourselves of the fact
that we have our reporting server kind of

29
00:01:10.389 --> 00:01:13.220
lonely, sitting out here on the side,
all on its own.

30
00:01:13.220 --> 00:01:15.310
Just waiting for
us to pay attention to it.

31
00:01:15.310 --> 00:01:16.740
It just hangs out there.

32
00:01:16.740 --> 00:01:21.620
And what we need to remember is we install
the SSRS SQL server reporting services

33
00:01:21.620 --> 00:01:26.180
role onto a management server separate
from the management server pool.

34
00:01:26.180 --> 00:01:30.210
Down here at the resource
pool we talked about.

35
00:01:30.210 --> 00:01:33.800
Once we instantiated that
role the ability to draw data

36
00:01:33.800 --> 00:01:38.150
through queries out of the data
warehouse database sitting over here.

37
00:01:38.150 --> 00:01:41.120
And then we have the ability
with the importation.

38
00:01:41.120 --> 00:01:42.720
That is the new phrase of the day.

39
00:01:42.720 --> 00:01:44.040
Importation.

40
00:01:44.040 --> 00:01:47.880
Not important, not importing,
but importation.

41
00:01:47.880 --> 00:01:51.930
The importation of the management packs
which we have talked about extensively

42
00:01:51.930 --> 00:01:53.190
in prior episodes.

43
00:01:53.190 --> 00:01:56.910
We'll talk about some more when we talk
about how to actually do customization

44
00:01:56.910 --> 00:01:58.840
of management packs, upcoming episode.

45
00:01:58.840 --> 00:02:02.570
Wanna make sure you take some time,
check that out at some point.

46
00:02:02.570 --> 00:02:05.980
We'll teach you how to write management
packs from the ground up, it's very cool.

47
00:02:05.980 --> 00:02:09.116
Dan is gonna sharpen up his quill and
his, do you ever write with a quill,

48
00:02:09.116 --> 00:02:09.930
by the way?

49
00:02:09.930 --> 00:02:10.590
>> I have, actually.

50
00:02:10.590 --> 00:02:11.435
>> With actually ink wells.

51
00:02:11.435 --> 00:02:12.860
>> Yes.
>> The whole nine yards.

52
00:02:12.860 --> 00:02:13.680
That's kinda cool.

53
00:02:13.680 --> 00:02:15.320
>> Yeah, I used to do calligraphy
when I was a kid, yeah.

54
00:02:15.320 --> 00:02:16.020
>> Did you really?

55
00:02:16.020 --> 00:02:18.650
Well, you draw, so I can imagine that
would probably be something you would do.

56
00:02:18.650 --> 00:02:19.820
But it is kinda cool, right?

57
00:02:19.820 --> 00:02:22.460
>> Yeah.
>> Dip the quill in the ink, and then you.

58
00:02:22.460 --> 00:02:24.960
But then you think about
the poor little porcupine or

59
00:02:24.960 --> 00:02:26.870
poor bird that they got it from,
whatever it may be.

60
00:02:26.870 --> 00:02:28.810
And then you're like-
>> They had it coming,

61
00:02:28.810 --> 00:02:30.010
that's all I'm gonna say [LAUGH].

62
00:02:30.010 --> 00:02:32.350
>> Right, wrong time, wrong place,
that's right it's just what you would say.

63
00:02:32.350 --> 00:02:33.570
>> [LAUGH]
>> So

64
00:02:33.570 --> 00:02:36.440
when you think about the reporting
services role, we're really

65
00:02:36.440 --> 00:02:40.585
thinking about bringing together
several different things, streams.

66
00:02:40.585 --> 00:02:42.215
And ideas all together in one place.

67
00:02:42.215 --> 00:02:44.819
And we have to do all that and
do it in the right way so

68
00:02:44.819 --> 00:02:49.225
that when we import the management packs,
we stack those reports up in the console.

69
00:02:49.225 --> 00:02:50.305
We have access to them.

70
00:02:50.305 --> 00:02:53.005
We're gonna show you where they are and
how that works.

71
00:02:53.005 --> 00:02:54.732
But we're talking about this.

72
00:02:54.732 --> 00:02:59.212
We're then gonna be able to use them
to extract, and to analyze, and

73
00:02:59.212 --> 00:03:01.162
to delve into that information.

74
00:03:01.162 --> 00:03:06.420
Using business intelligence, using data
analytics, using data visualization.

75
00:03:06.420 --> 00:03:10.510
And all the other key terms and
techniques and technologies

76
00:03:10.510 --> 00:03:13.720
that we would throw at this problem,
to really make this data come to life.

77
00:03:13.720 --> 00:03:18.710
You know the value, of a product like
SCOM is not in just the collection and

78
00:03:18.710 --> 00:03:20.910
archiving, warehousing of that data.

79
00:03:20.910 --> 00:03:24.050
That's important, but
that's just the nuts and bolts mechanics.

80
00:03:24.050 --> 00:03:28.930
The real value of this tool is the ability
to take that data, turn it around and

81
00:03:28.930 --> 00:03:31.550
analyze it from different perspectives.

82
00:03:31.550 --> 00:03:33.530
And then extract meaning from that data.

83
00:03:33.530 --> 00:03:36.090
That's really where we derive and
understand value.

84
00:03:36.090 --> 00:03:38.438
And so that's what we're
gonna be talking about here.

85
00:03:38.438 --> 00:03:41.370
Management packs, will have reports
included with them when we bring them in.

86
00:03:41.370 --> 00:03:43.010
So as we import management packs or

87
00:03:43.010 --> 00:03:46.690
we create management packs as
a vendor we add reports in.

88
00:03:46.690 --> 00:03:51.550
Reports are essentially just
predetermined, predefined SQL queries.

89
00:03:51.550 --> 00:03:53.970
SQL Structured Query Language queries.

90
00:03:53.970 --> 00:03:58.195
We gotta be specific when we say SQL cuz
Microsoft does such a good job of taking

91
00:03:58.195 --> 00:04:02.300
the concept of the term and
marketing the product against it, right?

92
00:04:02.300 --> 00:04:04.630
So when we talk about SQL databases,

93
00:04:04.630 --> 00:04:06.620
we're talking about Microsoft
database product name.

94
00:04:06.620 --> 00:04:10.620
But when we're talking about using Query
language, we have to be specific that

95
00:04:10.620 --> 00:04:15.732
we're talking about either SQL or
Transact-SQL, T-SQL.

96
00:04:15.732 --> 00:04:18.370
Maybe WQL, the WMI Query language,

97
00:04:18.370 --> 00:04:20.990
there's different implementations of
querying depending on what we're doing.

98
00:04:20.990 --> 00:04:25.520
But we're talking about the ability to be
able draw data out of those databases.

99
00:04:25.520 --> 00:04:29.260
Specifically, the warehouse database
through queries and then run them and

100
00:04:29.260 --> 00:04:30.350
display them in reports.

101
00:04:30.350 --> 00:04:34.330
That's really what reports allow us to
do and through the ops manager console.

102
00:04:34.330 --> 00:04:35.880
Allow us to interact with them.

103
00:04:35.880 --> 00:04:38.450
The nice thing about reports
are they could be scheduled for

104
00:04:38.450 --> 00:04:40.320
both execution, and delivery.

105
00:04:40.320 --> 00:04:45.380
So could say as a task essentially, hey at
two in the morning, run this report, and

106
00:04:45.380 --> 00:04:47.020
then email it out to me.

107
00:04:47.020 --> 00:04:50.870
Or a console message me or
SMS or whatever the case may be.

108
00:04:50.870 --> 00:04:53.400
Well, different options we'll
talk about what they are.

109
00:04:53.400 --> 00:04:56.230
And we can use
a Windows File Share to dump

110
00:04:56.230 --> 00:04:59.390
the report into [INAUDIBLE] go
graph it off the network somewhere.

111
00:04:59.390 --> 00:05:03.240
At a certain point in time we can use
what's called the null delivery provider.

112
00:05:03.240 --> 00:05:08.740
We can run the, I want to say SMS,
we can run the SSRS report.

113
00:05:08.740 --> 00:05:11.829
And then we can keep it
cached in the SSRS server.

114
00:05:13.000 --> 00:05:14.290
And we can just pull it down when needed.

115
00:05:14.290 --> 00:05:16.430
So it kinda sits there waiting for us.

116
00:05:16.430 --> 00:05:17.790
We can use email, as I said.

117
00:05:17.790 --> 00:05:19.266
So we can have pre-determined and

118
00:05:19.266 --> 00:05:21.810
pre-scheduled email delivery reports,
which is nice.

119
00:05:21.810 --> 00:05:24.190
You subscribe,
we'll talk about that process.

120
00:05:24.190 --> 00:05:25.970
You have notifications and

121
00:05:25.970 --> 00:05:28.650
subscriptions that we can tell
you when something's happening.

122
00:05:28.650 --> 00:05:30.450
You can get that information delivered.

123
00:05:30.450 --> 00:05:32.630
It's kinda like Amazon, but for reporting.

124
00:05:32.630 --> 00:05:35.560
As a matter of fact, I think they're the
next version, they're gonna come out, and

125
00:05:35.560 --> 00:05:36.591
essentially that's just gonna be them.

126
00:05:36.591 --> 00:05:38.630
>> [LAUGH]
>> All schedules, all delivery,

127
00:05:38.630 --> 00:05:41.420
everything, all Amazon prime,
brought to you by Amazon.

128
00:05:41.420 --> 00:05:43.720
That would be like,
talk about taking over the world, right?

129
00:05:43.720 --> 00:05:47.510
You convince Microsoft to let you do the
delivery on their reports for them, and

130
00:05:47.510 --> 00:05:48.070
you brand it?

131
00:05:48.070 --> 00:05:49.040
That would be-
>> Yeah.

132
00:05:49.040 --> 00:05:50.200
>> You gotta put that one on the list.

133
00:05:50.200 --> 00:05:53.804
>> At that point, you're definitely
world domination [LAUGH].

134
00:05:53.804 --> 00:05:57.540
>> Yeah,
you're running with the big boys, right?

135
00:05:57.540 --> 00:05:58.110
>> Yeah.

136
00:05:58.110 --> 00:05:59.030
>> That's big stuff.

137
00:05:59.030 --> 00:06:00.020
But you can imagine, right,

138
00:06:00.020 --> 00:06:02.770
just the capabilities that we have
when we think about this kinda stuff.

139
00:06:02.770 --> 00:06:05.650
We're gonna show you all this in
the console in a few minutes, by the way.

140
00:06:05.650 --> 00:06:07.690
We also can design our own custom reports.

141
00:06:07.690 --> 00:06:10.700
So it's nice to be able to take
reports off the shelf right?

142
00:06:10.700 --> 00:06:13.450
And say hey, I need to know how many

143
00:06:13.450 --> 00:06:16.550
errors I had interacting with that
website over the last 24 hours.

144
00:06:16.550 --> 00:06:18.290
They need to know how many bad reads or

145
00:06:18.290 --> 00:06:21.490
writes I had off that hard
drive on that machine.

146
00:06:21.490 --> 00:06:24.580
Cloud providers need this kind of
stuff on a daily basis to understand

147
00:06:24.580 --> 00:06:25.600
their infrastructure.

148
00:06:25.600 --> 00:06:28.470
There's lot's of value
in pre-made reports.

149
00:06:28.470 --> 00:06:31.810
But there's also value in customizing
reports and making our own.

150
00:06:31.810 --> 00:06:33.750
And we have a tool for that, as we say.

151
00:06:33.750 --> 00:06:37.280
Report builder, which is the standard
tool that we use with SSRS,

152
00:06:37.280 --> 00:06:39.300
with SQL Server Reporting Services.

153
00:06:39.300 --> 00:06:43.250
We use Report Builder, if you've ever used
it you know it's a grid-like interface.

154
00:06:43.250 --> 00:06:48.360
We drag out the report elements and
we create them on a grid.

155
00:06:48.360 --> 00:06:52.120
We lay them out, so it's almost like
a combination of the Form Builder

156
00:06:52.120 --> 00:06:56.110
that you're maybe used to Access,
if you've ever done report building there.

157
00:06:56.110 --> 00:06:58.640
Or if you ever use, remember FrontPage?

158
00:06:58.640 --> 00:07:00.480
>> Vaguely, yeah, from back in the day.

159
00:07:00.480 --> 00:07:01.810
>> Like way, way back, right?

160
00:07:01.810 --> 00:07:02.340
>> Yeah, yeah.

161
00:07:02.340 --> 00:07:06.129
>> So FrontPage was the original Microsoft
web authoring tool that they brought

162
00:07:06.129 --> 00:07:07.415
out long, long time ago.

163
00:07:07.415 --> 00:07:08.991
Got rebranded and

164
00:07:08.991 --> 00:07:15.090
is now being used under a different
name to be able to build a website.

165
00:07:15.090 --> 00:07:17.270
SharePoint Designer is what
we call FrontPage now.

166
00:07:17.270 --> 00:07:20.090
It's what it's been renamed
over the last Number of years.

167
00:07:20.090 --> 00:07:21.500
But it's kind of like that a little bit.

168
00:07:21.500 --> 00:07:23.240
It's got that kind of look and feel.

169
00:07:23.240 --> 00:07:25.960
Everything's kind of moving
towards that tabbed interface.

170
00:07:25.960 --> 00:07:29.220
Looks a lot like visual studio,
if you ever spend any time using that.

171
00:07:29.220 --> 00:07:30.760
And you build elements there.

172
00:07:30.760 --> 00:07:32.200
They all kind of look the same these days.

173
00:07:32.200 --> 00:07:33.990
So Report Builder's gonna be used.

174
00:07:33.990 --> 00:07:37.230
You can design and
publish reports right from there.

175
00:07:37.230 --> 00:07:38.370
It's a neat little tool.

176
00:07:38.370 --> 00:07:42.165
You download off the SSRS site as
you go on to use it, it installs,

177

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Adam continue discussing and demonstrating Scorecards, Dashboards, and Reporting available in SCOM. They jump back in by looking at how to configure Service Level Tracking and then move on to using Dashboards.

it shows its basic functionality.

But were lumping those other consoles

And I made this point,
when we first demoed the diagram for you,

And we referred to it

So I just wanna remind you
the fact that all those consoles

00:20:06.650 --> 00:20:07.970

Let's take a look at

So if we just come down here, or

Let's just come down here,

And I've got them already opened up,

The application advisor, and
the application diagnostics consoles.

We could see both of them here.

You just click on it,

Gotta make sure you have

You saw me when we're doing all the

00:20:41.618 --> 00:20:43.929

give an error it's usually that,

There's a prompt that pops up,

And you could see once we come in here,

Maybe we can go full screen just to

00:21:01.611 --> 00:21:05.460
Cuz I know they're kinda small and I can't

00:21:05.460 --> 00:21:07.310
Problem analysis reports.

00:21:07.310 --> 00:21:09.362

We have all these different areas

And so the App Advisor allows

So we can load up a specific report, get

00:21:33.590 --> 00:21:34.930

We can schedule.

We can make and mark something available.

474
00:21:38.350 --> 00:21:41.757
We can go ahead and essentially just

00:21:41.757 --> 00:21:43.120
how we wanna mange it.

So, the app advisor is like a subset

We can see if we click on just

we go in, application failure analysis.

We can go in and run a data sweep,

00:22:11.700 --> 00:22:15.880

We would specify a time range here.

00:22:18.593 --> 00:22:22.190
And then, apply it and

00:22:22.190 --> 00:22:24.740
I don't have any data

00:22:28.070 --> 00:22:28.960
But you get the idea.

489
00:22:28.960 --> 00:22:30.840
You would run it and

00:22:30.840 --> 00:22:32.820
>> Adam, you don't have a full
network sitting around, just so

00:22:33.540 --> 00:22:36.650
>> I don't have all that just sitting

00:22:36.650 --> 00:22:39.760
But you could see here, this is what

00:22:39.760 --> 00:22:41.290
we'd be able to use this portal.

00:22:41.290 --> 00:22:43.880
We can also use the application
diagnostics portal

00:22:43.880 --> 00:22:46.140
which is the other one that's launched or
available here.

497
00:22:46.140 --> 00:22:50.169
The console I should say cuz they're
really consoles and when we load them up.

00:22:51.330 --> 00:22:56.090
You'll see here, that we can go in and

all here by default.

00:22:59.080 --> 00:23:03.730
We can go in, look for applications errors
and/or performance related information

one or both group by name, right.

502
00:23:05.950 --> 00:23:08.879
Specify event data information.

00:23:08.879 --> 00:23:12.099
We have, as you could see aspects here.

00:23:12.099 --> 00:23:15.265
And we can pull this open and
specify Security,

00:23:15.265 --> 00:23:19.750
Performance, Application Failure,
and/or Connectivity.

00:23:19.750 --> 00:23:22.820
So we can look at these and
interact with them and order them.

507
00:23:22.820 --> 00:23:27.187
And we have to specify Event ID, so
we will be able to put in an event ID,

508
00:23:27.187 --> 00:23:29.275
whatever that event ID might be.

509
00:23:29.275 --> 00:23:32.526
And then we can drill through
the information that's coming in,

00:23:32.526 --> 00:23:35.560
pull in those events and

00:23:35.560 --> 00:23:38.890
We've mentioned certain event ID's

00:23:38.890 --> 00:23:42.240
About hey, when you install,
if you get this event ID, it means this.

00:23:42.240 --> 00:23:44.450
If you see this error code, it means this.

00:23:44.450 --> 00:23:47.880
We've given you some little small
inclination, an idea about those.

00:23:47.880 --> 00:23:50.590
But certainly, I have not gone through
an exhaustive list, cuz there's many,

00:23:50.590 --> 00:23:51.420
many of them.

517
00:23:51.420 --> 00:23:54.570
But you would see event IDs or
be able to Google for them, read up

518
00:23:54.570 --> 00:23:58.612
on the documentation on the product and
interact with them, and you would then be

519
00:23:58.612 --> 00:24:02.430
able to bring them in and search for

520
00:24:02.430 --> 00:24:05.625
You could also search here, interact with,

00:24:05.625 --> 00:24:09.422
just let me click on
the workspace to change the area.

00:24:09.422 --> 00:24:11.119
Specify here, there we go,

00:24:11.119 --> 00:24:15.875
specify applications, I did click, yet
I clicked and it just went right back.

00:24:15.875 --> 00:24:19.738
So you could see here we can go in and
we can specify applications,

00:24:19.738 --> 00:24:22.910
we can put in information for
certain applications.

00:24:22.910 --> 00:24:23.710
And if you look at,

00:24:23.710 --> 00:24:26.826
if we can go full screen you can see
the headers up top there in the columns.

00:24:26.826 --> 00:24:30.945
You could see what kind of

00:24:30.945 --> 00:24:34.412
The name of the app, statistics over the

00:24:34.412 --> 00:24:34.941
exception.

00:24:34.941 --> 00:24:39.980
Performance events, number of servers and

So we can do all of this and we would

We'd have to obviously have elements

00:24:48.950 --> 00:24:50.310
And we can either go in and

00:24:54.530 --> 00:24:59.940
We can go to Computers here as well, and

00:25:04.080 --> 00:25:07.815
And again we could specify here,
we've have to have elements created and

00:25:07.815 --> 00:25:08.969
enabled for us to use.

540
00:25:08.969 --> 00:25:13.710
And then we would apply and
see information being brought in.

541
00:25:13.710 --> 00:25:16.106
So it would allow us to be able to go in.

00:25:16.106 --> 00:25:23.800
We could go in and we can use these
portals or these consoles, right?

00:25:23.800 --> 00:25:27.140
To be able to drill down and

00:25:27.140 --> 00:25:31.390

00:25:31.390 --> 00:25:34.255
So we can see them and

00:25:34.255 --> 00:25:36.623
Which is also nice cuz, again,
you may not get to see those consoles.

00:25:36.623 --> 00:25:38.420
And if you don't know they're there,

00:25:38.420 --> 00:25:41.690
trip over them off in the corner

00:25:41.690 --> 00:25:45.190
We may not realize they’re there or

00:25:45.190 --> 00:25:47.670
unless somebody tells us,

00:25:47.670 --> 00:25:49.994
The only issue I have and

00:25:49.994 --> 00:25:54.115
The only issue I have with the tool

00:25:54.115 --> 00:25:58.275
It's a little busy, there's so

If you're not really paying attention

00:26:01.945 --> 00:26:05.325
Which is contextual and
it does change when we click on things.

You could miss so much stuff because it
is buried two, three, four layers deep.

557
00:26:09.505 --> 00:26:10.645
You just don't realize it's there.

558
00:26:10.645 --> 00:26:12.568
My point,
let me just show you something here.

00:26:12.568 --> 00:26:15.945
If I go into .NET monitoring,
and under .NET monitoring,

00:26:15.945 --> 00:26:18.740
I go to Monitored Applications here,
all right.

00:26:20.120 --> 00:26:22.166
This area changes dramatically, right?

00:26:22.166 --> 00:26:24.618
And if I go in here,
I go to Active Alerts,

00:26:24.618 --> 00:26:28.205
this area is essentially very

564
00:26:28.205 --> 00:26:30.420
But we have a subscription
item down below.

565
00:26:30.420 --> 00:26:38.640
But if I come up here and I look at

00:26:38.640 --> 00:26:41.310
And you'll see that now this

00:26:41.310 --> 00:26:46.140
I have actions to start maintenance mode.

00:26:46.140 --> 00:26:48.600
I can go in and
look at the Health Explorer.

569
00:26:48.600 --> 00:26:52.138
I can come down and
see a group of tasks specific to Windows.

570
00:26:52.138 --> 00:26:57.150
I have a whole bunch of report tasks that
are specific to this particular item.

00:26:57.150 --> 00:26:59.289
So everything is changing all the time,

572
00:26:59.289 --> 00:27:03.311
And that's just, for me anyway,

00:27:03.311 --> 00:27:06.790
Because sometimes it's hard to

574
00:27:06.790 --> 00:27:10.330
what I wanna do and it may be hard for

575
00:27:10.330 --> 00:27:12.942
One of the nice little hidden gems

00:27:12.942 --> 00:27:14.720

00:27:15.388 --> 00:27:16.964

And haven't really showed

00:27:19.800 --> 00:27:22.682
But the Health Explorer

00:27:25.088 --> 00:27:26.015
And drill in and

00:27:26.015 --> 00:27:30.230

584
00:27:30.230 --> 00:27:35.790
So here, ManagementConfiguration,

00:27:35.790 --> 00:27:38.010
We could see a summary and

00:27:38.010 --> 00:27:40.090
We can link to alerts that may be there.

587
00:27:40.090 --> 00:27:41.349
We could see state changes and

588
00:27:41.349 --> 00:27:44.279

589
00:27:44.279 --> 00:27:47.267
We went from it looks like
warning to good, right?

590
00:27:47.267 --> 00:27:50.455
Then it looks we went from error
to warning, and good back and

591
00:27:50.455 --> 00:27:52.155
forth bouncing around.

592
00:27:52.155 --> 00:27:55.945
And so as we highlight, we may or
may not have information or

593
00:27:55.945 --> 00:27:57.800
context around around one of these.

594
00:27:57.800 --> 00:28:00.505
But we can click through and
we can see each one,

595
00:28:00.505 --> 00:28:03.422
helps us to better understand
what may be going on.

596
00:28:03.422 --> 00:28:07.202
And I can cross reference alerts
right off the Health Explorer,

597
00:28:07.202 --> 00:28:09.140
drill in and see all the alerts.

598
00:28:09.140 --> 00:28:13.540
Again, all the management of data,
the reporting, the information and

00:28:13.540 --> 00:28:16.650

is very rich in detail.

600
00:28:16.650 --> 00:28:20.810
But sometimes, it's a little too much,
a little too rich, a little too detailed.

601
00:28:20.810 --> 00:28:25.290
For me, I really have to stop and
consider carefully what I wanna know.

602
00:28:25.290 --> 00:28:28.890
And really resolve or think through
in my mind the best way to get there.

603
00:28:28.890 --> 00:28:29.880
>> Yeah, no lack of data,

604
00:28:29.880 --> 00:28:31.970
just got to figure out where
the heck they're hiding the thing.

605
00:28:31.970 --> 00:28:35.280
>> An overwhelming abundance
of data actually is actually

606
00:28:35.280 --> 00:28:36.320
>> An embarrassment of riches.

607
00:28:36.320 --> 00:28:38.580
>> An embarrassment of riches, exactly.

608
00:28:38.580 --> 00:28:41.730
Let's take a look at how to get
that dashboard up and running.

609
00:28:41.730 --> 00:28:43.124
Do you think we have
enough time to do this?

610
00:28:43.124 --> 00:28:45.254
Should we make this say a new-
>> Depends on how long you

611
00:28:45.254 --> 00:28:45.860
think it'll take.

612
00:28:45.860 --> 00:28:47.234
>> Longer than you probably want it to.

613
00:28:47.234 --> 00:28:48.028
>> Okay, well then we will.

614
00:28:48.028 --> 00:28:51.523
>> [LAUGH]
>> [CROSSTALK] That's the great thing

615
00:28:51.523 --> 00:28:52.672
about doing the show.

616
00:28:52.672 --> 00:28:54.979
If we need a part three,
we do a part three, and

617
00:28:54.979 --> 00:28:56.650
you guys get the benefit of that.

618
00:28:56.650 --> 00:28:59.240
So Adam, I look forward to
seeing you in part three.

619
00:28:59.240 --> 00:29:01.830
Look forward to seeing our
good viewer there as well.

620
00:29:01.830 --> 00:29:04.110
As for this episode,
looks like we've come to the end.

621
00:29:04.110 --> 00:29:07.150
Thanks for watching, and signing off for
ITProTV, I've been your host,

622
00:29:07.150 --> 00:29:07.980
Daniel Lowrie.

623
00:29:07.980 --> 00:29:08.740
>> I'm Adam Gordon.

624
00:29:08.740 --> 00:29:09.780
>> And we'll see you next time.

625
00:29:09.780 --> 00:29:17.283
[MUSIC]

626
00:29:17.283 --> 00:29:18.965
Thank you for watching ITProTV.

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Adam finish discussing and demonstrating Scorecards, Dashboards, and Reporting available in SCOM. Here they show you how to create a completely customized Dashboard.
episodes.title: Scorecards Dashboards and Reporting Part 3

28

I'll show you that long anticipated,

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Adam take you through configuring the Operations Manager Console. They begin by defining key terms and then create custom views and Alert Resolution States. They also discuss configuring Notification Subscriptions as well as creating Diagnostic and Recovery Tasks.

All right, so let's start with

48
00:02:05.905 --> 00:02:10.080
Well, we're talking about
using the SCOM console and

49
00:02:10.080 --> 00:02:13.990
we're talking about the ability to
be able to sign permissions and

50
00:02:13.990 --> 00:02:17.740
use user roles and profiles and scoping.

51
00:02:17.740 --> 00:02:19.400
We've gotta think about
what all these terms mean,

52
00:02:19.400 --> 00:02:22.180
because we throw these terms out,
but we don't often define them,

53
00:02:22.180 --> 00:02:24.130
and really think through
the logic of what they are.

54
00:02:24.130 --> 00:02:27.800
So, let's start with the basics,
operation, and or privilege.

55
00:02:27.800 --> 00:02:29.378
These terms, these concepts.

56
00:02:29.378 --> 00:02:32.790
Essentially just any action that's carried
out by a user with the appropriate level

57
00:02:32.790 --> 00:02:36.420
of permission, is what an operation or
a privilege would entail,

58
00:02:36.420 --> 00:02:39.280
what do we define it as, or
what it would represent for us.

59
00:02:39.280 --> 00:02:44.250
A profile is a collection of
operations granted or given to a role.

60
00:02:44.250 --> 00:02:48.670
So we collect all of the operations
together, the individual things,

61
00:02:48.670 --> 00:02:51.940
the actions that somebody can do,
collect them all up, and

62
00:02:51.940 --> 00:02:55.510
we give them to a role, and
we then call that a profile.

63
00:02:55.510 --> 00:02:58.580
A scope defines the boundary
that the running profile or

64

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Adam demonstrate how to author your own custom Management Pack for SCOM. They begin by exploring some of the basic concepts behind Management Pack authoring. Then they discuss authoring Management Packs by using the Operations Console. Finally, they look at authoring Management Packs by using the Visual Studio Authoring extensions.
episodes.title: Management Pack Authoring

>> I'm Adam Gordon.

928
00:42:54.897 --> 00:42:56.663
>> And we'll see you next time.

929
00:42:56.663 --> 00:43:03.499
[MUSIC]

930
00:43:03.499 --> 00:43:06.496
>> Thank you for watching ITProTV.

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Adam explore the concept of integrating the System Center Ops Manager with the other System Center products. Here they detail each of the different System Center components that the Operations Manager with integrate with as well as discuss the benefits.
episodes.title: System Center Integration
episodes.transcript:

>> [LAUGH] Yeah.

>> SCOM-ified day here at
ITProTV in studio number

So we are going to

We talked about system
center config manager.

We've talked about a lot,

You see me and Daniel interact with,

We've played with or interacted with

And showing you individual pieces and

Or various things that may

We actually did an entire series

We're gonna go back in, and we're gonna

And we'll actually then take a look

So it should be an interesting

60

Let's start by talking

61

Service Level Manager, Service Manager,

This is our product that allows us to

Coming out whether you're I till centric,

64

or just generically

The service level manager,
the piece software,

is gonna be our hub or communication and

67

coordination for all the information that
we're gonna gather and get out of SCOM.

68
00:03:18.900 --> 00:03:23.370
So as we're doing our monitoring, and
as we're getting alerts, we're getting

69
00:03:23.370 --> 00:03:27.210
information generated about health status,
all thing we've been taking a look at and

70

packs are humming along.

We've done our customization as we

We have the data coming

information that gets generated in scum

76
00:03:46.340 --> 00:03:50.640
We want it to start generating tickets

77

kick off our incident and

78

79

Release management,
surface request fulfillment.

80

These are all of the different solutions
that a surface level manager brings to

81
00:04:03.030 --> 00:04:04.030

82

And I've spoken about this in other

00:04:07.050 --> 00:04:10.950
connectivity that needs to take place and
the fact that the value

84

85
00:04:15.427 --> 00:04:21.230
And is essentially just static, but rather
It's the value of taking that information,

86
00:04:21.230 --> 00:04:25.700

87
00:04:25.700 --> 00:04:29.380

And then creating action, and

So wanna be thinking about that as we're

93

Gonna take out on the web in just a minute

We have one for

It is going to work with the config

00:05:45.495 --> 00:05:50.500

of an updating our C I so our

115
00:06:10.020 --> 00:06:13.080
And on the front end,
our incident and problem and

118
00:06:21.230 --> 00:06:24.110
And so

A crossroads for information flow and

We have our orchestrator connector.

We do health and performance

144

We then can be told, across every product.

149

00:09:18.045 --> 00:09:21.275
We have protection and

175
00:09:24.905 --> 00:09:28.965
So all the different end points that we

176

We do have Operations Manager packs,
two of them, that are important for

Data Protection Manager 2012

179

180

181

that become available inside of SCOM.

183
00:09:54.690 --> 00:09:56.660

184
00:09:56.660 --> 00:09:59.430
We can use that to manage,
to maintain integrity, and

185
00:09:59.430 --> 00:10:00.740

186
00:10:00.740 --> 00:10:04.220
So we'll take a look at some information

187
00:10:04.220 --> 00:10:07.085
We have the Orchestrator product,

188

We've demonstrated some of this

189
00:10:10.280 --> 00:10:11.510
We've talked about it.

190

We integrate with SCOM through what

So we import integration packs

193

194
00:10:24.665 --> 00:10:28.485

create our workflows and sync them up.

195
00:10:28.485 --> 00:10:30.200
We're actually gonna take
a look at how to do that.

196
00:10:30.200 --> 00:10:34.050
We've done that in a prior episode, but
did just a very high level, generic pass.

197
00:10:34.050 --> 00:10:36.820
We didn't really set one up,
program it out the right way.

198
00:10:36.820 --> 00:10:39.150
We'll actually take
a look at how to do that.

199
00:10:39.150 --> 00:10:41.510
So a list of integration packs for SCOM.

200
00:10:41.510 --> 00:10:45.370
I'm gonna show you where that is and
how we can find those with Orchestrator.

201
00:10:45.370 --> 00:10:48.260
So it's important just to be aware of
what's out there, what's available for us.

202
00:10:48.260 --> 00:10:49.250
So we'll take a look.

203
00:10:50.540 --> 00:10:53.730
Once we get those integration packs up and
running, all those activities,

204
00:10:53.730 --> 00:10:55.410
as I mentioned, will be available.

205
00:10:55.410 --> 00:10:58.390
And we'll take a look at what those
activities look like on the web

206
00:10:58.390 --> 00:10:59.190

207
00:10:59.190 --> 00:10:59.730
Let's go over and

So Service Manager over here, right.

Service Manager, we talked about this.

00:11:35.570 --> 00:11:38.110
So all the information you would

we have different options here,
information, warning and critical.

289
00:12:41.920 --> 00:12:43.670
We'll go ahead and we'll do warning.

290
00:12:43.670 --> 00:12:45.330
So, we'll program those in.

291
00:12:45.330 --> 00:12:48.120
We're then go ahead, gonna click OK, and

292
00:12:48.120 --> 00:12:53.600
we've got our alert routing rule.

293
00:12:53.600 --> 00:12:57.320
And we could stack up a series
of rules here if we wanted to.

294
00:12:57.320 --> 00:12:58.680
You'll see that we can do this.

295
00:12:58.680 --> 00:13:03.010
If we add in another one, we'll then have
the option to move them up and down and

296
00:13:03.010 --> 00:13:07.270
have them centrally processed
in the appropriate order.

297
00:13:07.270 --> 00:13:11.310
Alerts that do not fit any of the rules
above will be routed through the following

298
00:13:11.310 --> 00:13:12.070
template.

299
00:13:12.070 --> 00:13:15.800
The default ops manager incident template
is the template that'll pick up these

300
00:13:15.800 --> 00:13:17.970
alerts because they're
coming from ops manager.

301
00:13:17.970 --> 00:13:21.150
What the rules really allow us to
do by binding to the template and

302
00:13:21.150 --> 00:13:26.060
specifying behavior, is specifying
a certain activity and a certain flow for

303
00:13:26.060 --> 00:13:29.210
that activity based on a criteria match.

304
00:13:29.210 --> 00:13:31.214
Otherwise, we have a capture wall,
much like a firewall.

305
00:13:31.214 --> 00:13:35.458
Block all or something like that,
when we don't have anything else to do.

306
00:13:35.458 --> 00:13:40.385
We'll go through and use the ops manager
incident template as programmed to deal

307
00:13:40.385 --> 00:13:44.490
with anything that's not already
setup with a rule up above.

308
00:13:44.490 --> 00:13:47.340
And it's first past the post in
terms of a match here, right?

309
00:13:47.340 --> 00:13:50.648
So once we hit a rule that matches
to either one or multiple rules,

310
00:13:50.648 --> 00:13:52.523
whatever it is, we filter through.

311
00:13:52.523 --> 00:13:56.273
We find the rule that matches the criteria
based on the alert coming in.

312
00:13:56.273 --> 00:13:58.040
And that's the one we apply.

313
00:13:58.040 --> 00:14:00.110
So as soon as we hit a match,
we go forward.

314
00:14:00.110 --> 00:14:04.530
If we don't, we fall into the catch-all
bucket at the bottom with the ops manager

315
00:14:04.530 --> 00:14:06.060
incident template, right?

316
00:14:06.060 --> 00:14:07.520
If we have to go in and
say, you know what,

317
00:14:07.520 --> 00:14:11.040
I need to make a change to that,
Just highlight it, edit it.

318
00:14:11.040 --> 00:14:13.920
Hey, I didn't really mean to do that,
highlight it and remove, right?

319
00:14:13.920 --> 00:14:16.590
So we've got all the tools
right here to do what we need.

320
00:14:16.590 --> 00:14:18.440
We're gonna go ahead,
we're gonna click Next.

321
00:14:18.440 --> 00:14:22.949
We now have to create a schedule,
poll for alerts every so many seconds.

322
00:14:22.949 --> 00:14:25.295
How often is the connector
connecting out and saying, hey,

323
00:14:25.295 --> 00:14:26.404
do you have anything for me?

324
00:14:26.404 --> 00:14:27.618
Kinda like, are we there yet, right?

325
00:14:27.618 --> 00:14:29.547
Are we there yet, are we there yet,
are we there yet, right?

326
00:14:29.547 --> 00:14:32.220
So how often do we wanna check on that?

327
00:14:32.220 --> 00:14:34.620
We've got it set to 30 seconds by default.

328
00:14:34.620 --> 00:14:36.180
No big deal, we can leave that.

329
00:14:36.180 --> 00:14:41.060
We'll do 60 seconds, once a minute,
probably good in most organizations.

330
00:14:41.060 --> 00:14:43.050
Don't really have a lot
of concerns about that.

331
00:14:43.050 --> 00:14:46.945
Then close alerts and Ops Manager when
incidents are resolved or closed.

332
00:14:46.945 --> 00:14:50.780
So I've talked about it in several
other episodes, the interaction and

333
00:14:50.780 --> 00:14:54.160
the connectivity here and the
communication flow that's bidirectional

334
00:14:54.160 --> 00:14:56.530
between these products as we
start setting up connectors.

335
00:14:56.530 --> 00:15:01.640
Do we wanna have ops manager alerts
closed our when they're resolved or

336
00:15:01.640 --> 00:15:03.440
dealt with here in service level manager?

337
00:15:03.440 --> 00:15:06.532
The answer is most likely yes cuz this
is what we're paying all the big money

338
00:15:06.532 --> 00:15:07.133
for, right?

339
00:15:07.133 --> 00:15:09.151
>> Mm-hm.
>> Wanna be able to manage it here,

340
00:15:09.151 --> 00:15:13.610
deal with it here, address it here through
our escalation pathway for our SLAs.

341
00:15:13.610 --> 00:15:15.184
And then say, hey,
by the way, we did that.

342
00:15:15.184 --> 00:15:18.213
Go ahead and just take care of that,
close it out for me in ops manager.

343
00:15:18.213 --> 00:15:21.520
So we don't have to go chase it in
the console and specify it later.

344
00:15:21.520 --> 00:15:24.320
If you, then,
are smart about this, you do this,

345
00:15:24.320 --> 00:15:27.850
your alerts automatically get generated
through monitoring on the scom side.

346
00:15:27.850 --> 00:15:30.320
Automatically get communicated
across the connector,

347
00:15:30.320 --> 00:15:32.540
are dealt with here in
service level manager.

348
00:15:32.540 --> 00:15:37.271
And then automatically we close the circle
of life, except it's the circle of alerts.

349
00:15:37.271 --> 00:15:38.752
>> [LAUGH]
>> And we actually go back and

350
00:15:38.752 --> 00:15:41.975
we close out the alert on the SCOM side,
which is great, right?

351
00:15:41.975 --> 00:15:44.500
So we're gonna go ahead and
we're gonna check that off.

352
00:15:44.500 --> 00:15:48.200
And resolve incidents automatically when
the alerts in the ops manager are closed.

353
00:15:48.200 --> 00:15:52.674
If we close an alert in ops manager,
make sure then we resolve the alert and

354
00:15:52.674 --> 00:15:55.936
automatically resolve it
in service level manager.

355
00:15:55.936 --> 00:15:59.750
Bidirectional, we're essentially dealing
with it and saying, on either side,

356
00:15:59.750 --> 00:16:01.281
once we do one, alert the other.

357
00:16:01.281 --> 00:16:05.136
So we're not wasting our time chasing
it when it's already been dealt with.

358
00:16:05.136 --> 00:16:08.364
And, in addition,
we don't have orphaned, or

359
00:16:08.364 --> 00:16:13.720
ghost activities that are left in the data
base, and are left in the console.

360
00:16:13.720 --> 00:16:15.230
And somebody looks at it in six months,
and goes,

361
00:16:15.230 --> 00:16:18.852
hey, why is that alert still open for
that Raid Ray failure?

362
00:16:18.852 --> 00:16:19.480
Right?
>> [LAUGH]

363
00:16:19.480 --> 00:16:20.320
>> What's going on with that?

364
00:16:20.320 --> 00:16:22.270
We've been out of storage for six months.

365
00:16:22.270 --> 00:16:23.580
No, no, that's all working fine.

366
00:16:23.580 --> 00:16:26.490
It's just somebody forgot to go back and
actually close it out.

367
00:16:26.490 --> 00:16:30.810
We used to see this a lot when this
was a very person intensive process,

368
00:16:30.810 --> 00:16:33.410
especially with help desk tickets,
or service desk tickets.

369
00:16:33.410 --> 00:16:36.160
Where tickets would get orphaned, because
people would just forget to go in and

370
00:16:36.160 --> 00:16:37.200
close them out.

371
00:16:37.200 --> 00:16:39.810
And, so this is gonna help us
to eliminate some of that, and

372
00:16:39.810 --> 00:16:41.430
this is the reason why
we're gonna check that off.

373
00:16:41.430 --> 00:16:44.320
So, we're gonna go ahead, and
we're gonna check this off as well and

374
00:16:44.320 --> 00:16:45.140
go ahead and do this.

375
00:16:45.140 --> 00:16:46.389
Hit next.

376
00:16:46.389 --> 00:16:48.300
We've got our little summary here.

377
00:16:48.300 --> 00:16:49.630
Tells us what we're doing.

378
00:16:49.630 --> 00:16:52.660
Always good is we talked about to
pay attention to the summary page,

379
00:16:52.660 --> 00:16:54.020
make sure we know what's happening.

380
00:16:55.120 --> 00:16:57.750
So, we're gonna go ahead, and
just make sure we have a read on that.

381
00:16:57.750 --> 00:16:59.140
We'll click Create.

382
00:16:59.140 --> 00:16:59.770
Give that a moment.

383
00:16:59.770 --> 00:17:00.727
Doesn't take very long.

384
00:17:00.727 --> 00:17:01.979
We'll just wait for that, and

385
00:17:01.979 --> 00:17:05.510
we'll see the little connector will
be displayed here in just a moment.

386
00:17:05.510 --> 00:17:06.420
We'll see we're done.

387
00:17:06.420 --> 00:17:08.731
Green circle, white check.

388
00:17:08.731 --> 00:17:10.300
I'll close the wizard.

389
00:17:10.300 --> 00:17:14.230
Now, this is just me just
observing the human condition, but

390
00:17:14.230 --> 00:17:16.510
I've basically done what I wanted to do.

391
00:17:16.510 --> 00:17:18.410
The wizard says, I'm successful.

392
00:17:18.410 --> 00:17:21.960
You could not just say, okay,
we closed the wizard screen.

393
00:17:21.960 --> 00:17:24.400
It takes extra money and
development time to close the screen out,

394
00:17:24.400 --> 00:17:27.430
as opposed to me having to
click on that last button.

395
00:17:27.430 --> 00:17:29.660
>> That's the way they feel about it.

396
00:17:29.660 --> 00:17:33.470
They didn't consult us on these things,
we've talked about this.

397
00:17:33.470 --> 00:17:34.520
>> Yeah.

398
00:17:34.520 --> 00:17:36.511
But you know I'm bitter
about this kind of stuff.

399
00:17:36.511 --> 00:17:39.720
I'm just thinking,
this is all really cool.

400
00:17:39.720 --> 00:17:41.510
You got this awesome technology.

401
00:17:41.510 --> 00:17:44.720
You couldn't spend the extra $5 give
the developer an extra piece of pizza,

402
00:17:44.720 --> 00:17:47.018
an extra red bull, and just say,
hey, close that out for them.

403
00:17:47.018 --> 00:17:48.797
>> [LAUGH]
>> You couldn't make that happen, right?

404
00:17:48.797 --> 00:17:49.795
Just didn't work.

405
00:17:49.795 --> 00:17:51.445
Anyway, we're gonna close there.

406
00:17:51.445 --> 00:17:52.125
And as soon as we do,

407
00:17:52.125 --> 00:17:57.035
you'll see we have our alert connector
showing up in the console, enabled yes.

408
00:17:57.035 --> 00:17:59.255
Our operations manager alerts are there.

409
00:17:59.255 --> 00:18:01.625
Notice now, we'll just highlight here,
so you can see.

410
00:18:01.625 --> 00:18:04.825
We now have some actions and
tasks specific to this.

411
00:18:04.825 --> 00:18:06.665
Delete, don't wanna do that, of course.

412
00:18:06.665 --> 00:18:09.620
But I betcha if I click Delete,
it'll let it go away without a warning.

413
00:18:09.620 --> 00:18:10.200
Right.
>> Probably.

414
00:18:10.200 --> 00:18:11.520
>> They couldn't close the console.

415
00:18:11.520 --> 00:18:14.350
But they'll screw you on
the Delete with no trouble.

416
00:18:14.350 --> 00:18:15.480
Make you do the work again.

417
00:18:15.480 --> 00:18:18.250
But we're going to stick it to them, make
them hit that close button every time.

418
00:18:18.250 --> 00:18:20.670
Right?
>> Remove all the operating systems, and

419
00:18:20.670 --> 00:18:22.045
everything is all.

420
00:18:22.045 --> 00:18:22.745
>> C:/format.
You're done.

421
00:18:22.745 --> 00:18:23.960
>> Yeah, there ya go.

422
00:18:23.960 --> 00:18:26.050
>> So, in addition,
we have properties, right?

423
00:18:26.050 --> 00:18:27.420
So, we can go and we can edit.

424
00:18:27.420 --> 00:18:30.860
We do have the ability to search,
we can do a little Synchronize Now.

425
00:18:30.860 --> 00:18:34.470
Synchronize Now pulls down
that information, and

426
00:18:34.470 --> 00:18:36.465
syncs the connector to make
sure the two are talking.

427
00:18:36.465 --> 00:18:38.455
I'll show you that in just a second.

428
00:18:38.455 --> 00:18:39.615
We can go ahead and

429
00:18:39.615 --> 00:18:44.105
start a PowerShell session from here as
well, with the service manager module.

430
00:18:44.105 --> 00:18:46.555
Remember we've shown you
the Ops manager shell,

431
00:18:46.555 --> 00:18:49.485
talked about the fact we've got
a shell for SharePoint, shell for

432
00:18:49.485 --> 00:18:54.050
Exchange, shell for this, shell for
that, it's like a big shell game, right?

433
00:18:54.050 --> 00:18:57.450
It's almost like the guy sitting on the
street corner with the cardboard box, hey,

434
00:18:57.450 --> 00:18:59.420
where's my management capabilities?

435
00:18:59.420 --> 00:19:01.640
What commandlets am I gonna use today?

436
00:19:01.640 --> 00:19:03.365
>> A second ago it sounded
like you said shellfish.

437
00:19:03.365 --> 00:19:05.810
>> [LAUGH]
>> Shellfish this and shellfish that.

438
00:19:05.810 --> 00:19:08.440
>> You're just thinking lunch time,
that's why you're thinking that.

439
00:19:08.440 --> 00:19:09.630
So, I'm just gonna click here real quick,

440
00:19:09.630 --> 00:19:12.330
we'll just take a look at two
things before we wrap up, one is,

441
00:19:12.330 --> 00:19:14.800
can we just go back to full screen,
because I'm talking about clicking and

442
00:19:14.800 --> 00:19:18.640
you're seeing nothing,
it's like box on box, screen on screen.

443
00:19:18.640 --> 00:19:20.980
So, you'll see I'm gonna click
on Start PowerShell Session,

444
00:19:20.980 --> 00:19:22.050
we'll take a look at that.

445
00:19:22.050 --> 00:19:25.570
I'm also gonna kick off synchronize for
us, so let's just click there real quick.

446
00:19:25.570 --> 00:19:28.210
We'll see this will take a second
to come up, doesn't take very long.

447
00:19:28.210 --> 00:19:32.240
Just move this down here, and you'll see
that we do now have the ability to go in,

448
00:19:32.240 --> 00:19:35.260
and use this if we want to, so
we'll have PowerShell available.

449
00:19:35.260 --> 00:19:37.940
We can go in and do that,
just get rid of that.

450
00:19:37.940 --> 00:19:42.080
We also have Synchronize Now,
synchronization request has been

451
00:19:42.080 --> 00:19:44.560
submitted, so
we're now essentially saying,

452
00:19:44.560 --> 00:19:48.270
hey, go open up that connector,
go talk to the other side.

453
00:19:48.270 --> 00:19:49.710
Grab some information.

454
00:19:49.710 --> 00:19:51.150
Let's see what's happening over here.

455
00:19:51.150 --> 00:19:52.610
Bring it back and update me.

456
00:19:52.610 --> 00:19:56.035
So, if we don't wanna wait that 60
second cycle, or whatever it is,

457
00:19:56.035 --> 00:19:58.506
we could do a manual
synchronization if we need to.

458
00:19:58.506 --> 00:20:01.691
And ever so often, you may have to do that
just to see something show up while you're

459
00:20:01.691 --> 00:20:02.430
waiting, right?

460
00:20:02.430 --> 00:20:05.420
But normally as long as the connectors
are set to communicate, and everything's

461
00:20:05.420 --> 00:20:07.880
working well, we normally don't have
to bother with the synchronization.

462
00:20:07.880 --> 00:20:10.924
But you can see that we can
do that if necessary, okay.

463
00:20:10.924 --> 00:20:11.880
>> Very good.

464
00:20:11.880 --> 00:20:16.790
Well, now, we've seen how to create this
alert connector for the Ops manager,

465
00:20:16.790 --> 00:20:17.890
very cool, right?

466
00:20:17.890 --> 00:20:23.580
Something I love how Adam was talking
about creating that whole connection life

467
00:20:23.580 --> 00:20:28.290
cycle almost where from start to finish
everything make sure that it gets touched,

468
00:20:28.290 --> 00:20:30.600
and worked on at the proper spot, and

469
00:20:30.600 --> 00:20:34.150
then ultimately completed, because
everything is now connected together.

470
00:20:34.150 --> 00:20:39.690
You don't have these ghosted tasks running
around loose, and rampant every which way.

471
00:20:39.690 --> 00:20:43.710
And going we need to go through this and
clean the system up, keeps that from

472
00:20:43.710 --> 00:20:46.720
happening, and that can be anybody
that's worked in administration for

473
00:20:46.720 --> 00:20:49.190
any length of time knows
that is a common problem.

474
00:20:49.190 --> 00:20:51.240
So, very cool that we
can make that happen.

475
00:20:51.240 --> 00:20:53.330
Adam, we thank you for
showing how we can do that, and

476
00:20:53.330 --> 00:20:54.870
we do thank you guys for watching.

477
00:20:54.870 --> 00:20:57.400
But it looks like we've come
to the end of our show.

478
00:20:57.400 --> 00:21:00.730
Signing off for ITProTV,
I've been your host Daniel Lowrie.

479
00:21:00.730 --> 00:21:02.210
>> I'm a synchronized connector.

480
00:21:02.210 --> 00:21:03.243
>> And we'll see you next time.

481
00:21:05.034 --> 00:21:10.821
[MUSIC]

482
00:21:10.821 --> 00:21:14.262
>> Thank you for watching ITPro TV.

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Adam demonstrate how to create an Operations Manger CI connector. They start by looking at the prerequisites that are necessary for the connection. Then they take you step-by-step through the creation, explaining each of the options in detail.
episodes.title: Create an Ops Manager CI Connector

Data center monitoring

That happens sometimes.

It's just one of those things.

[LAUGH]

All right, so we're gonna take a look

21
00:00:49.360 --> 00:00:52.950
In our last episode we had taken
a look at part one of two for

22
00:00:52.950 --> 00:00:54.960
the operations manager connectors.

23

We took a look at the alert connector,
walked through how to set that up.

24
00:00:58.520 --> 00:00:59.430
Pretty straightforward.

25
00:00:59.430 --> 00:01:00.670
Really not too complicated.

26
00:01:00.670 --> 00:01:03.967
This one won't be any more or
less complicated than the first one.

27
00:01:03.967 --> 00:01:05.730
It'll be the three bear analogy.

28
00:01:05.730 --> 00:01:07.687
Just right as they say.

29
00:01:07.687 --> 00:01:12.670
And we're gonna do the CI connector
configuration of the CI connector.

00:01:12.670 --> 00:01:14.940
Pretty straightforward,

00:01:14.940 --> 00:01:16.160
We're gonna right-click.

32

We're gonna do a new connector,

00:01:17.695 --> 00:01:21.070

00:01:21.070 --> 00:01:22.655
We'll set up the connector,

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Adam demonstrate how to install Integration Packs for Orchestrator. They start by looking at the prerequisites that are necessary for the installation. Then they take you step-by-step through the installation, explaining each of the options in detail.

What I mean very simply is the following.

00:08:53.590 --> 00:08:55.070

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Adam demonstrate how to configure the AD Connector to import data into System Center Service Manager. They start by looking at the prerequisites that are necessary for the installation. Then they take you step-by-step through the installation, explaining each of the options in detail.
episodes.title: Configuring the AD Connector

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Adam demonstrate how to configure the SharePoint Integration Pack connection. They start by looking at the prerequisites that are necessary for the installation. Then they take you step-by-step through the installation, explaining each of the options in detail.
episodes.title: Configuring the SharePoint Integration Pack

topics.title: Integrating Operations Manager with Other System Center Components

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Adam discuss troubleshooting, tuning, and disaster recovery using SCOM. They look at log files and enabling debug trace logging for use with troubleshooting. They also dive into tuning Management Packs and configuring SQL AlwaysOn. Finally, they configure data retention in Ops Manager.
episodes.title: Troubleshooting, Tunning and BCDR

00:41:36.465 --> 00:41:37.798
That's, I'm right here.

852
00:41:37.798 --> 00:41:38.305
Right here.

853
00:41:38.305 --> 00:41:39.330
That's what I'm gonna use.

854
00:41:39.330 --> 00:41:42.473
So that being said, we thank you Adam for
getting us this far,

855
00:41:42.473 --> 00:41:46.530
looking forward to seeing everybody here
in a part two where I expect to see you.

856
00:41:46.530 --> 00:41:48.496
We're gonna go ahead and
sign off for ITProTV,

857
00:41:48.496 --> 00:41:50.490
I've been your host Daniel Lowrie.

858
00:41:50.490 --> 00:41:51.170
>> I'm Adam Gordon.

859
00:41:51.170 --> 00:41:52.610
>> And we'll see you next time.

860
00:41:52.610 --> 00:41:59.867
[MUSIC]

861
00:41:59.867 --> 00:42:03.080
>> Thank you for watching ITPRO.TV.

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Adam continue their discussion on troubleshooting, tuning, and disaster recovery with SCOM. Here they detail the process of BCDR with regards to the Management Server(s) as well as restoring the Operational and Data Warehouse databases.
episodes.title: Troubleshooting Tunning and BCDR Part 2
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1

16

and of course, of BCDR.

There are some detailed

It's not overly complex, but

32

Because it's not as straightforward

Because if you don't do the restore

you get a nasty big old, hey, we can't

47

Show you the script involved with

We'll take a look at all that.

And we'll also go in and we'll talk

52
00:02:28.540 --> 00:02:31.820
Making some changes to make sure
that restore works the right way.

53
00:02:31.820 --> 00:02:33.190
So, let's go in.

54
00:02:33.190 --> 00:02:35.500
Let's start by talking about what happens,

55
00:02:35.500 --> 00:02:39.465
high level steps when a management server
fails, what do we do to restore it?

56
00:02:39.465 --> 00:02:42.320
And we're gonna go there.

57
00:02:42.320 --> 00:02:43.650
Getting better at that, right?

58
00:02:43.650 --> 00:02:44.420
>> You are getting better.

59

Otherwise, it sucks walking around

62

All right, so, what we're gonna

63
00:02:54.780 --> 00:02:58.710
Now, I've gone ahead, and

And I have, and

65
00:03:02.190 --> 00:03:03.250

66
00:03:03.250 --> 00:03:05.980
This is for Part Two of the demo here,

67
00:03:05.980 --> 00:03:08.820
But I have this SCOM, you can kind of see,

00:03:08.820 --> 00:03:12.250
I've got the SCOM install

00:03:12.250 --> 00:03:14.110
So we're gonna go into the D:/ drive.

00:03:15.666 --> 00:03:17.490
And on the D:/ drive, and

I didn't bother to make the command line

You don't really need to

It's just one quick thing.

But when we run setup.exe,

00:03:34.530 --> 00:03:37.460
When we run setup.exe/recover,

And this looks promising.

80
00:03:47.400 --> 00:03:48.840
Hey, I can-

I'm looking good, right?

00:03:52.550 --> 00:03:55.140
So we can go ahead, we can click Install.

But, this is the problem that

00:03:59.480 --> 00:04:02.050
Looks like it's running, and then we get

the un-smiley face, and
it came out and went wah, wah, wah,

Now they're good,

113

No cryptic error codes,

114
00:05:05.462 --> 00:05:08.062
No, yeah, we're just not interested

115
00:05:08.062 --> 00:05:09.082
You figure it out.

116

We tell you exactly what the problem is,
and I already told you what it is.

117
00:05:12.162 --> 00:05:13.992
We're not using the right set of switches.

118
00:05:13.992 --> 00:05:15.132
We're doing recover,

00:05:15.132 --> 00:05:18.900
but we got to do recover silent,

00:05:18.900 --> 00:05:20.580
The only way we could do a recover, and

00:05:25.710 --> 00:05:29.490
DR is currently supported

123
00:05:29.490 --> 00:05:32.970
So we do support recovery,

124
00:05:32.970 --> 00:05:35.600
Can't do it, in other words,
from the graphical interface.

125
00:05:35.600 --> 00:05:39.800
So we're gonna hit Cancel here,
we're gonna exit out of here knowing that.

126
00:05:39.800 --> 00:05:45.180
Now instead,

127
00:05:45.180 --> 00:05:47.790
We get to the right Notepad here.

00:05:47.790 --> 00:05:48.790
We need this.

00:05:50.180 --> 00:05:52.420
You could hopefully see

These are the high level steps,

00:05:57.670 --> 00:06:00.120

to happen to recover.

133
00:06:00.120 --> 00:06:04.520
So you'll see, build new server and
ensure computer name is the same, right,

134
00:06:04.520 --> 00:06:05.942

135
00:06:05.942 --> 00:06:10.790
Use the recovery option with the silent
switches, you can see right here.

136
00:06:10.790 --> 00:06:13.321
Setup.exe silent, accept ULA.

137
00:06:13.321 --> 00:06:16.840
One means yes, zero means no, recover.

138
00:06:16.840 --> 00:06:18.211
And then the rest of it.

139
00:06:18.211 --> 00:06:21.490
So, enable error reporting,
send CIP, or CEIP.

140
00:06:21.490 --> 00:06:24.680
Use Microsoft Update,
what's our database name?

141
00:06:24.680 --> 00:06:26.970
SQL Server instance, what's the instance?

142
00:06:26.970 --> 00:06:31.330
Data warehouse, database name, what's
the data warehouse SQL server instance?

143
00:06:31.330 --> 00:06:32.860
What's our account name?

144
00:06:32.860 --> 00:06:36.860
Data reader account,
data reader password, data writer user,

145
00:06:36.860 --> 00:06:40.900
data writer password, action account user,
action account password, right?

146
00:06:40.900 --> 00:06:45.990
So we gotta go through and do all of this,
and run this exact command this way.

147
00:06:45.990 --> 00:06:49.610
Filling in, obviously,
the variables associated, right,

148
00:06:49.610 --> 00:06:52.970
with what has to happen here
to recreate this instance.

149
00:06:52.970 --> 00:06:55.820
But if you don't take the time to
read through the documentation,

150
00:06:55.820 --> 00:06:59.030
you don't know this, you're off
to what seems like a good start.

151
00:06:59.030 --> 00:07:01.360
You hit the brick wall,
not the end of the world.

152
00:07:01.360 --> 00:07:02.640
It's easy enough to fix, right?

153
00:07:02.640 --> 00:07:05.272
It's just the time delay, the aggravation,

154
00:07:05.272 --> 00:07:08.410
you know you're under
the gun to get this fixed.

155
00:07:08.410 --> 00:07:11.390
The business is down right now,
in the sense that we're not monitoring.

156
00:07:11.390 --> 00:07:13.360
People are uptight.

157
00:07:13.360 --> 00:07:15.910
But less delays, and
the more happiness, the better, right?

158
00:07:15.910 --> 00:07:18.350
>> Dogs and cats are living together.

159
00:07:18.350 --> 00:07:19.300
>> Insane.

160
00:07:19.300 --> 00:07:19.830
>> Total chaos.

161
00:07:19.830 --> 00:07:21.125
>> Things falling out of the sky.

162
00:07:21.125 --> 00:07:23.690
>> [LAUGH]
>> It is not a good time, right?

163
00:07:23.690 --> 00:07:26.140
So we wanna make it as easy as possible,

164
00:07:26.140 --> 00:07:29.390
wanna make sure we kinda
streamline this process for you.

165
00:07:29.390 --> 00:07:33.360
Because honestly, as we're saying, this
is a stressful time in the organization.

166
00:07:33.360 --> 00:07:35.750
The less that goes wrong, and
the more that goes right,

167
00:07:35.750 --> 00:07:37.710
the happier you're going to be,
that's just the reality.

168
00:07:38.730 --> 00:07:42.970
Unlike a lot of other activities that
we engage in, the reality of this is,

169
00:07:42.970 --> 00:07:46.480
you probably don't do DR all that
often on any of these products.

170
00:07:46.480 --> 00:07:48.688
Because hopefully,
things just work the right way, and

171
00:07:48.688 --> 00:07:49.886
they don't blow up too often.

172
00:07:49.886 --> 00:07:53.078
And as a result, you may go through
a five-year maintenance in life

173
00:07:53.078 --> 00:07:55.379
cycle on this product and
never have to recover.

174
00:07:55.379 --> 00:07:58.808
Or you may have to recover,
but it may only happen once.

175
00:07:58.808 --> 00:08:02.210
Hopefully, you're in the former,
you don't have to recover at all.

176
00:08:02.210 --> 00:08:03.620
If you have to recover,

177
00:08:03.620 --> 00:08:06.650
hopefully this will at least give you
a point of reference to start from.

178
00:08:06.650 --> 00:08:09.950
But unless you're doing this
either as a consultant or

179
00:08:09.950 --> 00:08:13.580
as a test bed environment
generation kind of thing.

180
00:08:13.580 --> 00:08:16.940
You're probably not blowing things up and
having to recover them all that often.

181
00:08:16.940 --> 00:08:21.290
I talked to many, many customers, and we
talk about this concept, hey, let's plan

182
00:08:21.290 --> 00:08:25.500
for it, let's have a script set up, let's
just put the generic script in place.

183
00:08:25.500 --> 00:08:28.110
Let's make sure we keep
the variables listed, so,

184
00:08:28.110 --> 00:08:32.050
if we have to deploy, we know what it is,
you're not scrambling to figure this out.

185
00:08:32.050 --> 00:08:34.830
And they may go through
an entire product lifecycle and

186
00:08:34.830 --> 00:08:36.220
never actually have to use it.

187
00:08:36.220 --> 00:08:39.450
So it's important just to be thinking,
planning for

188
00:08:39.450 --> 00:08:42.900
success as opposed to having
to deal with it in the moment.

189
00:08:42.900 --> 00:08:45.410
Because then, it's scramble
just to figure everything out.

190
00:08:45.410 --> 00:08:46.880
So, wanna make sure you see this,

191
00:08:46.880 --> 00:08:49.820
you have a sense of this, you understand
the issues associated with this.

192
00:08:49.820 --> 00:08:53.240
So, we've dealt with that piece, and I'm
just gonna go ahead and tidy this up for

193
00:08:53.240 --> 00:08:54.360
just one second.

194
00:08:54.360 --> 00:08:59.090
Let's talk about the next piece, which is,
what do we deal with or how do we deal

with the process of recovering a failed
operational, or data warehouse database?

196

What happens if the database itself fails?

197

Server's okay, but
database's on the backend are not working,

198
00:09:08.930 --> 00:09:09.960
what are we gonna do?

199

Well if we have to go in and
recover a failed database

200

we're gonna go into the SQL Server studio
and we're gonna do some stuff in there.

201
00:09:16.950 --> 00:09:18.500
So let's go in, let's take a look.

202
00:09:18.500 --> 00:09:20.690
Got that piece set up for you as well.

203
00:09:20.690 --> 00:09:23.250
So we'll bring up
the SQL Studio here real quick.

204
00:09:23.250 --> 00:09:26.930
You can see and I'm already down in

00:09:26.930 --> 00:09:31.030
a demo of part two here about how
to edit out the named instance and

206
00:09:31.030 --> 00:09:32.660
make some changes when

00:09:32.660 --> 00:09:36.900
But you can see hopefully,
that we are in the SQL Studio,

we are in one of, I know it's kinda
hard to see because it's up at the top.

00:09:40.018 --> 00:09:43.200
Let me just bring this down, but
we're in one of the tables here for

210
00:09:43.200 --> 00:09:46.690

211
00:09:46.690 --> 00:09:52.860
But what I've done is I've right-clicked
on the databases folder at the top

Studio, and I've chosen restore.

00:09:57.940 --> 00:10:00.480
There's an option there

You'll be able to go in,
